story:
Robert Dotson "Fun" Raiser

This campaign will raise money to pay for a new heater and a winter's worth of heating oil for 91-year-old flatfoot dancing legend Robert Dotson. The remaining funds will go into the Robert Dotson Scholarship Foundation (RDSF), started by the Green Grass Cloggers to honor Robert. This scholarship is to be awarded yearly to an aspiring percussive dancer to attend dance workshops at the Swannanoa Gathering Old-Time Week.

This "Fun" Raiser kicks off with a dance celebrating Robert and his Walking Step. The dance will be held Sunday, October 12, from 2-5pm at the Old Cove Creek School Gym in Sugar Grove, NC. It features 3 great old-time bands - Laurel Creek, The Cork Lickers and the New Southern Ramblers. The Green Grass Cloggers will also be dancing. Please join us in the beautiful mountains near Boone, NC, during the height of the fall foliage colors, for an afternoon of flatfooting and square dancing. The celebration is FREE, but donations for this campaign will be accepted. Please note - NO TAPS on the gym floor!

Robert Dotson is the source of the Walking Step, a flatfoot step that the Green Grass Cloggers deciphered from his dancing in 1978. This Appalachian percussive flatfoot step changed the way the Green Grass Cloggers improvised in their freestyle step-dancing.  Since that time, Dotson's Walking Step  has been shared by the Green Grass Cloggers and the Fiddle Puppet Dancers (now Footworks) in performances and workshops throughout the US and overseas and has continued to influenced legions of percussive dancers throughout the world. 

My name is Rodney Sutton, and I was there in 1978 in Sugar Grove, North Carolina, in Robert's dance shack with the Green Grass Cloggers and the Cork Lickers. Robert and his wife Myrtle (both recipients of the 1994 NC Heritage Award) were holding one of their regular potluck, old-time music dance parties, and the little dance house with no interior walls was hanging precariously onto the hillside where Robert had built it. Since that raucous night of music making and all-night dancing, Robert's "Walking Step" has opened up the  joy of flatfoot dancing to thousands of folks, and his step is considered a "must know" if you want to be a good flatfooter. It is my, and many other folks', belief that Robert's "Walking Step" has had a comparable influence on contemporary percussive dance that parallels Earl Scruggs' 3-finger picking on the banjo and Doc Watson's flatpicking on the guitar. 

If by chance you are one of these many dancers, or maybe one of the hundreds of musicians who have played those old-time dance tunes for us to shake-a-leg to -- or maybe you are one of the many admirers of this old-time scene -- well, now here's your chance to chip in to help Robert out.

Robert has slowed down a lot this past year. He continues to be the eternal optimist and says he going to "beat this" and get back to how he was a few years ago. But the reality is his many near-death experiences on his farm over the years have taken their toll: he was nearly killed 10 years ago when a loaded gravel dump truck hit him on his tractor -- he was told his dancing days were over and that he might never walk again -- then 5 months later he was back flatfooting on stage at Merlefest. Robert also has emphysema and COPD, diabetes and AFib -- but his heart is strong, and his spirit is even stronger! He is still in good physical shape for "the shape he is in." 

I have had the pleasure of staying overnight with Robert at his house while I have been working part-time in Boone this past year. Robert is a great storyteller, and he keeps me cracked up with his old mountain sayings and his great sense of humor. He really does live his life following the golden rule -- treating folks like he wants to be treated.

For 22 years, Robert led the dances over at Slagle's Pasture Dance Hall in Elizabethton, Tenn. At that dance and countless other ones throughout the High Country around Boone, Lenoir, and Blowing Rock, North Carolina, Robert has spent the past 70-some years encouraging folks sitting down or standing around watching to come out on the dance floor and flatfoot with him. Now is the time to let him know how much we all appreciate his love and enthusiasm for sharing dancing! With the funds raised here you have the chance to help make sure Robert's legacy lives on. Any amount over the $3000 goal to pay for his new heater and fuel for the winter will go into the Robert Dotson Scholarship Foundation.

I am handling the funds for this campaign. Robert and I have opened a "special" stand-alone checking account so that he can receive donations directly from PayPal through this IndieGoGo campaign. It appears the bank set it up so it looks like it is my account, but that is only because Robert can't see good enough to sign his name - please trust me - all funds raised will go to Robert. His family and neighbors who have helped him over the years are also getting older, and Robert is healthier and sharper mentally than many of them. There are many local agencies and programs that would help Robert (like Meals on Wheels), but he does not qualify because he refuses to give up his truck, and though he hardly ever drives anywhere anymore, he tells the social workers who come out to "evaluate" him, "I can drive any damn where I want to go." That automatically knocks him out of any assistance programs.

Any donation large or small will be appreciated.

You will see that you can pay online with PayPal or credit card, or you can send a check. If you prefer to write checks, make them payable to Robert Dotson, and mail them to me: Rodney Sutton, P.O. Box 789, Marshall, NC 28753. This way, I can be sure they get deposited into his fundraising account.  In "For" or "Memo" at the bottom of your checks, please put "4Robert."

Robert Dotson & Rodney Sutton - Monday, October 13, 2014 - Sugar Grove, NC

Photo: Leanne E. Smith 


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • please help to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

Thank you so much for your support and even if you can't afford to send money right now, please send prayers and good thoughts Roberts way!

story:
It's Our 45th Anniversary!

Founded in 1969, Broom Street Theater is a small nonprofit focused on original and experimental work. Hundreds of plays produced on our stage are premiere works never before seen.

How do we keep it going? Mainly through the enthusiastic work of our volunteers, and the support of the public— ticket sales, small donations, and contributions from neighboring businesses.

Building On Our Accomplishments

We are always adapting to a changing environment. Today, we need your help to grow and thrive!

Contributions will go to help Broom Street Theater produce and promote its 2015 season. Depending on our level of success, your gift may also help us achieve some projects currently under consideration:

  • building and installing a new poster display case
  • upgrades to the lighting grid
  • course offerings and member scholarships
Our perks include an oval BST bumper sticker, tickets to upcoming performances, and refrigerator magnets, mugs, shirts, and hoodies with our 45 years logo.

Be Part Of Our Story

By giving to our campaign, you can be part of our long history of unique accomplishments. We value all contributions— we wouldn't be where we are today without the small donations that go into the baskets we pass around before each performance.

If you contribute at any level, we will contact you to ask about your shout-out preferences on Facebook or Twitter. We'll be happy to place your name in a post or tag you with a thank you for your gift.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Our greatest challenge is the same as it has always been:  to produce quality and original theater, while keeping ticket prices and participation accessible.

    If we are to achieve our goals of making participation accessible, then we will also benefit from your getting involved. Go to auditions, like us and follow us on Facebook and Twitter, submit a script, and spread the word about us and our campaign.

story:
Hello, my name is Robert Desrosiers, and I am asking for your help to bring my newest production to the stage.

Please, if you haven't already done so, watch my appeal above. You’ll know that this will be an elaborate live production, featuring dance, theatre, voice, and music, enveloped by striking imagery.

Your help will make The Choir's Carnival a reality.

Thank you,

Robert Desrosiers



Founder and Artistic Director of the Desrosiers Dance Theatre, Robert Desrosiers has produced many dance works, from pure dance to dance theatre. From the breathtaking Blue Snake in 1985 to last year’s majestic Bouffonia, Robert’s pieces share one thing in common: his unique blend of movement, sound, and imagery, combining the real and the surreal to create a spectacle that only he can bring to the stage. The Choir’s Carnival will take his body of work to the next level.

Robert is an artist unlimited by any one craft or style, restricted only by the extent his own boundless imagination. His works challenge performers in ways they did not think possible, pushing them to new heights of performance. Coupled with striking designs and passionate scores, his productions weave together all elements of the arts to convey incredible journeys through his first love: dance.



But why take our word for it? In the coming weeks we will be sharing interviews with colleagues and reviewers who have worked with Robert, giving you a firsthand account of what you can expect by supporting The Choir’s Carnival. Any donation you can provide brings us one step closer to production, and we will keep you with us every other step of the way through updates to our campaign page, videos, perks and more.

All of the donations you bring to this piece will go towards the continued creation of The Choir's Carnival. With your help, the curtain will rise on The Choir’s Carnival by the summer of 2015. The production will begin performances here in Toronto, after which cross-county Canadian and Worldwide touring.



The Choir's Carnival is on Indiegogo because we trust you for your support. This piece is being made for you, the viewer, and we want you to take a hand in bringing it to life. Part of this campaign is to show you why you want to be a part of this. That would not be possible if we took The Choir’s Carnival through the grant process.

We hope for your continued support. With it, we can go the distance.

story:
The story so far...

Everyone knows that Ireland is the best little country to give birth in…or is it?

Daughters of the Revolution is a satirical, musical, and irreverent play, examining exactly what women have to go through to get from pregnancy to birth.

And once you go down the rabbit-hole of the maternity services…who knows what could happen.

We just had a very successful sold-out run at the Harbour Playhouse with an excellent reception to the performance and art installation. The post-show discussions with professionals from the maternity services in conversation with the audience was also very successful.

Participants included Prof Chris Fitzpatrick, former master of the Coombe hospital, Marie O'Connor from Survivors of Symphysiotomy, and Philomena Canning midwife and co-founder of Midwives4Choice.

We also had a nice write-up in the Irish Times:

http://www.irishtimes.com/life-and-style/health-family/down-the-rabbit-hole-of-maternity-who-knows-what-can-happen-1.2557059

We now have video footage, photos, and audio recordings of the post-show discussions that will be made publicly available through podcasts on www.4elements.ie

The next step is to take Daughters of the Revolution on tour...

Join our heroine Evelyn Murphy on her epic journey through maternity, as she bravely contends with consultants, her mother, her partner, and the attentions of well-meaning friends.

Evelyn’s story creates a picture of contemporary Ireland in a time of rising birth-rates, uncertain economic prospects, and a health service in crisis.  In a year of celebrating uprisings, and renewed debate around the treatment of women in the Irish Constitution, Daughters of the Revolution asks: how free are women in Ireland when it comes to maternity?

Daughters of the Revolution takes a sardonic look at how women have to perform to meet the complex demands of society.

A word from Kate Harris, writer and director of Daughters of the Revolution 

Hi there! Thank you for checking out our campaign. Here is a little background on how we got here.

The idea for Daughters of the Revolution started a few years ago with the birth of my own daughter.  My experience of the Irish maternity services was bewildering and often inexplicably infuriating, so being a theatre maker I responded by making theatre. 

In 2013 CREATE awarded me a grant to research women’s experience of maternity in Ireland.  I ran workshops with women, talked to researchers, academics, medical practitioners, and student-midwives.  The result is a satirical and largely irreverent look at pregnancy, birth, and the HSE. 

At the heart of this play is the question of power, and when we’re talking about women’s bodies especially in Ireland, it is all about who has the power. 

It is an intensely exciting time to be a woman making theatre in Ireland. 

Join the revolution, with your help we can bring women's voices and experience centre-stage.

But wait...there is more

We are going take you on a massive journey of sight, sound, and dialogue through the maternity experience. The play, Daughters of the Revolution, will be framed by an art installation before the show and an expert panel discussion each night following the performance.

4elements’ Artist in Residence Coral Mallow will transform the entrance to the theatre space into an interactive art installation.  Centred on issues of agency and body autonomy as experienced by women in the Irish maternity services, the exhibition will investigate the social perceptions around maternity.

The exhibition will also include contributions from the artist Anne Marie Kilshaw-Visual Arts Director of the Complex, Paul Timon from the Dublin Camera Club, and Martina Hynan with excerpts from her 'Keeping Mum' project with the Claire Birth Project. 

Having started a conversation through art and performance, we will extend the conversation through a series of chaired post-show discussions.

The panel will bring together experts in the field of maternity and social policy to engage in open and honest dialogue with the audience in a safe, creative space. The conversations will be recorded and edited to be uploaded as podcasts to a dedicated SoundCloud account under the title Daughters of Revolution.

What you can make happen

We need your contributions and support to bring Daughters of the Revolution on tour:

Your contribution will go directly to the production of the event on tour:

  • Sound and Lighting Technicians
  • Payment for Actors
  • Royalities for Original Music by Doc O'Connor
  • Venue Hire
  • Insurance

What we will give you (don't mind the expiry date, we will make it happen!) 

Participant €10: Special thank you on the 4elements website and in the programme

Activator €25: Original Daughters of the Revolution poster signed by the cast and crew plus a thank you on the programme and website

Facilitator €50: Exclusive invitation for the Opening Night near you with two tickets to Daughters of the Revolution, as well as the signed poster and special thank you

Dramaturge €100: Limited edition soft-bound copy of the Daughters of the Revolution script signed by the cast and crew, as well as the exclusive invitation to the VIP reception, two tickets to the play, signed poster, and special thank you

Patron €250: Dinner for you and a guest in a restaurant with the cast and crew of Daughters of the Revolution, as well as the limited edition signed script, exclusive invitation to the VIP reception with two tickets to the play, signed poster, and special thank you in the programme and a permanent listing on the 4elements website as a patron of the arts.

Austerity hitting your wallet? You can still join the revolution by spreading the word. So please share this campaign on Facebook and Twitter, tell your friends, colleagues, and family.  And of course we could always use volunteers, don't be shy, get in touch. Help make Daughters of the Revolution happen.

The impact:

Daughters of the Revolution is an experiment in using art and performance to shape a public response to the crisis in the Irish maternity services. We are women exploring the underlying conflict between women’s bodily autonomy and the law, with humour and our unique insight on the experience of maternity in Ireland. 

This response is both timely and necessary. Since the death of Savita Halappanavar in University Hospital Galway in October 2012, the maternity services in Ireland have been in a state of continued crisis. The 8th amendment of the Irish constitution has also come under renewed scrutiny in the aftermath of Savita’s death, and the Protection of Life During Pregnancy Act, especially in light of the ‘Y’ case, has done nothing to halt public disquiet in that area.

In the contested narrative of maternity in Ireland, it is time for women to have their say.

With your help we can start the journey, join the Revolution today.

We are:

4elements Theatre Company is committed to ambitious theatre performance. Founded in 2009, 4elements incorporates political and social issues into a broader cultural discussion.  Our goal is to create exceptional artistic experiences based on social engagement.  4elements draws of participatory theatre practices including Augusto Boal’s Theatre of the Oppressed, using theatre to create dialogue within society.

Kate Harris-I have been working as a drama facilitator and theatre maker since 2005. I use Theatre of the Oppressed and other participatory theatre techniques to work in partnership with artists, community groups, and educational institutions.  I have created performances with a wide range of youth and community groups, working through theatre to combat social exclusion and start dialogues within the communities around the issues affecting them.  
Some of my previous work includes: Home (2012) Devised and directed in collaboration with actress Sarah Tapes and performed as a work in progress at the Project Arts Centre; Dodgy Dealings (2011) Devised and written in collaboration with Henrietta Street Adult Community Education Centre, performed at the Dublin Five Lamps Arts Festival in April 2012; Wasted (2011) Devised with ARTSI and the Community Response Drama Group; and Hidden Voices Trilogy (2009) Three short films produced by Community Response Drama Group.

thank you
Dramaturge
€100: Limited edition soft-bound copy of the Daughters of the Revolution script signed by the cast and crew, as well as the exclusive invitation to the VIP reception, two tickets to the play, signed poster, and special thank you
Patron €250: Dinner
for you and a guest in a restaurant with the cast and crew of Daughters of the Revolution, as well
as the limited edition signed script, exclusive invitation to the VIP reception with two tickets to the play, signed poster, and special
thank you in the programme and a permanent listing on the 4elements website as a patron of the arts.
Austerity hitting your wallet? You can still join the revolution by spreading the word. So please share this campaign on Facebook and Twitter, tell your friends, colleagues, and family.  And of course we could always use volunteers, don't be shy, get in touch. Help make Daughters of the Revolution happen.

The impact:
Daughters of the Revolution is an experiment in using art and
performance to shape a public response to the crisis in the Irish maternity
services. We are women exploring the underlying conflict between women’s bodily
autonomy and the law, with humour and our unique insight on the experience of
maternity in Ireland.  
This
response is both timely and necessary. Since the death of Savita Halappanavar
in University Hospital Galway in October 2012, the maternity services in Ireland have been
in a state of continued crisis. The 8th amendment of the Irish constitution has
also come under renewed scrutiny in the aftermath of Savita’s death, and the
Protection of Life During Pregnancy Act, especially in light of the ‘Y’ case, has done nothing to halt public disquiet in that area.
In the
contested narrative of maternity in Ireland, it is time for women to have their
say.
With your
help we can start the journey, join the Revolution today.
We are:
4elements
Theatre Company is committed to ambitious theatre performance. Founded in 2009,
4elements incorporates political and social issues into a broader cultural
discussion.  Our goal is to create
exceptional artistic experiences based on social engagement.  4elements draws of participatory theatre
practices including Augusto Boal’s Theatre of the Oppressed, using theatre to
create dialogue within society. 
Kate Harris-I have been working as a drama facilitator and theatre maker since 2005. I use Theatre of the Oppressed and other participatory theatre techniques to
work in partnership with artists, community groups, and educational institutions.  I have created performances with a wide range of youth and community
groups, working through theatre to combat social exclusion and start dialogues
within the communities around the issues affecting them.  Some of my previous work includes: Home (2012) Devised and directed
in collaboration with actress Sarah Tapes and performed as a work in progress
at the Project Arts Centre; Dodgy Dealings (2011) Devised and written in
collaboration with Henrietta Street Adult Community Education Centre, performed
at the Dublin Five Lamps Arts Festival in April 2012; Wasted (2011) Devised with
ARTSI and the Community Response Drama Group; and Hidden Voices Trilogy (2009) Three short
films produced by Community
Response Drama Group.

story:
Short Summary

My fellow classmates and I are soon to be seniors at Millikin University. And we are looking to do something huge! We plan to direct our own production of the tribal rock musical HAIR on Millikin University's campus. This will be a good culmination of our theatre education while at school and an impactful way to start off our senior year. By casting the show this spring and rehearsing over the summer, we hope to produce HAIR on September 15th on our own school quad.  We need your help!  Shows are not cheap to produce.  But we think this one's message is worth it.

The Impact

HAIR is not only a musical, but a movement. In the 60's it addressed issues in America involving, race, drugs, free love, war, peace, and what it really means to be an American. It is clearly evident that the problems we faced in the 60's are the same problems we face today. People are just as divided about the War on Terror as they where with the Vietnam War. The right for the freedom to marry draws parallels to the civil rights struggle we as a nation faced in the 1960's. The economic and political climate in this nation is bubbling. Time Magazine named their Person of the Year for 2011 'The Protestor' and, with the upcoming Presidential election, the youth are showing their direct power in influencing the politics of this nation, making this the perfect time to produce HAIR. 

What We Need

$200 – refundable safety deposit for rights and material

$95 – recorded orchestrations for rehearsals

$25 – campus event security

$25 – refundable prop deposit

$100 – costume rental deposit, costume cleaning

$100- lights rental

$100- miscellaneous production costs

$645 - total

Other Ways You Can Help

Please come and support us on September 15th as we bring this brilliant piece of theatre to Millikin University!  Admission to the show is free!

story:
Three Cat Productions is a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of Three Cat Productions must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. 

  

Support Three Cat Productions

Three Cat Productions is thrilled to present our exciting 2013/14 Season at the Berger Park Coach House Theater in the Edgewater neighborhood of Chicago. The season features three unique, world premiere productions from Chicago-based playwrights and furthers our mission to nurture a broad variety of artists.    (Special thanks to Gary Gimmestad for composing the music for our fundraising video.)

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $5,000 to support our season of new voices. The funds will be used for Joint Attention, Tell Me When It Hurts, and the 2014 Chicago New Work Festival.

$2,000 - Scenery, costumes, props, lighting and sound equipment. 

Want to help purchase the set pieces for Joint Attention? Or lighting supplies, including a new light board? Costumes for Tell Me When It Hurts? For an organization like ours, every penny truly helps.

$2,000 - Artist Wages

Help compensate our talented team of designers, actors, and production crew for their hard work! With 10 actors and more than 10 people making up the production crews, a lot of talented people are collaborating to bring Joint Attention and Tell Me When It Hurts to the stage.

$750 - Marketing 

Our wonderful designs have been donated by the talented designer and Three Cat co-founder Rob Dorn. Your donation can help cover our other marketing costs, including the printing of posters, postcards, and banners.

$250 - Scripts Printing

The 2014 Chicago New Work Festival will feature staged readings of eight new works. To print scripts for even one of the new works can cost up to $80 per show.

The Impact

Three Cat fosters Chicago-based artists in long-term nurturing relationships. Hearing works in readings helps playwrights advance their works. Full productions bring both new voices to audiences and help playwrights grow as artists. Your donation directly makes this happen for several playwrights this year via the main stage season and the New Work Festival. 

Ways You Can Help

Can't afford to contribute right now.  We understand!  You can still support Three Cat.  Help spread the word about the campaign and about our season

About Our Season

Joint Attention by Pat Curtis

A young couple’s son is diagnosed with autism, and they struggle with the extraordinary challenges that follow. As they wrestle with conflicting medical opinions and an abundance of inconsistent information, their relationship becomes strained, and they discover life’s normal issues won’t wait while they strive to understand their son’s condition.

Joint Attention explores the pitfalls of a still unfamiliar and misunderstood condition, and the dedication and determination required to address it.


Tell Me When It Hurts by Lisa Scott

Stripped of his ER and rejected by his love, Dr. Guy Better is in crisis. Over the course of one night, a pair of off-kilter clinic patients and a surly police officer push him toward catharsis and renewal.

Playing with the fantastical and the absurd, Tell Me When It Hurts blends sincerity and silliness to create an ultimately warm-hearted work about the real pain of living.


Hang Your Hat at Mister K’s book by Jarrin Davis

Step into the smoked-filled world of Chicago’s early jazz era as Ella, Barbra and the crew take us on a red-hot vocal ride in the new musical revue Hang Your Hat at Mr. K’s. Seen through the eyes of a cook and bellhop who watch in the background as magic unfolds, the musical revue recalls stories from one of Chicago’s most famous jazz clubs, where many well-known musicians and comedians started their careers.

Hang Your Hat at Mr. K’s spans three colorful decades. Packed with music, comedy and dance, it is sure to delight audiences who remember the crackling Chicago jazz era or are discovering its vibrant history for the first time.


Chicago New Work Festival

Developed with the goal of showcasing Chicago playwrights, fostering playwright-director partnerships, and bringing new works to the Edgewater neighborhood, the second annual Chicago New Work Festival will take place in January 2014 at the Berger Park Coach House Theater. The festival will feature eight Chicago-area playwrights, each partnered with Chicago-area directors to workshop new plays or musicals. We are proud to be able to offer playwrights the opportunity to advance their works.

We are proud to be able to offer playwrights the opportunity to advance their works.

story:
Hi, friends!

You may know us as musical comedians. You may know us as actors from going to University together or working together in various productions in and out of NYC. You may know us from brunch. What you may not know is that we've had a 10 year dream of doing this wonderful comedic play where we are cast as hilarious BFF's together. We first did a scene from this play in college and that sealed our friendship onstage and off. We took it to competition. We're ready to take it to the world.

We're the right age to make these characters really come alive, and the play is hilarious and smart. We have excellent talent attached in the form of a fabulous Director and other highly experienced professional theater folk who are ready to dive head first into this project and make it happen. This is not our first time at the rodeo, we know what it takes to produce a quality theatre production in NYC and we know how to save money doing it while still creating an unforgettable experience for the audience and everyone involved. We have the passion, the time and the drive. We have the talent, the creativity and the plan. What we don't have is...the money.

IF YOU HAVE EVER WANTED TO MAKE SOMEONE'S DREAM COME TRUE, THIS IS YOUR CHANCE. 

If you've never helped produce a play before, a lot goes into it!

We need to:

  • Rent a wonderful space that you'll be comfortable coming to
  • Purchase materials for the set, props, & costume pieces
  • Pay for rehearsal space
  • Pay for the rights

...and MUCH more including marketing and promotions so people actually come enjoy it. We don't even plan to pay ourselves. This is a labor of LOVE.

If we don't make our goal here, we're taking whatever we get and applying it to the list above and will continue to work our butts off making this dream happen. We're not quitters. Let's do this.

Other Ways You Can Help!

  • Share this campaign EVERYWHERE! Include the link in a personal email to your closest friends and family.
  • Post this campaign link with a sincere comment on Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, Google+...
  • Mention this campaign and making dreams come true on your blog or website. We support every single person who supports us. You know us, we work hard. We care. We only play divas on stage! ;)
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

We thank you from the bottom of our heart. Stay tuned for videos and photos and other fun things we'll be sharing with you here. Again, you're making a decade-long dream come true. You're making magic. You're making us tear up...and we love you for it.

story:
I am Menelik Shabazz, award-winning filmmaker, known as one of the pioneers of black British cinema. I recently produced the acclaimed THE STORY OF LOVERS ROCK documentary. Now I am on a new adventure a musical theatre play THE AWAKEN ONE. 

THE AWAKEN ONE is a story of JASON a young man who enters the spirit world of his ancestors who tells him stories that lead to his transformation and mission to become an guide/angel to help mankind. The story is told against the backdrop of young black men in London and the USA who are killing themselves brutally. The play presents this theme in an original way by taking us into the twilight world of the African Ancestors where the past, present and future meet. There, Jason encounters Malcolm X, Dr Martin Luther King, Marcus Garvey and the Pharaohs of ancient Egypt Akhenaton and Tutankhamen. These encounters make him reflect on his life and journey in both worlds.

I decided to venture into theatre because it is a more direct way of dealing with this project, which I am bursting at the seams to get out.

This project has me feeling so passionate because I want to make a difference to the narrow world that many young blackmen and women are living in and create and create a cross generational story. I want to open up new landscape of ideas and different storytelling through theatre, song, dance, spoken word and multi-media. At the heart I want to tell a universal story that everyone can relate to.

Those of you that know my work will know that I produce work of high standard and work that has a vision and longevity.  I have surrounded myself with a strong cast of actors who have all worked in film, TV and theatre. Including Angela Wynter (EastEnders), Victor Romero Evans ( Burning An Illusion/Mark For Death), Lovers Rock singer Janet Kay (Silly Games).

I have already have bookings in theatres in London, and Midlands/ UK and there is a strong interest in the USA and Caribbean.

I am here on Indiegogo to build a community of support for this project because this way allows me to be free to express my vision. It also fits within my vision to involve a community of likeminded people in my work. My film THE STORY OF LOVERS ROCK was previous example of this and I want to translate this experience into this project to keep this concept going.

I am asking for your support to raise $50,000 in order to be able to perform this play and meet the performance dates in October/November.

There are several levels of affordable donations:

  1. $75 you will receive a signed certificate from me to acknowledge your contribution
  2. $150.00 you will receive a signed certificate from me and inclusion in a commemorative booklet.
  3. $400.00 you will receive a ticket to the show in London and a chance to meet and greet the cast and crew, signed certificate from me and inclusion in a commemorative booklet.  
  4. $1500.00 you will receive an Associate Producer Credit for the first run of shows (no points), a signed certificate and inclusion in the commemorative booklet.

Lets spread the word and share this opportunity to your friends and family.  This is a unique chance to create something extremely special and historical with a lasting legacy.

I thank you.

LETS MAKE OUR RELATIONSHIP WORK

Menelik Shabazz

Writer and Director

story:
Sponsor one Theater workshop by italytime in every school!

Created by italytime and based on a new script by Paolo Tartamella, our ‘Pinocchio in Manhattan’ is the first workshop where kids of the age 6-11 get to learn the Theater methodology, improvise with professional actors and perform on stage with Pinocchio. A lot of activities! But one simple message, which is so urgent in today's world and so needed for the generations to come: don’t lie! However hard it may look and feel, truth is the only place where individuals and society find their freedom, the only grounds for a sustainable future. We have to promote a culture of truth now, in our schools and in our communities.  

The Pinocchio in Manhattan program by italytime has two clear objectives: 

1. Spread a culture of truth, with a compelling and contemporary message, centered around the world-known character of Pinocchio and his new friends (original script by Paolo Tartamella) 

2. Build social engagement and creativity via the Theater methodology (play directed in schools by Vittorio Capotorto, with the participation of two professional actors)

Kids will have the chance to interact with two professional actors, integrate the Pinocchio in Manhattan story, create the ending of the story, and perform on stage to express themselves and learn the Pinocchio lesson by ‘living it’ on stage! 



Teatromania – italytime is an international not-for-profit project conceived by Vittorio Capotorto and Francesco Pagano, with the endorsement of Dacia Maraini and Roberto Saviano, whose objectives are:

1.  To give new artists the chance to create and re-invent Italian arts, design & culture

2.  To allow kids and teens to nurture their imagination & social engagement

3.  To include everyone from the most diverse background to exchange contemporary Italian experiences

Our mission is to share with the world the irresistible beauty of new Italian cultural experiences. At the center of the world: NYC.

Our goal is to create the first permanent Casa Teatrale where the best of Italian Theater and the power of live performances will help especially the young to nurture their dreams, discover their identity and build a better world.

The italytime Team offers the following programs:

·  Theater workshops for children and schools

And also:

·  Live Theater shows, featuring new artists and new artistic work

·  Classic Italian Movies and live Theater nights

·  Selected soirees featuring short movies from new Italian Directors and live Theater performances

·  Theater Practicums, to learn the Theater methodology and perform on stage, while perfecting the Italian language

·  Readings and Monologues delivered to your door

And, much more!


Visit us at www.italytime.org    www.facebook.com/italytime

story:
The premiere of UNCOUPLING will feature Michael Mizerany’s brazen and unabashedly bold choreography, and will showcase his dynamic and dangerous partnering maneuvers.

On the tour, I'll be bring 4 of San Diego's finest dancers:  Blythe Barton, Bradley R. Lundberg, Erica Ruse and Justin Viernes.

UNCOUPLING will be part of the 30th Anniversary Celebration of the Arts and Issues Performance Series at my Alma mater, Southern Illinois University at Edwardsville.  I will also debut my new company COMPULSION DANCE & THEATRE at this event!

Help fund this Tour To The Midwest To Premiere UNCOUPLING!! 

To give you an idea of where your generosity goes,

  • Airfare - $1,750.00. Purchase 5 round trip tickets from San Diego to St. Louis.
  • Dancer Payment - $2000. Performance Stipends for Blythe, Bradley, Erica and Justin
  • Rehearsal Space - $250. Space to choreograph and rehearse for the premiere of UNCOUPLING

And with Indiegogo Flexible Funding, the campaign will receive all funds raised regardless if we meet our final goal.  Fantastic!

Performance Details:

Saturday, February 21, 2015.  7:30 PM

Southern Illinois University

Dunham Hall

Edwardsville, IL 62026

Visit http://artsandissues.com/millsworks.shtml for artist roster.

The premiere of UNCOUPLING will feature Michael Mizerany’s brazen and unabashedly bold choreography, and will showcase his dynamic and dangerous partnering maneuvers.On the tour, I'll be bring 4 of San Diego's finest dancers:  Blythe Barton, Bradley R. Lundberg, Erica Ruse and Justin Viernes.
UNCOUPLING will be part of
the 30th Anniversary Celebration of the Arts and Issues Performance
Series at my Alma mater, Southern Illinois University at Edwardsville.  I will also debut my new company COMPULSION DANCE & THEATRE at this event!

story:
Event and Company Summary:

NGD Clothing presents: Battle Grounds.  A dance event that is going to promote urban culture in head to head tournament style battles. Our company NGD Clothing is a street and urban clothing line that specializes in design and print and we aim to design clothing that can be worn by people of all ages, shapes, colors and sizes. NGD Clothing is a company that thrives and receives great inspiration from hiphop culture.  To us at NGD Clothing hiphop is more than just music, it's a lifestyle. Hiphop is a way of life ,a culture. It's a tool that can be used as an outlet that youth and young adults can use in a positive manner to help release and get there voice out there to be heard and seen. Whether it's via fashion, dance, music or any other artistic form. So we at NGD Clothing want to create this event as an opportunity for those who have a passion for dance to showcase there talent and show people what they can do and what they are capable of.

Event Details:

This event will be held at a local spot in Tempe, Az. However in order to create the best environment possible we will need some assistance from the people to help get the necessary tools and to promote and spread the word in every way we can. Some things needed for the event will be a DJ, Sounds equipment, lighting equipment, staff to help run the event, booths for vendors and other local business owners to showcase they're works, host of the event, judges and other miscellaneous details. Also we need to promote the event to help get publicity so theses dancers and performers can show the whole city what they can do.

Event Impact:

Any and all contributions will be greatly appreciated. This event is not even about our clothing line or what we do as a company, its about giving those an opportunity to show who they are. There is so much unseen and untapped potential that no one ever sees or has heard of. So many talented people have fallen in between the cracks just because they were never given the opportunity to display themselves. And keeping that in mind we at NGD Clothing have created this event to help bring public those who want to be seen and give an opportunity to be showcased.

Event Challenges:

The challenge of the event is simple. Making it a successful event. Without the proper funding there is no way we can put on a successful event that is going to be properly done, property promoted and properly sustained. So if our funding goal is not meant then that means it will be very difficult a good show. We want to make sure this event is going to be the best it possibly can, so a fair opportunity is offered to those who want to be apart of it. Without help then there is a possibility the event will fail and we wont be able to go through with the project at all.

Event Contributions:

$1.00 - Thank you! every dollar will be a great contribution towards our goal and will be greatly appreciated.

$5.00 - Post Card - You will receive a NGD Clothing post card sent out to you to show how greatly appreciative we are for your contribution. 

$15.00 - custom sticker - receive a custom made NGD Clothing sticker sent directly to you after the end of the campaign.

$30.00 - get an NGD Art Print! - We at NGD also create custom Art Prints! and when $30.00 is received a custom NGD art print will be sent straight to your front door! (Free shipping included)

$50.00 - Receive a NGD t-shirt. Receive a free NGD Clothing tee specially made by us here at NGD and sent directly to your front door (Free shipping included)

$75.00 - Receive a NGD crewneck sweater. NGD will send out one of our custom designed sweaters also delivered straight to the front door. (Free shipping included)

$150.00 -Tee and a hat - Receive an NGD  made t-shirt and snapback hat - Receive one tee and one snapback hat that has been specially designed and made by us at NGD clothing. Delivered straight to you. (Free shipping included)

$300.00 - Receive a Tee, sweater, and snapback hat. Receive 3 NGD made items! one tee, one crewneck and one snapback hat! all made by us here at NGD Clothing. Delivered to you and only you. (Free shipping included)

$500.00 - Fresh package - Receive 4 NGD items! get a tee, tank top, crewneck sweater, and snapback hat!. All made by the one and only NGD Clothing. and as always promised shipped directly to your front door. (Free shipping included)

Can't donate? No problem!

If you cant donate that's no problem at all! All we ask is that you help spread the word! save the flyer image below and simply post it your social media: Facebook, Twitter, or IG. Helping spread the word can help immensely in helping this event spread like wildfire!


Where to find more info?

Want to keep up on the event status and see how things are going? then follow NGD Clothing. We will post continuous updates about the event on all our social media sites. So follow us on Twitter, IG, and Facebook to keep up.

FB: https://www.facebook.com/ngdwear

Twitter: https://twitter.com/NerdyGDesign

Website: http://www.ngdclothing.com/

IG: @ngdclothing or @mrngd

story:
Short Summary

Musical of the Year is the story of a composer’s 60-year attempt to write the ultimate award-winning musical. A lovingly irreverent, tongue-in-cheek tribute to the musicals we have known and loved for generations.

In 1958 and college sweethearts Rudy Brown and Lizzy Conlon embark on writing the ultimate award-winning musical. Year after year they set out to “improve” their work by emulating whatever has most recently won Broadway’s Musical of the Year. Thus they begin a 60-year process of adapting their work (based on a certain 19th century French novel), purloining the musical styles of Lerner and Loewe, Rodgers & Hammerstein, Kander & Ebb, Jerry Herman, Stephen Sondheim, Andrew Lloyd Webber, Stephen Schwartz, Boublil & Schonberg and virtually every other composer in the musical theatre canon. Will they ever win the award? Will their relationship survive?


What We Need & What You Get

We need £2500 to ensure that we can firstly, provide props and costume for the opening run (April 2015 - already in rehearsal!) and secondly, we want to take Musical of the Year forward onto a national tour and an appearance at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2016.

The funds will be distributed in the following order:

1. Props and costume for the current cast in rehearsal

2. Payment for the live band over four nights

3. Contribution to the church where the performance will be held

4. Planning and PR costs to take Musical of the Year to its second stage - a national tour!

What you get:

See the perks for helping us to fund Musical of the Year x

The Impact

Composer Stephen Lanigan-O'Keeffe is now rehearsing his third original musical and this piece of work captures his startling musical talent and wickedly dry humour perfectly. In order to avoid stagnation, new musicals have to come from somewhere and Elokay Productions feel that Musical of the Year needs to be seen and seriously considered as a contender for national and eventually international fame. 

With a cast and crew of up and coming musical theatre professionals, you could help to make our dream of presenting a brand new, hilarious musical come true.

Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't help us financially, you can spread the word and get our cast playing to full houses for the entirety of the run!

Please share these links to the event:

April 8th to 11th at 7.30pm

St Stephen's, Hampstead

Tickets: https://www.ticketsource.co.uk/musicaloftheyear

http://youtu.be/ZxRcQU-L5gw

https://www.facebook.com/events/658210324302496/?ref_newsfeed_story_type=regular

#musicaloftheyear

story:
The Company:

Tinted Windows is a New York based company comprised of female dancers. The company was founded by Carly Lepore as a means to express her artistic drive with like minded collaborators. The four dancers of Tinted Windows are recent NYU Tisch grads who share a commitment to movement and the creation process.

The Help Needed:

We need your help! Creating any dance piece, evening length or otherwise, is an intense process both creatively and logistically. Many people contribute their time, energy, and ideas in order to make the company’s dream a reality. Every little bit helps! All of the money raised will go to the collaborators: dancers, designers, and Gibney’s production team. These people deserve compensation for their hard work and unyielding passion for Tinted Window’s performance.

The Great Beyond:

Take a look at the company!

  • Like us on Facebook: www.facebook.com/tintedwindowsdance
  • Follow us on Instagram: @tintedwindowsdanc
  • About the performance: gibneydance.org/event/pop-performance-tinted-windows/2018-07-26/

story:
Who We Are:

Mildred’s Umbrella is a non-profit theater company based in Houston, Texas focused on producing plays by women, increasing gender parity in the performing arts, and promoting unique stories and viewpoints.

What's going on:

An anonymous donor has challenged us to raise $5,000 in two weeks. If we meet this challenge the donor will MATCH it! C'mon y'all, who doesn't like a challenge? Read more about why Mildred's Umbrella is important below. 

What We Believe:

  • Everyone deserves access to great, thought-provoking art, so we keep our prices low and offer free tickets to low-income students.
  • Artists should be paid for their work. You wouldn’t work for free, so why should they? We pay everyone on our creative teams.
  • Art should ask questions, help us see things differently and make sense of the world around us. We will not compromise this value just for a show that sells.

What this means:

Because we are dedicated to bringing you work you have never seen, plays that offer a different perspective, art that helps you find meaning…sometimes we don’t quite fit in. You know how that is. We make weird art that makes people think and is sometimes hard to explain. Sometimes that’s not super popular like the 7000th performance of A Christmas Carol. Sometimes (most times) it is. Because we are ALWAYS working but not always making bank, we absolutely rely on funding from government agencies, foundations, businesses, and individual donors to make all this possible. TL;DR: Without community support, Mildred’s Umbrella, the only women-focused theatre in Houston, would close.

Don't believe us? Our space-mates just announced they're closing shop due to funding shortfalls. It happens. Funding from government sources is on the decline. Foundations and businesses are still unsteady following the recession and not willing to take a risk on risky, groundbreaking theatre. People are a little scared at the state of the world and afraid to spend on art instead of a bunker. We understand.

We won’t fault your very realistic and rational fear of the future, but we are here to help you through it. That’s what art does. It makes the fear go away. It brings an ounce of sense (or nonsense) to the world. It’s what we do. It gets us by, gets us to dinner, gets us through, gets us better and more. And it’s why you should help us.

Please donate to Mildred’s Umbrella today. We have a phenomenal season planned and we don’t want to cut a thing. You need art. And right, now, art needs you.  

Our 2017-18 Season

IN A WORD
by Lauren Yee, July 27-August 12, 2017

Directed by Troy Scheid

Today is the two-year anniversary of Fiona’s son’s disappearance, and still, nothing makes sense to her. Not her blasé husband, the incompetent detective, or the neighborhood kidnapper who keeps introducing himself in the checkout line. As Fiona delves back into her memories of that fateful day, to uncover that crucial missing piece, grief and comedy collide, and ordinary turns of phrase take on dangerous new meanings.

"some of the best work we’ll see on a Houston stage this year." Natalie De La Garza, Houston Press.

"poignant, funny and surprising." Wei-Huan Chen, Houston Chronicle


FEATHERS AND TEETH
by Charise Castro Smith, October 19-November 4, 2017

Directed by Jacey Little

Home-sweet-home turns into a haunted house for thirteen-year-old Chris when Carol—her father’s new fiancée—moves in. Struggling with the recent death of her mother, Chris is convinced Carol is evil, but she just can’t persuade Dad. When a mysterious, potentially dangerous but kind of cute creature is found in the family’s backyard, Chris assumes it’s a sign from above to eliminate Carol once and for all. This imaginative, bone-chilling, and wildly funny play brings the notion of dysfunctional family drama to sensationally scary heights.
 

WELL
by Lisa Kron, January 18-February 3, 2018

Directed by Bree Bridger

Well is a funny and touching comedy about mothers and daughters, mind over body, social activism and theatre itself. Lisa, the onstage playwright, attempts a memory play about her force-of-nature mother, Ann, who though constantly ill manages to heal a community. Besides Lisa and her mom, the show presents doctors and fellow patients at the hospital to which Lisa goes when she finds herself beset by the same sort of disabling allergies as her mother. We are also introduced to residents of the Lansing area, which Ann Kron organized to become a community.

 

DARK MATTER (short plays by Don Nigro)
by Don Nigro, March 29-April 14, 2018

Directed by Jennifer Decker and Miranda Herbert

A darkly humorous anthology of plays focused on female protagonists, by Don Nigro  including Tales from the Red Rose Inn, Lucy and the Mystery of the Vine-Encrusted Mansion, Higgs Field, The Malefactor's Bloody Register, Darkness Like a Dream, Wharburton's Cook, Things that Go Bump in the Night, and Uncle Clete's Toad.

 

MUSEUM OF DYSFUNCTION X: New Short Plays by Emerging and Established Playwrights 
Various Playwrights, June 21-30, 2018

For the tenth year in a row we are curating a collection of the odd and unsung with two weekends of new short plays by emerging and established playwrights. Sourced from around the world, our reading panel selects the top 20 for production, which are then thrown together by local artists. Like last year, we're holding ten spots exclusively for student writers.

story:
“Remember what it says in the bible: aim for the stomach and he’ll bleed heavily but won’t die straight away.”

Cream Tea and Incest
 

What a title! But what's it about?

Romance! Adventure! Murder! Aristocrat Eddie Spangler and valet Jeffrey must learn the meaning of these words and more in this new knockabout Edwardian comedy. Delight in their capers, mix-ups, and the dead bodies left in their wake. 

Join Eddie Spangler, an incompetent but optimistic Englishman and his loyal valet, Jeffrey, on a simple matchmaking quest that quickly deteriorates into a race against time when the Machiavellian forces of the aristocracy move to wreak their vengeance. Lord Wiggins is set to inherit Rhodesia upon his marriage to Emily Rhodes, but their romance is faltering. It is up to Eddie and Jeffrey to sort Wiggins out as quickly and violently as possible. Meanwhile – the evil Lord Biggins lurks in the shadows, waiting to execute dark schemes of his own…

http://www.thehopetheatre.com/productions/cream...

From a sell-out run at the 2017 Edinburgh Festival Fringe comes the world’s first 2.5 dimensional show set in a world where every prop and set piece is made out of cardboard.

★★★★ Broadway Baby                      "Highly Recommended Show" FringeReview

 

Our Story

A four hander, written and performed by Benjamin Alborough with Eoin McAndrew, Edward Spence and Aidan Cheng, Cream Tea and Incest has been in development and preview since September 2016 with a rotating cast and creative team. This has done wonders for the show and we're very grateful that so many people have lent their time and talents to it.

We've had the great fortune of performing the play before; for two nights at the 2017 Leicester Comedy Festival, three nights at The Bread & Roses Theatre in April 2017 and a week-long run at Surgeon's Hall at the 2018 Edinburgh Fringe. Our show sold out its run at Edinburgh but we ended up just barely covering our costs. We've already put quite a bit of our own money into the show but we've now reached a stage where we can no longer afford to do this. 

All shows that play at The Hope Theatre have to pay their actors a legal wage. This is great and we love Equity's work but we need your help to make it happen! 

The show went down well at Edinburgh and we're planning to ramp it up even further as we move to an Off West End theatre. We've increased the size of our team and have a new director and designer.  We're going to transform the inside of The Hope Theatre into a cardboard fortress.

 

Why we're doing it

The comedy theatre scene is great but it's almost all devised. We wanted to do something completely different; take traditional light comedy inspired by music hall and English farce and modernise it beyond all recognition. Cream Tea and Incest is more Road Runner than Oscar Wilde. The characters are psychotic imbeciles, incompetent and recklessly violent; bounding through the plot with little regard for anything other than their own greed and ambition. We wanted the show to be slickly executed and as dense with gags as possible. No set changes, no blackouts, no unnecessary pauses.  The show is very silly and it is very fun.

The Hope Theatre

From the 10th of April to the 28th of April we have 15 performances at The Hope Theatre in Islington. The Hope is a lovely place to be, to work and to see shows and we're very happy that they were keen to collaborate with us.

Although The Hope Theatre receives no public subsidy, it was the first Off West End venue to open with a house agreement with Equity, the UK’s largest performers union, to ensure a legal wage for all actors, stage managers and box office staff working at the theatre.

Rehearsal fees, performance fees and holiday pay have to be paid weekly in arrears to all the performers in the show and so we can't simply pay from a box office split. This is great for the actors, it means that they don't have to rely exclusively on the marketing team for them to be able to get paid for doing their job. Benjamin Alborough, who also wrote it, will be waiving his fee to help guarantee the wages of the other actors. That is, unless we hit £4000...

Where the money goes:

We have a fully costed budget and have devised our rehearsal schedule around our actors so it's the most cost efficient it can be. The financial breakdown of our £3000 target is as follows:

£2200 - Actor fees (£1200 rehearsal, £1000 performance)
£200 - Set
£200 - Print (flyers, posters, programmes)
£150 - Costume rental
£250 - Online marketing

£3000 is a HUGE amount for a small scale production company, but with your help, we can reach this target (and reward you for your support). 

Please be as generous as you can!

 

Other ways you can help

Please spread the word by sharing this campaign with your friends and family - it will help us so much. We are very grateful for every contribution received and even the tiniest amount will help us so much.

If you donate, it would be really great if you posted about the campaign to your facebook, twitter, instagram so we can make as many people aware of it as possible!
story_txt: “Remember what it says in the bible: aim for the stomach and he’ll bleed heavily but won’t die straight away.”Cream Tea and Incest What a title! But what's it about?Romance! Adventure! Murder! Aristocrat Eddie Spangler and valet Jeffrey must learn the meaning of these words and more in this new knockabout Edwardian comedy. Delight in their capers, mix-ups, and the dead bodies left in their wake. Join Eddie Spangler, an incompetent but optimistic Englishman and his loyal valet, Jeffrey, on a simple matchmaking quest that quickly deteriorates into a race against time when the Machiavellian forces of the aristocracy move to wreak their vengeance. Lord Wiggins is set to inherit Rhodesia upon his marriage to Emily Rhodes, but their romance is faltering. It is up to Eddie and Jeffrey to sort Wiggins out as quickly and violently as possible. Meanwhile – the evil Lord Biggins lurks in the shadows, waiting to execute dark schemes of his own…http://www.thehopetheatre.com/productions/cream...From a sell-out run at the 2017 Edinburgh Festival Fringe comes the world’s first 2.5 dimensional show set in a world where every prop and set piece is made out of cardboard.★★★★ Broadway Baby                      "Highly Recommended Show" FringeReview Our StoryA four hander, written and performed by Benjamin Alborough with Eoin McAndrew, Edward Spence and Aidan Cheng, Cream Tea and Incest has been in development and preview since September 2016 with a rotating cast and creative team. This has done wonders for the show and we're very grateful that so many people have lent their time and talents to it.We've had the great fortune of performing the play before; for two nights at the 2017 Leicester Comedy Festival, three nights at The Bread & Roses Theatre in April 2017 and a week-long run at Surgeon's Hall at the 2018 Edinburgh Fringe. That is, unless we hit £4000...Where the money goes:We have a fully costed budget and have devised our rehearsal schedule around our actors so it's the most cost efficient it can be. story:
How it all started...sigh...

In 2010, Marie-Pier, myself and some other lucky ladies from The School of Dance were somehow blessed by the dance gods to have a creation process with Susie Burpee and Dan Wild. So fun! And during this process, Marie-Pier and I got the chance to create a duet together! Weren't we lucky! We'd never created together before and we realized that we were meant to be. Haha. ;)

So! Five years later, Marie-Pier came to me and was like "Yo girl! Let's apply for this grant, we will commission Dan Wildand be super awesome and pick up where we left off with our duet and make it new and more mature and cool and we will be epic!" and I was like "Right on!"

So we applied for our Ontario Arts Council grant to commission Dan Wild to make this new and more mature and epic and extra cool piece for us. And when we were putting the grant together we were thinking "They're going to appreciate it so much more if we say we're gunna do some fundraising!" (It's true, likelihood of receiving a grant is 28.736% higher if you say you will fundraise part of the money.... Umm, kidding, but kind of not.)

Anyways, so they did like it! They gave us the grant!! When I told MP I thought she had passed out from excitement. So, we're so really excited and scheduled to start creation in January, 2016.

BUT

It's not much, but we need it...

Soooo, our grant to pay two weeks of in studio creation for Marie-Pier, myself and Toronto-based choreographer Dan Wild amounts to $4860, BUT we need $5360 to cover all the costs of the creation.

Which means we need to fundraise $500 to cover our expenses, as we promised the Ontario Arts Council we would do!

Which is where you generous souls come in!

FYI: We may seem like we already have a decent chunk of cash, but this money has to cover quite a bit:

1. The salaries of three professional artists for two weeks of intensive creation

2. Round trip travel costs for both Marie-Pier and Dan from Montreal and Toronto, respectively.

3. Accommodation for Marie-Pier and Dan for two weeks.

It adds up quickly!

Just remember...

More than ever, artists are encouraged to do this...

It's not easy to ask your friends and family to donate to your projects. I know Marie-Pier and I have both struggled with guilt for asking our family and friends for money. Unfortunately, there's not a lot of cash for the arts. Artists from all over Ontario  fight tooth and nail to get a grant like this from the OAC! The $500 we're fundraising may not seem like a lot, but I assure you it helps enormously.

Artists, you know... we live to give! We're making this stuff to strike a cord with you. To tap into humanity and share what we might find with you! And to create a discussion with, well, you! 

A wise woman once told me that art is a service to society and that an artist's work is a charitable donation to creating a better world. 

Sounds amazing, right!

The point is we really want to do this project and this money is integral to its success. 

We are only accepting donations of $5, $10, and $15. So don't try to donate more... (I'm talking to you Mom and Dad)

story:
DanceAction at FIDCDMX

Welcome to DanceAction. We are a contemporary dance group directed by choreographer Carmen Caceres. We combine the talent of several collaborators in dance, music, drama, and visual arts. All these artists come from diverse backgrounds and have their individual artistic aesthetic, but work together as a team in this creative platform to produce performance art works. Through an interdisciplinary approach that includes dance, music, drama, and visual images, we like to develop works that reflect social issues, people, and relationships.

We were invited to present our most recent work, Game Night, at the First International Contemporary Dance Festival of Mexico City (Primer Festival Internacional de Danza Contemporánea de la Ciudad de México – FIDCDMX). The Festival takes place from July 29 to August 14, 2016 in Mexico City. Over the course of two weeks, the FIDCDMX will showcase over 30 dance companies from all over the world, to present their art to the vibrant community of Mexico City. 

We are an emerging dance group with a great desire to continue growing and expanding, making work, sharing it, and inspiring others through the process. This is a unique opportunity for us, and with your help we can make it happen!

The Festival will generously provide meals and accommodation in Mexico City for the six members of our company. With your support we will be able to cover the airfare expenses to travel to Mexico from New York City and present our piece for two consecutive nights at Un Teatro in Mexico City.

What is the FIDCDMX?

The First International Contemporary Dance Festival of Mexico City FIDCDMX emerges as a project that seeks to frame national and international contemporary dance, aiming to promote international collaboration with a variety of remarkable dance proposals. There is no festival of this kind in Mexico City that, not only provides a forum to national companies, but also invites works of other countries and contexts to coexist.

The festival aims to make a program introducing choreographers and companies with innovative artistic projects, of solid contents, and committed to the rigorous work of the body. It also seeks to include young artists and experienced artists, as well as companies of small and large scale, being a priority for their selection, the strength of the works regardless of the trajectory of the creators.

Game Night is an interactive dance performance that explores people’s behavior in relation to the elements of chance and choice, and how these elements shape human relationships. Two people meet and connect; the crossing of their individual needs determines what kind of relationship they will cultivate. Chance is responsible for putting pieces together, creating a unique configuration of love (or non-love) for each relationship. Watch Game Night’s teaser here!

How Can You Help Us?

Your contributions will help us raise $3,000 to cover the airfare expenses to travel from New York City to Mexico City in August this year. We are a group of 4 dancers and 2 singers participating in this great production of Game Night. Each one of the flights costs $500. Your generous support will take us to Mexico to share our work with the international dance scene.

Even the smallest contribution is incredibly valuable for us, and we would like to thank you for any donation you can possibly make to DanceAction. Helping us will bring you a lot of joy in many different ways, check out these amazing PERKS:

For any contribution of $10 or more we will be sending you a personal thank you note to your home address.

With a donation of $50 or more you will receive our warm thank you note and a letter size professional picture of DanceAction dedicated to you!

Donating $75 to $150 you will receive one of our merchandise items (tote bag or t-shirt) and a personal invitation to attend one of our private rehearsals.

With a contribution from $151 to $300 we will offer you all the perks above, and invite you and 3 friends of yours to a private composition class in New York where we will lead you through our creative process.

With your donation of $300 or more you will become a long-time friend of DanceAction, with free tickets to all our upcoming shows in New York City, guest access to our private rehearsals giving you the opportunity to witness our creative process, a DVD copy of DanceAction’s latest work Game Night, a DanceAction Photo Book, and 1 merchandise items (tote bag or T-shirt).

Every single contribution is important for us and it will help us to get closer to our goal of traveling to Mexico City for this great opportunity.

What are our risks?

We are a very small company and unfortunately at the moment we do not receive any funding or grants to financially cover the costs of our productions, neither to afford a project of this scale. However, we dream big and we work hard to find our ways to overcome the challenges allowing us to create art and present it. Our ultimate goal is to convey a message through our work that will generate social awareness and hopefully will create changes. Led by the urgency of our purpose we decided to take the risk and move forward with this project, even knowing that we will be traveling to a foreign land! We believe that it is crucial to spread our message, inviting audiences from all over the world to have a unique experience witnessing our work. Perhaps our words will resonate somewhere else and make a difference.

Other Ways You Can Help

As we mentioned, your support is very important for us and we truly appreciate any form of help. Spreading the word about this campaign will be a huge help for us. We strongly believe that if all of us contribute even with one single grain of sand to a project, it will make it possible.

Thank you so much!

story:
MARGIN OF ERROR

(or, the Unassailable Wisdom of the Mouse and the Scorpion)

by Eric Coble

Hello. My name is Matthew Cameron Clark. I have been putting plays on stage in Boise for twenty years and there are a couple of things that have remained consistent throughout those years: I do my very best to gather the smartest, most talented, big-hearted people I can to work together on each play, and . . . 

. . . I can't do it without the support of this remarkable community.

Will you help me and BCT to bring the world premiere of this new play to the stage? MARGIN OF ERROR (or, the Unassailable Wisdom of the Mouse and the Scorpion) by Eric Coble will star Richard Klautsch and Veronica Von Tobel. I am directing and we begin rehearsals on March 22. Like every other professional non-profit theater production in this country, it wouldn't be possible without contributions from generous people like you.

Together we have built BCT . . .

. . . into a company with a national reputation for open collaboration, big ideas, and telling great stories. We have another story to tell now. It's smart and surprising. It's very funny. It will ask all of us to think about a few things in a new way. And it is as timely as anything we've ever done here.

This is the story of Harold Carver, the greatest political strategist the nation has ever known. But he’s running four floundering campaigns, his personal life and professional life face cataclysm and he has no one to help him but his wide-eyed intern, Daphne, all while stranded at Gate B16 in the Boise airport. It's a no-holds-barred look at how we choose our elected officials (and every other product) in our winner-takes-all world.

The playwright, Eric Coble, is also the author of THE VELOCITY OF AUTUMN, which had its world premiere at BCT in 2011 and went on to Broadway, starring Academy Award winner Estelle Parsons. His play GRAPHIC DEPICTIONS also premiered here at BCT and has gone on to a number of other productions across the country. For this play, MARGIN OF ERROR, Eric is the inaugural recipient of the BCT River Prize. We are mustering all the help we can to make this production a great one.  

What we need & what you get

We are hoping to raise $15,000 over the next three weeks to help pay for this production. That number is less than 25% of what we will actually need to spend to bring this play to life. Ticket sales and other contributions that have already been made to BCT will cover the rest. So, we need your support to make this possible and we have put together some very cool perks to make it even more worth your while. If you can't donate, please share this on Facebook and help us to spread the word. 

More about the BCT River Prize

The BCT River Prize was established by a generous leadership gift from Susan May and Andy Owczarek. It is an annual fellowship awarded to support a playwright in developing a new idea through the writing and workshop process into a full premiere production. Every play travels a unique course, beginning from the idea at its source. The River Prize provides the resources and openness to see where that course will take us.
