story:
America's bloody love affair with guns is no laughing matter. Sometimes you have to laugh (and sing) to keep from crying.


*UPDATE: Many thanks for all the generous support! We are gearing up for the action packed premiere on Saturday August 13th (with multiple performances to follow), get your advanced tickets here now! *

After an initial work-in-progress performance last summer, and a number of readings and rewrites since, our new play is back and better than ever! MACHINE GUN AMERICA debuts at the New York International Fringe Festival (the largest multi-arts festival in North America) this August.

Star crossed lovers tangle with well-armed toddlers, Open Carry activists, a powerful gun rights leader modeled after NRA honcho Wayne LaPierre, and a dangerously depressed gun safety mascot named Eddie Eagle, in this musical farce inspired by real news stories -- and a real machine gun-loving amusement park for the kids just up the road from Disney World.

SPRINGTIME FOR HITLER meets URINETOWN meets CHARLIE VICTOR ROMEO meets the tabloids -- this new gonzo dark comedy musical, with original songs, blends fact with fiction by interspersing the narrative with updates from recent dramatic headlines. This interplay between the satirical world inhabited by our characters, and reminders that this world all but exists in the US, makes for a jaw dropping theatrical landscape.

Don't just believe us though, here are a few early reviews:

"It's hard to beat the the NRA for sheer melodrama and lunacy, but this laugh out loud play manages to construct a world that is both utterly insane, and only slightly more over the top than what we've come to accept as the norm in the US -- where gun lobby profit, power and paranoia trumps human lives."  

- Andy Bichlbaum, co-founder of The Yes Men


"By it's end, MACHINE GUN AMERICA reaches that place that every good satire drives toward. It's utterly loony and absurd and gasp-worthy, while at the same time completely logical in the world we live in."

- Bill Roberts, screenwriter

"This is a brilliant satire on America's devastating gun culture that is, like all great satire, perilously close to the truth. In fact it would not be beyond the craven tactics of the NRA to advocate arming toddlers since the gun industry, the true client of the NRA, is brazenly marketing its lethal products to children."

- Leah Gunn Barrett, Executive Director of New Yorkers Against Gun Violence

We need your support to give our Fringe Festival production all the bells and whistles it deserves!

Theater is labor intensive, logistically complicated, and rarely profitable. It's also a huge team effort and when it sings, it really sings. We think this play sings, and is telling the right story at the right time. We need all the help we can get to produce, perform and market the multi-day run at the Fringe Fest this August, and use that momentum going forward.

The $2,000 goal (which we hope to augment with grant money, in kind rehearsal space, and naturally, credit card debt) will go toward the following:

  • Compensation/Stipends for cast, director, and a composer working on original music for the show
  • Video production and editing for multimedia elements of the production
  • Props and costumes for the show (apparently it won't be easy to secure an Eddie Eagle costume)
  • Marketing materials, flyers and other creative guerilla PR and marketing stunts and tactics

If we surpass our goal, any and all additional funds will go toward further marketing and promo,  increased compensation for actors, and longer term development of the work.

Others ways you can help!


There are plenty of ways you can help us get this project off the ground! Here are just a few off the top of our heads:

  • Help us spread the word -- share the campaign with your friends and colleagues, post this page on your Facebook and Twitter feeds, you know the drill.
  • Put us in touch with any journalists, bloggers, theater-makers, activists or funders you think would be interested in helping us build broader exposure and impact for this work.
  • Attend one of the August Fringe Festival performances! The show premieres on Saturday August 13 and will run a minimum of five times between August 13-26. Get your tickets now!

Impact: Beyond the Stage


The national debate around guns often runs along predictably hyper partisan lines. By creating space to explore this story through theater in an intentionally provocative and disarming way, we endeavor to smash through that echo chamber. MACHINE GUN AMERICA provides an opportunity to impact both theater loving New Yorkers and later, the national conversation -- as the play continues to develop and is shared with new audiences across the country.

That conversation is as vital and important as ever. The worst mass shootings in modern American history just took the lives of 49 women and men in Orlando. The GOP majority in the Senate responded a week later by voting down a number of modest measures, like universal background checks, that could make it harder for terrorists, criminals, or serial abusers to access weapons of war. And the NRA responded to the massacre with the familiar talking points: more guns, everywhere. They also just closed out their latest annual convention calling for more guns in American schools, and by recommending that parents store guns in their children's bedrooms.

And this overheated election cycle is about to get even more over the top, with some gun rights leaders already calling on supporters to resort to "the bullet box" if they're not happy with November's ballot box results.

The play has been in development since 2015, launching with an initial works in progress performance at Dixon Place, an award-winning performing arts venue in lower Manhattan. At that performance we organized a talk back after the show with the Executive Director of New Yorkers Against Gun Violence, and we're excited to partner with NYAGV again to do a similar series of talk backs during our Fringe run this August, and beyond. We're also in discussions to perform the piece at a national meeting of gun control advocates in Washington DC later this year.

Who Are We? Thanks for Asking!


Playwright Joseph Huff-Hannon is an award-winning writer published in The New York Times, The Guardian, Rolling Stone, Salon, Huffington Post and elsewhere, a campaigner and activist with experience in guerilla theater, and a longtime collaborator with satirical culture jamming group the Yes Men. On the eve of the Sochi Winter OIympics and the passage of Russia's high profile anti-gay law, Joseph co-edited a book of "illegal" real life LGBT love stories, with celebrated Russian journalist Masha Gessen. He also once tried to warn sun seekers on Fire Island about impending sea level rise and climate change, to little avail.

Producing partner Frack Theatre is a New York based theater company that utilizes theater as a means of community empowerment. Using techniques of verbatim and documentary theater, Frack uses storytelling as a means of investigation. Frack Theatre digs deep, puts pressure on the dominant discourse and exposes its cracks and fault lines. Underneath the thick crust of a homogenized society lie the deep, profound and moving stories that so often remain untold. Some of Frack's off-Broadway productions have tackled LGBT rights and perceptions of history, the nascent #BlackLivesMatter movement, and more recently, gun culture in the United States. Frack Theatre is Samuel Clark, Oscar Lopez, and Lindsay Morris.
story_txt:
America's bloody love affair with guns is no laughing matter. Sometimes you have to laugh (and sing) to keep from crying. *UPDATE: Many thanks for all the generous support! We are gearing up for the action packed premiere on Saturday August 13th (with multiple performances to follow), get your advanced tickets here now! *After an initial work-in-progress performance last summer, and a number of readings and rewrites since, our new play is back and better than ever! MACHINE GUN AMERICA debuts at the  New York International Fringe Festival (the largest multi-arts festival in North America) this August.Star crossed lovers tangle with well-armed toddlers, Open Carry activists, a powerful gun rights leader modeled after NRA honcho Wayne LaPierre, and a dangerously depressed gun safety mascot named Eddie Eagle, in this musical farce inspired by real news stories -- and a real machine gun-loving amusement park for the kids just up the road from Disney World.SPRINGTIME FOR HITLER meets URINETOWN meets CHARLIE VICTOR ROMEO meets the tabloids -- this new gonzo dark comedy musical, with original songs, blends fact with fiction by interspersing the narrative with updates from recent dramatic headlines. This interplay between the satirical world inhabited by our characters, and reminders that this world all but exists in the US, makes for a jaw dropping theatrical landscape. Don't just believe us though, here are a few early reviews:"It's hard to beat the the NRA for sheer melodrama and lunacy, but this laugh out loud play manages to construct a world that is both utterly insane, and only slightly more over the top than what we've come to accept as the norm in the US -- where gun lobby profit, power and paranoia trumps human lives."  - Andy Bichlbaum, co-founder of The Yes Men"By it's end, MACHINE GUN AMERICA reaches that place that every good satire drives toward. It's utterly loony and absurd and gasp-worthy, while at the same time completely logical in the world we live in." - Bill Roberts, screenwriter"This is a brilliant satire on America's devastating gun culture that is, like all great satire, perilously close to the truth. story:
S T O R Y 


In 2016 Stephanie Zaletel, Louis Lopez, and Amabelle Aguiluz were invited to create a brand new work, WATER STORIES, as Artists in Residence at the MorYork Gallery in Los Angeles. The piece integrated contemporary dance, massive textile sculptures and wearable art, field recordings, and 60 minutes of new music.

After 8 sold-out performances, rave reviews (SeeDance, DancePlug, Venison Magazine), and an invitation to be presented at the ACE Hotel Rooftop Pool / The Bootleg Theater in LAX Festival, as well as Current LA Water: Public Art Biennial this dynamic team has been invited to present a brand new work, Marshmallow Sea, at Velocity Dance Center in Seattle, WA alongside local Seattle artist, Anna Conner, in March 2017.

We are thrilled for this opportunity to create another water-centric work in such a vibrant, creative, water-centric city! 

In 2017 we are also touring this site-sensitive work to Santa Fe, NM as part of Place Project's 2017 programming, and we are applying to festivals in Arizona, Portland, New York, Chicago, and Massachusetts with our acclaimed dance-theater work, FLWRS -- not to mention plenty of LA-based programming and creative workshops while we are home!

Your donations will directly fund the brand new creation, national premier, and tour of Marshmallow Sea as well as the touring revival of FLWRS!

F E A T U R I N G

Choreography by Stephanie Zaletel
Wearable Art by Amabelle Aguiluz
Marshmallow Sea Music by Jonathan Snipes
F L W R S Music by Louis Lopez
Large Scale Fabric Pieces by Clare Graham

Lighting Design by Pablo Santiago-Brandwein
Dance Performance by szalt (dance co.) - Lindsey Lollie, Sarah Prinz, Amir Rappaport, Jordan Saenz, Julia Planine-Troiani, Stephanie Zaletel

FUNDING COVERS

  • Director, Administrator, Dancer, and Collaborator Compensation (for 8 working months)*
  • Rehearsal and Performance Rental Fees
  • Production Expenses (costumes, flowers, props)
  • Travel Expenses in Seattle and New Mexico (including housing, fuel, and per diem)**
  • Application Fees for National Dance Festivals

*2017 Season = January - June | August - November

**One very generous donor has offered to cover szalt's flights to Seattle.

All funds raised go towards production costs and artist compensation while in creation and on tour. The more we raise, the more work we can produce in 2017! Thank you for keeping us working to bring high-quality, socially relevant live art to LA and cities across the US. 

T E S T I M O N I A L S  &  P R E S S

"every moment holds all the magnitude of life and no moment or movement is wasted" -Julia Nowak on FLWRS at LAX Festival for Riting LA

 

"charged, tense, and tender... outstanding and totally engaging" -Jeff Slayton on FLWRS at HNYPT LA  & O E at Highways for SeeDance

 

"high concept work where all the elements glow with unified effect" - Steven Woodruff on Water Stories premier at MorYork Gallery for Dance Plug

 

"After performing in szalt 's FLWRS, talking to (audiences) after the show, and reading reviews I can see more than ever that this kind of art-making is service. And it matters. Because all the individuals that it affects matter. If everyone is doing what they can within their skill set to bring people together emotionally, physically, spiritually, politically - we are headed in a good direction." -Sarah Prinz, szalt company member

 

"FLWRS by szalt was like an I.V. to my soul, and I didn’t even know I was thirsty. With no knowledge of the show before hand, I found myself gutted by the performers and sideswiped by their stunning virtuosity. Days later, I feel giddy having experienced such fruitional mastery. With no words, five women create such an irrepressible vocabulary of space and body." -Sarah McCarron, audience member at LAX Festival

 

szalt is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a nonprofit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of szalt will be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
The Residency:

Hello and welcome to our very first crowdfunder! For those who don’t know us so well, we are Gavin Robertson and Nicholas Collett and we've been making and touring devised theatre both in the UK and internationally for over twenty years.

We are about to embark on a very exciting and specific Research and Development period.

Through performing each of our shows in Kansas City we were very fortunate to have been invited to apply for a creative residency in Seaside, Florida, USA, by an organisation called 'Escape 2 Create'. Having applied we've been accepted, which is a privilege in itself, and therefore in January 2016 we'll be there developing each of our new solo shows. Those that are familiar with us and/or our work know that since 2012  we've created four solo shows (two each) and collaborated on all of them together. This has given us a distinct style of work and we're now looking at working on the two new solo productions.

We'll be in Seaside for four weeks. We are being provided with accommodation. As part of the scheme we also have a contribution  towards travel. However, we do still need your help! We need two international return flights, plus two internal return flights inside the USA, and even the transfer costs to/from the airport comes to a total of  $200.

So, our research tells us that we need a total - for travel ONLY - of £2000.

So once we're there- what then? Well, alongside developing TWO shows we are, as part of this opportunity, conducting workshops and delivering a performance to local schools.

 As part of the style of the work, there is always movement (usually to musical underscore) in place of text. We would like to record this in order to complete the shows on our return to the UK. We don't expect to necessarily return with two fully-fledged productions BUT- BOTH productions will need a promotional trailer in order to help secure bookings. We would like to also ask you therefore for a further £1000 which will enable us to physically shoot this material and edit the results into professional reels in a professional studio. In fact, that amount won't cover the full costs, but it will significantly help! We expect to spend a good portion of our time, in Florida, using the camera (both stills and video) to capture developing work in progress.

We hope you can help us get to our target, especially including the last part. Getting there is only a beginning!

Every penny is appreciated - so whatever you can spare, even if it is just the time to share the link, we will be genuinely grateful. 

The SHOWS:

"Your Bard" - Nicholas Collett

William Shakespeare  - the greatest playwright the world has ever seen? Or just a front man? A player – or a poet?

Now’s your chance to meet Will in person. In the pub. An informal audience with the man himself. Nicholas Collett takes the lid off a legend in your local – Will’s childhood, adventures at the Globe and what’s it like on tour. And whether he wrote all those plays…

He might play a few of the greatest hits, teach you to dance the Volta, or write a sonnet.

Ladies and gentlemen, raise your glasses –

Your Bard!


"An Iron Bar Is Mostly Empty Space" - Gavin Robertson

In its way this is a natural follow-up to the first solo show, ‘Crusoe’, as it looks at the way in which Humans need and want to connect – increasingly so in a world where virtual living is popular and possible and real interaction reduced. It also looks at patterns in nature and draws a link between the two seemingly unconnected subjects.

"AN IRON BAR IS MOSTLY EMPTY SPACE" is actually a quote from David P. Barash a Professor of Psychology at the University of Washington, USA, and in essence refers to the human condition which is ever-changing. He goes on - "Even inanimate objects that appear solid and persistent are revealed by modern physics to be in a constant state of flux".

Gavin is already doing lots of reading of some quite technical books, as well as watching documentaries and jotting down random quotes and ideas...


We really do hope you feel you can contribute. Obviously our first aim is actually being able to get there so any funding will be prioritised towards the travel costs. This is a unique opportunity for us to spend a month as artists away from the usual pressures of daily life in the UK.


Thank you.

story:
A Letter From the Playwright  

Dear Donors,

I am a Brooklyn based interdisciplinary theatre maker, teaching artist and the daughter of an American Foreign Service officer. I grew up internationally, moving every three years, always observing the United States from the outside looking in. My curiosity as an artist lies in a desire to better understand people and places that confound me—especially those of the country I represent. My one-woman show, Shenandoah, is the embodiment of this desire.

Shenandoah is a young woman trapped by circumstance in the infinite planes of Middle America. Though she dreams of the wider world, comfort and complacency keep her homebound. That is, until the death of her father sets her free. Will she muster up the courage to leave?

My company, Grasshopper Chorus, and I have been invited to bring Shenandoah to this year’s Prague Fringe Festival; the largest English-language theatre festival in continental Europe.

With your support, we hope to seize this opportunity to engage an international audience in our examination of Middle American identity. Shenandoah is a story of mourning and isolation, of delight and self-liberation. It’ll make you laugh and make you cringe, and make you wonder what it means to be American.

Thank you kindly,

Nancy Monahan

 

What We Need

$1,500 PER COMPANY MEMBER

Includes: airfare, lodging, travel insurance, a food stipend, and ground transportation

$1,000 FOR PROJECT DEVELOPMENT

Includes: the festival participation fee, rehearsal and performance space in NYC, publicity, shipping costs for our set

 

What Your Donations Will Provide

$10 - One hour of rehearsal space in New York

$25 - Food for one company member for a day in Prague

$50 - Cost of shipping our set to Prague OR public transportation for one company member for the entire trip

$100 - Our posters for the festival OR our flyers for the festival OR travel insurance for one company member

$500 - Our performance in New York OR one month of rehearsal space in New York OR ground transportation for the whole company

$1,000 - Our lodging for the entire trip OR daily food stipends for the whole company OR our publicity costs in their entirety

$3,000 – Round trip flights to Prague for the whole company

 

Other Ways You Can Help

As a group of young artists facing the daily grind of New York City we understand that not everyone can afford to donate money. But there are still plenty of ways to help us out! Here are few ideas:

Share this Indiegogo: Ain’t nothin’ like good, old fashioned word of mouth! 

Like and Share Our Facebook Page: and we will like you forever! www.facebook.com/shenandoahtheshow

Visit and Share Our Website: Read more about the company, see photos of past productions, listen to demos of the music. Share it with friends, loved ones, heck even your enemies! www.shenandoahtheshow.com

Let us Borrow Your Private Jet: Just kidding…or are we?

Come See Us Perform: 

Late March—we will be hosting a Concert Fundraiser and EP Release Party in Brooklyn! Come experience the original music of Shenandoah, live with the four-man band featured on the EP.

Late April—we will be putting on a full production, the same one that Fringy Pragues (Pringy Frogs?) will see at the Festival. This will be an opportunity for our local donors to see the show before we take it overseas. We also want to hear your questions and feedback! Check our website and facebook page for updates.

My company, Grasshopper Chorus, and I have been invited to bring Shenandoah to this year’s Prague Fringe Festival; the largest English-language theatre festival in continental Europe.
With your support, we hope to seize this opportunity to engage an international audience in our examination of Middle American identity. Shenandoah is a story of mourning and isolation, of delight and self-liberation. It’ll make you laugh and make you cringe, and make you wonder what it means to be American.
Thank you kindly,
Nancy Monahan
 
What We Need 
$1,500 PER COMPANY MEMBER
Includes: airfare, lodging, travel insurance, a food stipend, and ground transportation
$1,000 FOR PROJECT DEVELOPMENT
Includes: the festival participation fee, rehearsal and performance space in NYC, publicity, shipping costs for our set
 
What Your Donations Will Provide
$10 - One hour of rehearsal space in New York
$25 - Food for one company member for a day in Prague
$50 - Cost of shipping our set to Prague OR public transportation for one company member for the entire trip
$100 - Our posters for the festival OR our flyers for the festival OR travel insurance for one company member
$500 - Our performance in New York OR one month of rehearsal space in New York OR ground transportation for the whole company
$1,000 - Our lodging for the entire trip OR daily food stipends for the whole company OR our publicity costs in their entirety
$3,000 – Round trip flights to Prague for the whole company
 
Other Ways You Can Help
As a group of young artists facing the daily grind of New York City we understand that not everyone can afford to donate money. But there are still plenty of ways to help us out! Here are few ideas:
Share this Indiegogo: Ain’t nothin’ like good, old fashioned word of mouth! 
Like and Share Our Facebook Page: and we will like you forever! www.facebook.com/shenandoahtheshow
Visit and Share Our Website: Read more about the company, see photos of past productions, listen to demos of the music. Share it with friends, loved ones, heck even your enemies! www.shenandoahtheshow.com
Let us Borrow Your Private Jet: Just kidding…or are we?
Come See Us Perform: 
Late March—we will be hosting a Concert Fundraiser and EP Release Party in Brooklyn! Come experience the original music of Shenandoah, live with the four-man band featured on the EP.
Late April—we will be putting on a full production, the same one that Fringy Pragues (Pringy Frogs?) will see at the Festival. This will be an opportunity for our local donors to see the show before we take it overseas. We also want to hear your questions and feedback! Check our website and facebook page for updates.

story:
Birth of a Festival...

Every year the Cleveland Branch of the English Speaking Union with the cooperation of Great Lakes Theater Education Depart hosts the Annual Shakespeare Monologue competition. Students in grades 9-12 from schools across Northeast Ohio compete for the opportunity to represent Cleveland in the National Shakespeare Competition. The ESU Monologue Competition offers students the chance to dive deeper in the work of the prolific playwright. Students are usually coached for months on their specific monologue and then given a few precious seconds to show the judges what they have.


And then it's over....

For many students, the experience ends at their school competition—since only one student from each school can advance.And only one can represent Cleveland in the National Competition.

We thought: “Why should the competition be the end of it?”

The best part about winning a spot at the competition is the opportunity to meet students from other schools, see scenes performed by professional actors and put together scenes from Shakespeare’s canon with the help of Great Lakes Theater teaching artists.

And in 2017, The Cleveland Branch of the English Speaking Union produced the first All-City Shakespeare Festival with cooperation from Great Lakes Theater.

Students from Westlake to Willoughby worked tirelessly to create a site specific, roaming production of A Midsummer Night’s Dream at the Cleveland Botanical Gardens. The students ranged from freshman in high school to college sophomores, each bringing their own experiences and skill levels to the rehearsal room. For some of our students, this was their first time tackling full length Shakespeare play. For some it was one of their first plays.

We are currently tackling Romeo and Juliet! Our performance is just a few weeks away and we still need your help in supporting this talented, multigenerational group of performers.

Every dollar earned in this campaign... 

  • Brings our students' family members to the performance. This one night only performance is primarily a fundraiser and every dollar raised goes toward covering the cost of our cast's VIPs. 
  • Provides master classes with Shakespeare professonials in the Cleveland theater community
  • Assists with the cost of Green Room and Dressing necessities including dinner for each cast member.
  • Supplies additional make-up and costumes for our youth actors.
  • Gives students from across the Northeast Ohio area the ability to work collaboratively with professional artists and other students on a one-night only performance of Romeo and Juliet.

For Tickets to this All-City Shakespeare 2018: Romeo and Juliet Click Here!

 

Thank you for your Support! See you June 29th!

story:
Purchase Tickets

We are so grateful to the 114 people who backed our Indiegogo fundraiser! If you're looking to buy tickets for the show, you can do so here.

Hello! We're Unfiction Works.

We're an artistic collective that produces narrative-driven circus. We are passionate about telling the stories we often keep hidden. Our first full-length show, Baggage Claim, has been in development since May 2018. We're so excited to share it with you, and we're launching this campaign to sell tickets and raise funds!

Where will the money go?

Circus is not cheap! Our overall budget for the show is $9,000, and our goal is to raise at least $5,000 of that through this campaign. Your support will help us pay for the theater rental (payment is due two weeks before opening night!), insurance, circus equipment, props and set design, and stipends for the performers, director, stage manager, choreographer, and lighting and sound tech. We are passionate about paying all of the artists and production staff involved in the show. It's almost impossible to make a living as a performing artist and we are aiming, in our own small way, to help change that.

Perks!

If your favorite part of a plane flight is the swag (looking at you, Biscoff cookies and weird earbuds), then you've come to the right place. In addition to general admission and VIP tickets, we're also offering some pretty cool perks for backers of our campaign:

  • If you're not local to Seattle, grab the Friends from Afar perk to see an exclusive recording of the whole show
  • Take an aerial private lesson with fabulous coaches Sandy or Danya
  • Let Andrew help you assess online dating matches or give your profile a makeover--trust us, he's a professional

In fact, bring a Tinder date to the show and you'll get a free drink at intermission.

Pay-what-you-can

It's important to us that circus is accessible. A portion of tickets for each show will be pay-what-you-can. Email us to get on the list to reserve those!

Other ways to support us

  • Share this Indiegogo campaign with your family and friends!
  • Like our facebook page and share our website
  • Volunteer to run the door and see the show for free! (Email us)
  • Bake treats for us to sell during intermission in exchange for tickets (Email us)
  • Bring us tasty green room snacks during show week (Email us)

The Company

ALICIA RADFORD - Producer, artist

Alicia Radford is a jill-of-all-trades who has spent the last decade developing a diverse skill set: she is a graphic designer, accountant, seamstress, nonprofit operations professional, and performer. She discovered circus arts in 2014 and immediately fell in love, training at Versatile Arts and then in Portland as part of The Circus Project’s 2017-2018 training and performance company. Her first love is rope, but her current obsession is handbalancing. Alicia is passionate about using circus to tell stories, and creating full-length performance opportunities for artists.

ANDREW FLEWELLING - Artist

Andrew, a bartender turned circus performer, has been training in various circus arts for about four years. He has dabbled in many proficiencies from aerial (refining skills mostly on aerial fabric), to partner acrobatics, to hand balancing – he’ll even attempt to juggle, but let’s just say that’s a work in progress. Andrew is fascinated by both the fitness and performance aspects of circus. Andrew’s current focus is integrating partner acrobatics into dynamic storylines. Outside of circus, Andrew is working on nursing school applications with the hope of becoming a nurse practitioner. When he’s not training, he’s either out at the dog park with his boxer, Athena, searching for new books, working on mixed media art projects, or baking things that are part of no one’s diet.

DANYA VOLKOV - Artist

Danya discovered a love for movement arts after watching the 1995 PBS recording of Riverdance, to be quite specific. Since then, she has enjoyed dabbling in various forms of dance, movement, and more recently circus arts. Inspired by the combination of athleticism, grace, and seeming magic of aerial arts, she studies at Versatile Arts, with a favoritism toward tissu. Danya's current interests in the air include translating dynamic rope movements to fabric, hanging from one elbow, and spinning like mad! During the day she is absorbed in developing reusable products and sustainable materials. When not busily tying herself in knots, you may find her curled up with her cat listening to audiobooks, getting lost in the great outdoors, or attending metal shows.

JORGE GARZA - Artist

Originally from Mexico, Jorge immigrated to the United States in the summer of 2000, where he pursued a Bachelor's degree in Fine Arts and Media Arts. He discovered the circus world as a hobby in 2008 and fell in love with it. For several years, he tried different circus apparatus such as silks, lyra, Cyr wheel and rope. Rope being his favorite apparatus, he has been training on it for the last five years and finds the simplicity and complexity of the rope its two most attractive qualities. Professionally, Jorge spends a lot of his time working as a 3D designer at a local Industrial Design firm, where he is able to combine his design and creative skills with his passion for aviation. Aside from circus arts, Jorge has a passion for nature, animal conservation, traveling, learning other cultures, languages and ways of life around the world.

KIRSTIE ARNBERG - Co-Producer, artist

Kirstie is a queer, Filipina-American woman from southeastern Washington who is enthusiastic about feelings, flowers and flying through the air. She is a social worker by day and an aerialist at night, striving for vulnerability and connection in both work and play. Kirstie fell in love with aerial arts several years ago after years of gymnastics and rock climbing and now has a soft spot for the lyra. Kirstie enjoys integrating her contemplative, yet cheery personality into her aerial art. When she’s not spinning and flipping around, she can be found reading poetry, vintage shopping or having heart to hearts with her loved ones.

SANDRA KOPRIVA - Artist

Sandra is a former motorcycle mechanic turned circus artist and instructor. Her first experience trying circus aerials was with Beverly Sobelman of Versatile Arts, 12 years ago. She has been learning (and working and learning more), teaching, and performing ever since. She most enjoys working on rope, but thinks she’s done her best work on fabric. She has mainly performed rope, fabric, and doubles trapeze. She works to be strong and emotionally fearless in all parts of her life. When not training, Sandra enjoys studying languages and riding her bicycle.

ALEX GOLDSTEIN - Director

Alex Goldstein started dancing as a young child, but stopped to pursue sports and academics. She took up dance again at the end of grad school and has been high kicking ever since. Alex’s undergraduate and graduate degrees are in chemistry, and she worked in software development for 20 years before leaving that world behind to focus on movement. She has danced professionally for a number of Seattle-area companies, and currently dances with the take3 dance project. Alex trains in ballet, performs modern, but finds the most joy in jazz. She discovered circus arts nine years ago. Her favorite apparatus is the one she is not actively hanging onto, but she specializes in rope and single point trapeze. Alex is also a Soma practitioner with her own practice, Enso Bodywork. She has thoroughly enjoyed spending time at the airport with this wonderful cast.

GARET NENNINGER - Lead Stage Tech

Garet surprised friends and family by joining the circus in 2013 with his first aerial class. By 2014, he performed in his first show and discovered his love of aerial performance art. He has since performed both solo and as part of Duo Gemini, generally exploring aspects of partnership. He tends toward rope and silk, but has also tried unusual apparatus such as frame, and a two-bar dance trapeze. Professionally, Garet applies his creativity at an engineering firm that develops innovative high tech products for medical device, consumer electronics, and other markets. Aside from circus arts, Garet enjoys shudokan karate, vintage motorcycles, sewing aerial costumes, and woodworking.

story:
Ballet Neo, an innovative neo classical ballet company, infuses classical ballet with sophisticated  emotional themes. Kate Thomas,  Artistic Director & Choreographer, has been called "a master story teller" and brings a raw honesty to the company’s repertory  Ballet Neo's Spring 2014 program consisted of divergent slants on drama. Thomas’  Appalachian Suites  the Monongah West Virginia Mining disaster in collaboration with Grammy Award winning composer Mark O'Connor is a touching depiction of hope in the face of tragedy, portraying the struggle of Italian immigration to this country. Thomas'  Measurement & Caution is a deeply sensual exploration of the inherent loneliness of human intimacy. These works stir imaginations & redefine perceptions of the ballet as theater, enticing new audiences to discover the art form. 
Thomas' most recent work has takes a turn towards the lighthearted.  "Fellini's Dream"  conjures a selection of the  fantastic characters created by this gifted film director  throughout his career.  Set to the music of Guy Klupetcek , Fellini's Dream is a delightful collage of music movement and fantasy. 
  
Keep visiting this campaign page for new perks, event updates & artist information. 
Help Ballet Neo get back to work...today.

Right now you have an opportunity to truly contribute to the future of Ballet Neo.

  1. Ballet Neo needs your help to continue to grow during this tenuous time.
  2. Your support will allow us to pay our talented dancers .
  3. Your support will allow us to expand our audiences through New York City performances. 
  4. Your support will allow us to replace old worn costumes.
  5. Your support will allow us to expand our calendar of events . 
  6. Your support will allow us to hire publicity assistance.
  7. Your contribution will provide a proven, meaningful, international platform for our creative team, both on stage & behind the scenes.

Our  2015-16 program expected to attract the largest audience in our history. In addition, Ballet Neo is broadening our international audience via strategic media coverage.The possibilities are endless with your help.

What Is Required

 We're raising funds to pay for: 

  • Venue Fees ($6000)
  • Artist Fees ($7000)
  • New Costumes ($1500
  • Publicity ($2000)

TOTAL: $16,500

Our goal is large, yes, but so is our vision. Be part of the movement and donate to Ballet Neo today. We absolutely need your help to see this project through. With your support, http://balletneocompany.wix.com/balletneo will continue to grow artist ically.  Please make a donation today!

What You Get

  • A very public thank you via social media
  • Your name or company listed on http://balletneocompany.wix.com/balletneo
  • Ballet Neo swag
  • Tickets to exclusive V.I.P. events
  • & More

See the boxes to the right for details!

Give in 4 Easy Steps

  • Choose which perks you want from the menu to the right. 
  • Click the "Contribute Now" button.
  • Make your donation on a fully secure webpage
  • Feel really good about yourself.

NOTE: you can give any amount you wish. The totals listed are the minimum to receive each perk

You're Important & Sharing is Caring

Please share this new fundraising campaign! You can help us recruit support by simply using the sharing tools below.

story:
What is "The Choking Game"?

90 minutes.  Real time.

The Choking Game tells the story of Natalie and Matt, a high school couple from suburban Long Island who use their live amateur internet pornography show, www.thechokinggame.net, as a battleground in their crippling emotional and physical war against one another.  

It's Who's Afraid of Virginia Wolf? for the YouTube generation.  (Or, more appropriately, 50 Shades of Grey by way of the Disney Channel.)


Originally workshopped as part of IRT's 3B Residency in NYC in 2013, The Choking Game brings the voyeurism of our modern technical world into the sweaty intimacy of theater.  "Watching people watch this show is a fascinating experience", says playwright-director Kaitlin Colombo. "We've had full-grown adult men walk out of the theater shaking and sobbing.  At it's core, it's a good old fashion monster movie  - but instead of a ghost or a demon, you just have two angry and terrified teenagers."

Making it's debut as part of their inaugural "F*ckFest" ("a sex-tival, if you will"), The Brick provides the perfect space to tell this devastating and visceral story.  "The entire show will take place in the audience's lap," says Colombo.  "There will be no opportunity to look away or even take a breath as the play flies along at a break-neck speed towards it's devastating and shocking conclusion."

When/Where is The Choking Game?

Friday, June 19th (8:30PM) 
Monday, June 29th (7:00PM) 
Thursday, July 2nd (10:30PM) 
Friday, July 3rd (9:00PM)

The Brick Theater

Where Your Money Goes

We're doing this fast and dirty - it's going to be a minimalistic production so the focus goes completely on the story and the characters.  No bells and whistles - just a boy, a girl, a bed and a laptop.

We've been very lucky so far... People are excited about this show and are being incredibly generous, stepping up to offer us some free rehearsal space, casting services, donations of props/costumes, etc.  AND, as we have the honor of being part of F*ckFest, we don't have to pay to perform in the venue (which, depending on the venue, can typically be upwards of $10,000 per week!).  

It's all coming together - but we still need help as we're missing some vital components.  What components are those?  Here - have a handy diagram...

And that's where you come in!

Every dollar you donate will help us bring this show to life.  And, as The Colombo Company is fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas, much of what you donate is fully tax-deductible! 

(And everyone knows - the horror you feel leaving the theater after The Choking Game pales in comparison to the horror of a tax audit!)

Who's Playing "The Choking Game"?

Kaitlin Colombo is a Los Angeles-based writer, director and stand up comedian who's work has appeared on NBC, MTV and E! Entertainment television. 

At the age of 17, she sold a television pilot based on her stand up comedy to FOX (Hypnotic/Doug Liman, Exec. Prod.).  Her article “Deadly Web: The Rise and Fall of SchoolScandals.com” was published in Geek Monthly Magazine and she is a seasonal blogger for Edge Publications.  

A member of the Actors Studio's Playwright Director Workshop, Kaitlin has directed many works for the NYC stage.  Specifically, her work on the world premier of The Seeing Place's production of "When We Have Gone Astray" was singled out by Talk Entertainment as "extremely truthful and engaging... I found myself truly moved."

Kaitlin served as Program Director for the Alec Baldwin Fellowship at Singers Forum, a program focused on working with new plays.​​

For more information, visit www.kaitlincolombo.com

Winner of the The Caffe Cino Fellowship Award, The Brick is Williamsburg, Brooklyn’s destination for cutting-edge theatrical experience. The Brick and its company, The Brick Theater, Inc, were founded in 2002 by Robert Honeywell and Michael Gardner. Formerly an auto-body shop, a yoga center, and various storage spaces, this brick-walled garage in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, was completely refurbished as a state-of-the-art performance space.

The Brick has been home to many critically acclaimed premieres, including Bouffon Glass Menajoree (NY IT Award Winner—Outstanding Play), In a Strange Room (Time Out New York’s Top Ten Plays), Samuel & Alasdair: A Personal History of the Robot War (NY IT Award Winner—Outstanding Play), Suspicious Package (ITBA Award Winner—Best Unique Theatrical Experience), Craven Monkey and the Mountain of Fury (NY IT Award Nominee—Outstanding Performance Art Production), and Greed: a Musical Love $tory (NY IT Award Nominee—Outstanding Musical), The Brick has hosted some of downtown theater’s most innovative artists, including Annie Baker, Young Jean Lee, The Debate Society, Thomas Bradshaw and Nick Jones.

For more information, visit www.bricktheater.com.

Sara Ball is a recent graduate of the Studio program at the American Musical and Dramatic Academy. She is a part of the improv street team for the new musical The Wild Women of Planet Wongo and is thrilled to be making her New York stage debut with The Choking Game.

Originally from Long Island New York, Cooper Lawrence graduated from University of Arizona with a degree is Sociology and Marketing and back to New York to pursue his career in acting. He has recently graduated with his MFA in Acting from The Actors Studio Drama School at Pace University this past May. He performed his thesis project from the play (K2) as Taylor.  His recent film credits include The Last Days of Stanley Foster (NYU film thesis), IBM National Campaign. He has had the privilege of working on characters from Detroit (ASDS), The Boys Next Door (ASDS), Midsummer Nights Dream (BADA), New works from Stephen Adly Gurgis (Labyrinth Intensive Ensemble) and others. He is very greatful and excited to be apart of this production of The Choking Game and would like to thank his close friends and supportive family, but most importantly his dog Simon for always being there when times get tough. 

MORE BIOS COMING SOON!

"The Choking Game" is Risky!

And not just because you can't shout out the safety word...

Theater is risky.  And scary.  And not just because a stage light can come crashing down on you, Birdman-style, at any given moment.  

                         

*Actual rehearsal footage from The Choking Game.  (No, not really.)


The future of Off-Off Broadway is at risk.  Production expenses continue to soar year after year and, in order to stay alive, theater companies and producers HAVE to reach out to our audiences in order to make ends meet.  You are the most important part of the process as we literally cannot survive without you guys.  

We've assembled an amazing cast and crew who are working tirelessly to tell this story.  But we won't be able to do it without your help.  So please consider donating what you can...
story_txt:
What is "The Choking Game"?




90 minutes.  Real time.

The Choking Game tells the story of Natalie and Matt, a high school couple from suburban Long Island who use their live amateur internet pornography show, www.thechokinggame.net, as a battleground in their crippling emotional and physical war against one another.  It's Who's Afraid of Virginia Wolf? for the YouTube generation.  (Or, more appropriately, 50 Shades of Grey by way of the Disney Channel.)Originally workshopped as part of IRT's 3B Residency in NYC in 2013, The Choking Game brings the voyeurism of our modern technical world into the sweaty intimacy of theater.  "Watching people watch this show is a fascinating experience", says playwright-director Kaitlin Colombo. "We've had full-grown adult men walk out of the theater shaking and sobbing.  At it's core, it's a good old fashion monster movie  - but instead of a ghost or a demon, you just have two angry and terrified teenagers."Making it's debut as part of their inaugural "F*ckFest" ("a sex-tival, if you will"), The Brick provides the perfect space to tell this devastating and visceral story.  "The entire show will take place in the audience's lap," says Colombo.  "There will be no opportunity to look away or even take a breath as the play flies along at a break-neck speed towards it's devastating and shocking conclusion."When/Where is The Choking Game?

Friday, June 19th (8:30PM) Monday, June 29th (7:00PM) Thursday, July 2nd (10:30PM) Friday, July 3rd (9:00PM)
The Brick Theater
Where Your Money Goes


We're doing this fast and dirty - it's going to be a minimalistic production so the focus goes completely on the story and the characters.  No bells and whistles - just a boy, a girl, a bed and a laptop.
We've been very lucky so far... People are excited about this show and are being incredibly generous, stepping up to offer us some free rehearsal space, casting services, donations of props/costumes, etc.  AND, as we have the honor of being part of F*ckFest, we don't have to pay to perform in the venue (which, depending on the venue, can typically be upwards of $10,000 per week!).  

It's all coming together - but we still need help as we're missing some vital components.  What components are those?  Here - have a handy diagram...



And that's where you come in!
Every dollar you donate will help us bring this show to life.  And, as The Colombo Company is fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas, much of what you donate is fully tax-deductible! 
(And everyone knows - the horror you feel leaving the theater after The Choking Game pales in comparison to the horror of a tax audit!)

I found myself truly moved."
Kaitlin served as Program Director for the Alec Baldwin Fellowship at Singers Forum, a program focused on working with new plays.​​

story:
Short Summary

HERstory Counts presents: SILENCED

7 diverse female identified womyn will take the Red Sandcastle stage by storm this December 8th-11th, 2016. Each womyn will be performing a 10 minute monologue, all auto-biographical in nature, about a true story and experience. Come and see the strength, compassion and love these womyn display on stage as they are telling their true and authentic story about a time in their life where they have been silenced, or have been impacted by another person’s silence.

*This Campaign has been created to help raise funds for performance venue costs, rehearsal costs, production costs, as well as to pay for all the creators and production team for their work. This campaign was also created to spread awareness of what REAL diversity looks like on stage. To see our words into action, support us by donating to this campaign and/or coming to see our show!

What is HERstory Counts?

From our Founder: “HERstory Counts is a project I created in April after over a decade of complaining -which, strangely, got me nowhere. I was complaining about the lack of diversity in our Toronto theatre houses. So many of the womyn in my life felt the same way. There are so many of us -so many talented womyn in this city, in this country, in this world. Where are OUR voices? This was my response to no longer accepting ‘We’re going to be casting diversely’. It’s not just about putting a colour or a race or a size on top of a role, it is about diversity of perspective. That’s what HERstory Counts is: many diverse perspectives. Each of these monologues are autobiographical in nature, and based on a certain theme, which is risky. We know that. I once heard: life is inherently risky. There is only one big risk you should avoid at all costs, and that’s the risk of doing nothing. So, YOU, showing up and coming to our shows, supporting and donating to our company, as well as our projects and bearing witness to this movement is you doing something."

Company Mandate: HERstory Counts is a company which is about creating a platform for diverse perspectives in story telling. HERstory Counts is a social justice movement focused on the out loud representation of those who are systematically (and systemically) left out of textbooks, left out of curriculums, left out of legislature… Left out. HERstory Counts is a response to the silencing of female-identified womyn whose stories belong in the world. We are a company featuring true stories, performed by the creators themselves offering a space to challenge and push past the ideals of the status quo. We feature and celebrate female-identified womyn of all backgrounds, all ages, all races, all histories, all sizes, all sexual orientations, and all abilities.

 

What We Need & What You Get

As HERstory Counts is a new company, we heavily rely on donations from people like YOU to be able to do what we do. Every donation, small or large, is very appreciated and goes a long way!

This is where your money will go:

- Paying all of the creators/performers and the production team 

-Paying for the rehearsal hall

-Paying for the venue at Red Sandcastle Theatre

-Paying for all the production costs: sound, lighting, props, and costumes

*If we do not reach our campaign goal of $3500, priority goes to paying all the womyn involved for their work, as well as to pay for the venue of the show.

Fun and exciting Perks: 

$10- You will receive our eternal love and gratitude

$25- Love, gratitude AND high fives 

$50- Love, gratitude, high fives AND we will give you a shout out during the opening speech of every one of our shows

$100- Love, gratitude, high fives, shout outs AND your name will be entered into a draw to meet with the cast of SILENCED after one of our shows

$150- Love, gratitude, high fives, shout outs AND your name will be entered into a draw to win two FREE tickets to one of our shows

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign to all our your friends and family :)

Come to see our show!! Tickets will be available for purchase on brownpapertickets.com two weeks prior to our opening night. 

Like our Facebook page: HERstory Counts

Follow us on Twitter: @HERstoryCounts

Follow us on Instagram: @herstorycounts

Check us out on Patreon: www.patreon.com

 

For more information about our company visit our website: http://herstorycounts.com/

story:
With the funds raised I plan to fairly compensate my dancers, purchase final costume pieces and high quality documentation (professional photos and video) of my work for archival and future promotional purposes.

My cast of 4 beautiful women (Alexis Anderson, Cynthia Kilgore, Elena Giannuzzi and Kayla Hyde) and I have been hard at work in rehearsals for The 23 Xperience, which will be premiered at Barnstorm Dance Fest June 16th and 23rd. In this work I am exploring my life and what it contains. My concept has shifted from memory to revealing realism. Real issues, battles and lessons that I have faced during the age of 23, and how I have become more in love and aware with who I am today. I am playing with contained emotions and allowing them to have a voice, by sharing with the audience vulnerability, passion, and fun. 

I am hoping to grab the audience attention by allowing them to become aware of self. Speaking from personal experience, I have found myself attracted to the idea of pleasing people, and allowing the opinions of others to dictate my individual voice. This piece is a symbol of my determination and grit composed beautifully into a night of eclectic movement and impetuous emotion.

Please help support a voice that is eager to share and inspire.

 

Listed below is the break down of were the funds will be spent. If our goal is not meet the funds will be focused on paying the dancers and purchasing final costume pieces.

4 dancers: Payment $350 each

Final Costume Pieces: $150

Professional Photos: $150

Professional Copy of the work: $20

Campaign Total: $1,720

story:
Summary

Hi. My name is Elise Robinson, and I'm a PhD candidate in Theatre and Performance Studies at the University of Georgia. This fall, I'm directing a production of Alice Birch's fantastic feminist play, Revolt. She said. Revolt again. for UGA's 2018-2019 season. As a director with over two decades of experience, I have long been committed to making my productions accessible to the widest possible audience. Though UGA does not typically offer ASL (American Sign Language) interpreted performances, it is important to me to have at least one ASL-interpreted show during my run. Sadly, my extremely small budget does not stretch to paying for sign-language interpreters, so I am hoping to raise funds so that we can offer this important service to our deaf and hard-of-hearing audience members.

What We Need & What You Get

I am looking to raise $500 for this campaign. That money will pay for:

  • Two ASL interpreters for a single performance (two interpreters is standard for theatrical performances so that dialogues and group conversations can be more clearly interpreted)
  • The interpreters' preparation time with the script
  • The interpreters' attendance at rehearsals to familiarize themselves with the production

What you get: the satisfaction of making the world a better, more accessible place!

The Impact

I strongly believe that theatre is an important cultural experience that should be open and available to everyone. Additionally, ASL interpretation is its own art form that can only enhance a theatrical performance for everyone present. In a world that is all too often built along ableist lines, ASL-interpreted performances make theatre more equitable and showcase the expressive art form of sign language.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't donate right now? No problem! Help me out by sharing this campaign on all your social media pages! And come see my show!

story:
I am hoping to produce a version of 'THE TEMPEST"  at Eressos for the Eressos International Women's Festival in 2016.This production of The Tempest will be featured as a promenade performance during the festival which runs from 3rd - 19th September 2016.

This will be a version performed by professional actors, residents of Skala Eressos and visitors.  The performers will be women from Europe and this will reflect the diversity and creativity of the project.  We will include music, workshops and visual arts as part of this production. 

Eressos is the birthplace of Sappho and since the 1980's has been pivotal in providing a safe resort for Women, including Lesbian Women from around the world.  It is a place of great natural beauty and there are good relationships between the women who visit, the international women who live at Skala Eressos  and the local Greek people many of whom contribute to the festival during the month of September.

We are looking for funding for accommodation, travel expenses for the actors and the costs of building simple but effective props,  staging, costumes and special effects.

We have the endorsement and support of a variety of institutions such as The Globe Theatre, London, The Arcola Theatre, London and The Los Angeles Women's Shakespeare Company.

It is hoped that this production will create opportunities for cultural engagement amongst a community that is suffering a downturn in tourism due to the migrant crisis and the Greek economic downturn.  It is also hoped that this adaptation will reflect some of the difficulties faced by refugees and people stranded on islands which is a theme of the play. 

​Sue Frumin :  Director Sea-change Theatre Company

story:
What Dance Could Be

Who We Are


Founded in August of 2015, PDX Contemporary Ballet is a registered 501(c)(3) and recently announced their very first full performance season, Prologue to a Memoir.


For more information about our first season, click the link below
http://www.pdxcb.com/20162017-season/


For more information about the company and its vision, go to
http://www.pdxcb.com/#our-story

The Rehearsal Space

PDX Contemporary Ballet has been fortunate enough to rent out a local dance studio for rehearsals. This large facility has a brand new sprung floor and marley. These sprung floors are essential to ensure the safety of the dancers by providing a cushioning effect.


This cushioning effect takes the added impact of shock out of the dancers’ joints and greatly reduces injury, especially when the dancers jump. Marley, a thin vinyl layer placed on top of the floor, helps prevent the dancers from slipping while wearing pointe shoes.


Having this dance space not only protects the dancers but also allows PDX Contemporary Ballet to expand their repertoire. For the first time this year, PDX Contemporary Ballet will have the ability to create a full performance season and perform works on pointe.


The Need

For dance companies, bodies create art. We need to ensure that all of our dancers are dancing in the best and safest environment possible. Thankfully we have found just the place. However, it does come with a price.


$6,351

is what we need to make our studio rental fee for the entire season.


Every little bit helps!


-$13 pays for one hour of rehearsal time

-$44 pays for one day of rehearsal

-$176 pays for one week of rehearsal

-$706 pays for one month of rehearsal

-$2,117 pays for three months of rehearsal


Your Donation is Doubled!!!!

   Every donation made to this campaign will be MATCHED dollar to               dollar up to $1,000 thanks to an anonymous donation. Take    advantage of this exciting chance to have your generosity extend even                                                                further!



The Impact

On average PDX Contemporary Ballet spends 137 hours in rehearsal in order to put on a 90 minute show. The rehearsal process is absolutely critical not only to the health and wellbeing of the dancers but also to the production value of PDX Contemporary Ballet. Please help us be the best we can be!


Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign on your personal social media pages! Help us spread the word. The more people who know, the more likely we are to reach our goal.



Thank you for all of your support!

cushioning effect.This cushioning effect
takes the added impact of shock out of the dancers’ joints and greatly reduces
injury, especially when the dancers jump. Marley, a thin vinyl layer placed on
top of the floor, helps prevent the dancers from slipping while wearing pointe
shoes.Having this dance
space not only protects the dancers but also allows PDX Contemporary Ballet to
expand their repertoire. For the first time this year, PDX Contemporary Ballet
will have the ability to create a full performance season and perform works on
pointe.The Need
For dance companies,
bodies create art. We need to ensure that all of our dancers are dancing in the
best and safest environment possible. Thankfully we have found just the place.
However, it does come with a price.
$6,351
is what we need to
make our studio rental fee for the entire season.
Every little bit helps!
-$13 pays for one hour of rehearsal time
-$44 pays for one day of rehearsal
-$176 pays for one week of rehearsal
-$706 pays for one month of rehearsal
-$2,117 pays for three months of rehearsal

Your Donation is Doubled!!!!

   Every donation made to
this campaign will be MATCHED dollar to               dollar up to $1,000 thanks to an anonymous donation. Take    advantage of this exciting chance to have your generosity extend even                                                                further!



The Impact
On average PDX
Contemporary Ballet spends 137 hours in rehearsal in order to put on a 90
minute show. The rehearsal process is absolutely critical not only to the
health and wellbeing of the dancers but also to the production value of PDX
Contemporary Ballet. Please help us be the best we can be!
Other Ways You Can Help
Share this campaign
on your personal social media pages! Help us spread the word. The more people who know, the more
likely we are to reach our goal.



Thank you for all of your support!

story:
We've reached our super stretch goal! Any extra money we make will be going towards our next production.

Much love
- V+K

Who are you, anyways?


We are Vanessa Labrie and Kathleen Glynn, co-founders of Trip & Guts Theatre, the first and only theatre company in the United Kingdom that aims to showcase Québec culture and new writing. Our first production is Cut Throat (Tranche-Cul) by Jean-Philippe Baril Guérard, and will be part of the Camden Fringe 2016, in London.

In this massive English theatre hub, we quickly realised there was barely any trace of Québec theatre at all, mostly because of the language barrier. Québec music is known around the world (Arcade Fire, Patrick Watson, Rufus Wainwright, Coeur de Pirate, hell, Céline Dion!), and so is Québec cinema (Xavier Dolan, Jean-Marc Vallée, Denys Arcand, Denis Villeneuve, Philippe Falardeau), but Québec theatre is underrepresented in the UK.
After all, to our knowledge, there are only five professional Québec actors listed in the whole of the UK, and we're two of them.

However, Québec theatre is worthy of being in the limelight. We are incredible storytellers: Catherine-Anne Toupin's Right Now run at the Bush Theatre, the Traverse and the Theatre Royal Bath was a massive success.

We want to show the world what we can do, by collaborating with fantastic artists from the UK and all over the world. 

Okay, and what are you up to?

We are performing Cut Throat on the 15-16-18-19-20-22 August 2016 at the London Irish Centre. You can book HERE.


All right, what do you guys need?

Our initial goal was to raise £2000 prior to the run. We didn't know we were going to get such an overwhelmingly positive response, and we are beyond thankful that you've helped us reach not only our initial goal, but our stretch goal of £2500!

We've decided to add a super stretch goal - £3000 - to help us cover some new fees we've had to deal with (the reprint of the programmes, public liability insurance, etc). Plus, the more money we raise crowdfunding-wise, the more likely we'll be able to pay our fantastic cast and the more money we'll be able to donate to Refugee Action.

With that money, we'll be able to cover our production costs - which still doesn't include anyone's salary. We weren't able to get any financial aid from arts organisations here or back in Québec, so we've been putting our own money into this from the start.

£3000 will help us cover the venue, the posters, the leaflets, the teasers, the programmes, the actual Camden Fringe submission, the adaptation of the play, and the copyrighting of the play.. Any extra money we make will go into paying the cast/crew.

And why should I help?

Cut Throat is a strikingly relevant play in these uncertain times. It examines the power of a well-crafted argument and just how far one can go with charisma. The play is a reflection of human cruelty, so we can come to understand it.

15% of the profits we make will go to Refugee Action to help refugees and asylum seekers in the United Kingdom. As expats, we understand how hard it is to move to another country, and we moved to England by choice. We want to help out the people who had no choice but to leave everything behind to survive.

We have a gender equal casting, with people from a large variety of backgrounds and ages. It is a hard business if you don't fit the mould, so we wanted to give a voice to as many different people as possible through this play.

We'd like as many people as possible to be executive producers of this project, which is why our crowdfunding campaign is so important. We want you to feel like you've made a difference in our production, and this is why we've designed our perks in such a straight-forward way.

And is there anything else I can do to help out?

We all know the power of social media, and how it can rally people around a project. So if you haven't already:

- Follow us on Twitter @tripandguts , re-tweet us and share the love!
- Invite your friends/family/neighbours/secret crush to the show. Event HERE.
- Book your tickets online now HERE. We keep 95% of advanced sales, 75% of sales at the door.
- Take a look at our website.

story:
About Us

Founded in the summer of 2014, we are an all-female theatre troupe that puts up productions of Shakespeare plays in order to raise money for various causes! 
Recently, we have also included musical cabarets in our season's lineup, and this fall, we will be putting up a new original play by a female playwright! We hope to continue to expand or horizons and explore new possibilities for performances and artistic expression!

Why We Need Your Help

As all of the donations from our past shows go to the causes we have chosen to support, so we need your help to continue to produce theatre that empowers women and girls, which can only contribute to a more equal and enlightened society! We may be a small group, but we're growing, and it all starts with one small voice, doesn't it?

Why The Project Is Important

It has always been true that art is one of the most important outlets to empower and inspire people. Through our theatrical endeavors, we provide artistic opportunities for women that would otherwise be unavailable in a male-dominated and often sexist industry. We provide a female voice and perspective, which benefits both men AND women. We turn history on it's head, changing out the all-male casts of Shakespeare's time for all-female casts, finding new meaning through our own interpretations. We are currently developing outreach programs for young girls that will help inspire them to realize they are capable of anything and everything. All in all, we believe in and promote a woman's right to the power of her imagination and the importance of her ideas. 

Risks & Challenges

As of now, our rehearsal space is an apartment living room (though we have been able to put up our shows at the Carriage House Arts Center in Norwalk, thanks to their incredible generosity). Our costumes are what we have in our closets, and everything we do in terms of producing our shows is volunteer. We do everything we can to scrape together and put up our best possible productions, but in order to do that and to keep creating new theatre, we need a little help pushing forward! The more money we have to produce our shows, the more we can do in terms of outreach, and the more impact we can have on our society! We are a passionate and hard-working group of women; we care a great deal about we're doing and we hope you will too!  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, please spread the word about our group! We hope to see you come out to one of our shows, or even participate!

story:
Short Summary

Mercy, Mercy is a new play by Annette Storckman. When church organ player Meredith puts her father in a nursing home, she is forced into a desperate financial situation. In order to pay her bills, she and her boyfriend begin killing people so she can play at their funerals for cash. A dark comedy about the United States healthcare system with a healthy dose of Catholic weirdness.

This play is being presented at The Barrow Group as a staged reading, and we need your help with some final bits of funding!

What We Need & What You Get

While we will be receiving a lot of help through our package with The Barrow Group, there are still some costs that are not covered.

  • Art is work, and we expect people to be paid. With your help, we can ensure that our actors and creative team receive the compensation they deserve. There are additional costs like rehearsal space, listings, and printing. With funding, we can ensure we get the right spaces and production tools that will make this developmental reading enjoyable for the audience and useful for the team!
  • This reading is free to the public, however, for every donation of $5 or more, you will receive a thank you in our program. For $15 or more you will get a thank-you and special reserved seating.  For $25 or more you will receive a thank-you, reserved seating, and our playwright, Annette Storckman, will also write a personalized haiku for you on Twitter (@astorcks). 
  • If we do not reach our entire goal, the funds will be prioritized to paying stipends. But in a perfect world, those who have already fronted their hard-earned money for production costs will receive a refund.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand not everyone can contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Share this campaign with your friends! Be like Meredith and use some Catholic guilt on them. Or murder them? No, that's probably bad... right?
  • Come to our show on October 26th!

xx
The Mercy, Mercy Team

story:
WHO AM I?                                                       TÜRKÇE AÇIKLAMASI AŞAĞIDA

I am Tugba, a performer from Istanbul. I have finished my studies in theather at Studio Players founded by Sahika Tekand and as a sociology student at Bogazici University. This season, I have been acting professionally in stage play, naming Tiyatrogrotto, Kitchen To Measure.

WHAT DO I WANT?

I have been accepted to the international workshop by world famous Attis Theater Company. This means so much to me. Learning the ‘biodynamical acting technique’ founded by TheodorosTerzopoulos in its birthplace Athens will not only improve my acting skills, it will also let me observe how this asthetic perception can affect on perceiving of the world. My great interest towards biodynamical acting lays upon its immense capacitiy to create an energy zone through the phsycality of body. Throughout my one month in Athens, what I experience will be my reunion with my own body in order to unleash and release the source of energy in my body and express it on stage. The other thing about biodynamic acting that fascinates me is its strong connection with memory of the body. I believe biodynamic acting can be an evidence of an obscured cultural and artistic universe of which body has never forgotten. Mind may forget but body always remembers. In short, as a woman actor, I have got really close to witness an entire different story about the world which has been for long locked in limited spaces and suppressed bodies, and I really want to be able to hear this story and share it with everyone I can reach to.

WHY I NEED YOUR HELP?

It is near impossible to find theather funding in Turkey. Unfortunately, attempts to get a scholarhip most often remain unresponded. And it gets even harder to find a financial support when one diverges from mainstream, in this case attending to a Terzopoulos workshop can be conceived too marginal. Also it is extremely hard to sustain a living Turkey as performer and one has to work in different jobs. Although I have been working for months in different jobs such as tour guiding or babysitting, I could not yet managed to collect enough money for the workshop expenses. Your support will make possible this artistic experience which I dream of such a long time. My dear friends, colleagues, teachers and supporters, I am asking for your support for to go to Athens.

  So here is the deal:

  Cost of the workshop : 1000 euros

  Transportaion (by bus): 120 euros

  Accomodation: 600 euros

  Food and other stuff: 600 euros

  Total expenses for my trip to Athens: 2320 Euros

  Total expenses equal to  almost:  2578 Dollars ( ı have to write as dollar calculation , because, ı have no verified accounts for euros) 

Even smallest contribution you will make means a lot for me. Please support as much as you can do. But if you cannot support financially, there are other ways to contribute and each one is also much appreciated:

  -You can accomodate me in Athens, or help me contact with people who have a place in Athens

  -You can share this campaign with your social circle (via facebook, twitter, website etc.)

-You can introduce me with institutions, organizations, etc. that you think can help me to provide the financial source

You can contact me via lalobakuartet@gmail.com for all your questions. Thank you very much!


BEN KİMİM?

Ben Tuğba.

 İstanbul’da yaşayan bir oyuncuyum. Boğaziçi Üniversitesi sosyoloji eğitimimin yanı sıra Şahika Tekand’ın kurduğu Studio Oyuncuları’nda tiyatro eğitimi tamamladım. Bu sezon, Tiyatrogrotto ile Mutfak Söyleşileri adlı bir oyunda profesyonel oyunculuk yapmaktayım.

NE İSTİYORUM?

Temmuz ayında gerçekleşecek olan dünyaca ünlü Attis Tiyatrosunun uluslararası  yaz dönemi eğitimine kabul edildim. Terzopoulos’un geliştirdiği biyodinamik oyunculuk tekniğini yerinde Atina'da öğrenmek sadece oyunculuğumu büyük ölçüde geliştirecek bir dönem değil, aynı zamanda Terzopoulos’un yaratmış olduğu estetik görüşün nasıl bir dünya görüşü haline geldiğine de şahit olacağım.  Biyodinamik oyunculuğa bu kadar ilgi göstermemin nedeni ise, doğrudan bedenin fizikselliğinden yola çıkarak sahnede  büyük enerjisel bir alan yaratma kudretine sahip olmasıdır. Bir ay boyunca yaşayacağım tecrübe, bir oyuncu olarak bedenin kaynaklarını ortaya çıkarmak ve doğrudan bunu sahnede ifade edebilmek için bedeninle yeniden yeniden buluşmanın kendisini kapsamakta.  Beni özellikle bu eğitime iten şeylerden birisi de biyodinamik oyunculuğun beden hafızası ile kurduğu sıkı bağ. Bu teknik, hem sanatsal hem de kültürel anlamda bedenin hiçbir zaman unutmadığı bir dünyanın kanıtı olabilir. Belki akli düzeyde birçok şey unutulabilir, ancak beden her zaman hatırlar. Özetle, bedenlerin mahkum edildiği ve otoriteler tarafından belli mekanlara sıkıştırıldığı bir dünyanın karşısında, bedenin kendi hafızası ile anlatabileceği bambaşka şeyler var demenin yoluna bir kadın oyuncu olarak çok yakınım ve bununla yaşamayı ve aktarmayı çok istiyorum.

Neden böyle bir yardıma ihtiyacım var?

Türkiye’de tiyatro alanında fon bulabilmek çok zor.  Sanatsal alanda burs talebine karşılık alabilmek için atılan adımlar karşılıksız kalıyor, maalesef.  Ana akımın dışındaki eğilimler yeteri kadar desteklenmiyor.  Atina’da Terzopoulos’un atölyesine katılmak marjinal kalabiliyor.

Bunun yanı sıra Türkiye’de sadece tiyatro oyuncusu olarak hayatının idame ettirebilmek nerdeyse imkansız ve ek bir iş yapmak durumundasın. Aylardır ekstra işler yapmama rağmen eğitim ücretini karşılayabilecek durumda değilim. Bu işlere oyun ablalığı, tur rehberliği gibi işler dahil.  

Vereceğiniz destek, uzun zamandır hayalini kurduğum bu sanatsal buluşmayı mümkün kılacak. Sevgili dostlarım, meslektaşlarım, hocalarım ve destekçilerimden Atina'ya gidebilmem için destek istiyorum.

DURUM ŞU:

Atina’ya yapacağım yolculuğun masrafları şöyle:

Eğitim ücreti: 1000 Euro

Ulaşım (Otobüs): 120 Euro

Konaklama: 600 Euro

Yiyecek ve diğer harcamalar: 600 Euro

Toplam: 2320 Euro

Toplam (ortalama): 2578 Dolar ( Dolar olarak yazmak durumundayım çünkü, euro için uygun bir  banka hesabına sahip değilim)


Yapacağınız en küçük bağış bile benim için çok önemli. Lütfen elinizden geldiğince destekleyiniz. Maddi destek veremiyorsanız, başka yollar da var. Şöyle:

Başka Nasıl Yardımcı Olabilirim?

  • Atina’da bana kalacak yer sağlayabilir ya da kalacak yer sağlayabilecek biriyle iletişim kurmamı sağlayabilirsiniz.
  • Bu kampanyayı kendi çevrenizde paylaşabilirsiniz. (facebook, twitter, internet sayfası, blog etc.)
  • Gerekli kaynağı sağlamama yardım edebilecek organizasyonlarla beni iletişime geçirebilirsiniz. 

Her türlü sorunuz için lalobakuartet@gmail.com adresinden bana ulaşabilirsiniz.
