gerçekleşecek olan dünyaca ünlü Attis Tiyatrosunun uluslararası  yaz dönemi eğitimine kabul edildim. Terzopoulos’un geliştirdiği biyodinamik
oyunculuk tekniğini yerinde Atina'da öğrenmek sadece oyunculuğumu büyük ölçüde geliştirecek bir dönem değil, aynı zamanda Terzopoulos’un yaratmış olduğu
estetik görüşün nasıl bir dünya görüşü haline geldiğine de şahit olacağım.  Biyodinamik oyunculuğa bu kadar ilgi
göstermemin nedeni ise, doğrudan bedenin fizikselliğinden yola çıkarak sahnede  büyük enerjisel bir alan yaratma kudretine
sahip olmasıdır. Bir ay boyunca yaşayacağım tecrübe, bir oyuncu olarak bedenin
kaynaklarını ortaya çıkarmak ve doğrudan bunu sahnede ifade edebilmek için
bedeninle yeniden yeniden buluşmanın kendisini kapsamakta.  Beni özellikle bu eğitime iten şeylerden
birisi de biyodinamik oyunculuğun beden hafızası ile kurduğu sıkı bağ. Bu teknik, hem sanatsal hem de kültürel
anlamda bedenin hiçbir zaman unutmadığı bir dünyanın kanıtı olabilir. Belki akli
düzeyde birçok şey unutulabilir, ancak beden her zaman hatırlar. Özetle,
bedenlerin mahkum edildiği ve otoriteler tarafından belli mekanlara
sıkıştırıldığı bir dünyanın karşısında, bedenin kendi hafızası ile
anlatabileceği bambaşka şeyler var demenin yoluna bir kadın oyuncu olarak çok
yakınım ve bununla yaşamayı ve aktarmayı çok istiyorum.
Neden
böyle bir yardıma ihtiyacım var?
Türkiye’de tiyatro
alanında fon bulabilmek çok zor. 
Sanatsal alanda burs talebine karşılık alabilmek için atılan adımlar
karşılıksız kalıyor, maalesef.  Ana
akımın dışındaki eğilimler yeteri kadar desteklenmiyor.  Atina’da Terzopoulos’un atölyesine katılmak marjinal
kalabiliyor. 
Bunun yanı sıra Türkiye’de
sadece tiyatro oyuncusu olarak hayatının idame ettirebilmek nerdeyse imkansız
ve ek bir iş yapmak durumundasın. Aylardır ekstra işler yapmama rağmen eğitim
ücretini karşılayabilecek durumda değilim. Bu işlere oyun ablalığı, tur
rehberliği gibi işler dahil.  
Vereceğiniz destek,
uzun zamandır hayalini kurduğum bu sanatsal buluşmayı mümkün kılacak. Sevgili
dostlarım, meslektaşlarım, hocalarım ve destekçilerimden Atina'ya gidebilmem
için destek istiyorum.
DURUM ŞU:
Atina’ya yapacağım
yolculuğun masrafları şöyle:
Eğitim ücreti: 1000
Euro
Ulaşım (Otobüs): 120
Euro
Konaklama: 600 Euro
Yiyecek ve diğer
harcamalar: 600 Euro 
Toplam: 2320 EuroToplam (ortalama): 2578 Dolar ( Dolar olarak yazmak durumundayım çünkü, euro için uygun bir  banka hesabına sahip değilim)
Yapacağınız
en küçük bağış bile benim için çok önemli. Lütfen elinizden geldiğince
destekleyiniz. Maddi destek veremiyorsanız, başka yollar da var. Şöyle:
Başka Nasıl Yardımcı Olabilirim?

Atina’da
     bana kalacak yer sağlayabilir ya da kalacak yer sağlayabilecek biriyle iletişim
     kurmamı sağlayabilirsiniz.
Bu
     kampanyayı kendi çevrenizde paylaşabilirsiniz. (facebook, twitter,
     internet sayfası, blog etc.)
Gerekli
     kaynağı sağlamama yardım edebilecek organizasyonlarla beni iletişime
     geçirebilirsiniz. 

Her türlü
sorunuz için lalobakuartet@gmail.com
adresinden bana ulaşabilirsiniz.

story:
Short Summary

Gravity Arts is a production company founded by Hunter MacNair.   Our goal is to create a network of artists who are glued together by intrinsic curiosity, a knack for the unconventional, and a desire to give.  We are producing our first production, an ambitious adaptation by Hunter MacNair of William Shakespeare's poetic history play "Richard II" at the Access Theater opening October 13th.

Hunter MacNair is an actor who has been in New York City for 5 years.  In that time he has worked with and learned from hundreds of fellow actors, directors, musicians, painters, sculptors, filmmakers, etc.  New York is teeming with inspiration and originality and Gravity is how he wants to tie his experiences together.  Gravity is not a theatre troupe.  It is not a record label.  It is a community of artists who are taking the expected and stripping it of all preconceived notions, leaving a canvas reserved for simplicity in storytelling. 

With your donation, you will be planting the seeds of what will some day grow into a large tree with branches that extend all directions.  This is a company that will have something for everyone and by contributing, you are giving chances to artists not only now with this production, but down the road after we have made our statement with our very first show.  Your generosity is what will make this thing happen.  

What We Need & What You Get

After months of planning and design, we have discovered our budget is a necessary $5,000.  We simply do not want to sacrifice the quality of what we make.  This figure will go entirely to the show and will be spent on (but not limited to):

  • Theater rental (Access Theater Gallery Space)
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Props and wardrobe
  • Set
  • Paying artists
  • Marketing
  • Stage manager

We need to make sure all outside artists are compensated for their help.  Gravity will not be taking any of these funds for itself.  It all goes to the show.  

You can see our perks listed on the right side of the screen.  No donation is too small and comes with our deepest gratitude.  With your investment, you can someday say, "I was a part of the beginning."  You'll thank yourself later.

The Impact

As mentioned earlier, Gravity Arts is not a theatre company.  Plays are familiar ground with who we are right now and this particular production is designed to encompass what we are all about: brevity, originality, and transcendence.  Down the road Gravity will share the talents of many other artists whose talents lie in different mediums.  By supporting our premier venture, you are investing in the quality of how we introduce ourselves to the world.  From there we grow. 

Gravity is the phenomenon that has shaped the Universe.   Things with energy, such as stars, are attracted to each other, thus creating galaxies, solar systems, life.  It is not a force.  In the absolute broadest of terms, it is the result of space and time coexisting.  It gives and takes, leaving us with a sense of balance.  Gravity Arts wants to emulate that balance.  How do we do this?  By getting behind ventures that meld the past with the future, the compassionate with the merciless, the dark with the light.  On top of that, we are here to give a platform to artists in all different mediums.  Gravity Arts wants to spread the love, but to do that we ask for yours first. 

By supporting Richard II you are helping this immediate production.  But it goes deeper than that.  With the success of this show, we will be able to continue our tireless work on other projects in the future.  Our Richard II is an innovative, fast-moving, colorful piece of poetry delivered by an extraordinarily small cast of 3.  We are ready to share with the people and would be honored to have your involvement, no matter how big or small.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share us on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and everything else with your friends and family!  Especially that rich, eccentric uncle of yours.  Every dollar is helpful and goes toward the show.  We are also going to need physical hands their at the space, so if you want to contribute your time as an usher or helping us get the space together pre-performance, we could use it.  Even get a seat to the show out of it.  So again, please share us with everyone and we hope to see you this October at Richard II.

story:
The Project  

In the Bay Area there is a wonderfully diverse and vibrant contemporary dance community. However, a gap exists in the understanding of highly influential historical dance forms on the dance and music we enjoy today. We strive to make historical dance relevant for modern audiences, enticing our contemporaries to take a new look at the past.

Through performances of "The Dancing Master" we hope to revive an appreciation of baroque dance and its influence on music through time by offering two fun and fully-costumed one-hour performances of baroque dances as they influenced the music of J. S. Bach.

True reconstructions of 18th century dances are rarely seen in the Bay Area.  Connections will be sought between specific Bach compositions and 18th century dances. By performing them together we hope to transport audiences to a time when this collaboration between music and dance flourished.

Performances will be held in San Francisco and Berkeley, California in March of 2019

Before each performance, a 30-minute pre-concert talk will include an invitation for the audience to learn a simple Baroque social dance with us.

Dates and Venues

Saturday, March 2, 2019: St. Mark's Lutheran Church, San Francisco: 7:30p.m.

Sunday, March 3, 2019: St. Clement's Episcopal Church, Berkeley: 2:00p.m.

The Producers

Jennifer Meller formed San Francisco Renaissance Dancers (SFRD) in 2012 after she joined well-established early music choir San Francisco Renaissance Voices (SFRV) as a dancer in 2011. She was promoted to the role of Dance Director in 2012 and formed the SFRD company to specialize in recreations of early operas from Medieval, Renaissance, and Baroque eras. Since then, Jen has been choreographing, performing, and making costumes for productions with local early music ensembles including “The Play of Daniel”, "Ordo Virtutum", “Venus and Adonis”, and  “Dido and Aeneas”.

Vicki Melin (traverso) and Katherine Heater (harpsichord) formed Nash Baroque in 2013 and presents concerts for festivals and chamber series as well as benefits to fund children’s music education. Members of the group are professional musicians who have advanced performance degrees from the Royal Conservatory in The Hague, and the Sweelinck Conservatory of Amsterdam. Nash Baroque Ensemble draws on a number of talented musicians, recognized nationally as specialists in music of the Baroque, to create the best ensemble for the chosen repertoire.

What We Need & Where it goes

The musicians and dancers are booked, the venue contracts signed, and rehearsals already underway for "The Dancing Master" shows. Your contribution will help us to pay the 11 artists fairly for their hard work in making this show a reality. 

We are excited about this project, and hope we can inspire you to get excited too! We believe that experiencing baroque music and dance together greatly enriches the experience of both disciplines, and has a lasting effect on the audience and the artists alike.

 

The Impact

San Francisco Renaissance Dancers welcomes dancers of all sizes, colors, abilities, backgrounds and genders. Our dancers meet regularly to practice early dance technique and study the extant manuals published by dancing masters from the 15th through 18th centuries. Dancers also learn the art of deciphering the notations in these manuals and experience the exciting process of bringing an ancient dance to life. 

Costumed performance with live musicians is a necessary part of fully understanding baroque dance. The baroque movement vocabulary is more deeply understood once the heavy and restrictive clothing is donned. And when the musicians start to play, improvising and reacting with and around the accents of the dance, a dancer can feel lifted and light, despite the costume.

Musicians are often surprised to learn that the baroque dance style is more lively than they would have thought. For baroque musicians to see the movements associated with a music form helps them to understand the way the music would have been played at the time. This leads to a performance of whimsical interplay between musician and dancer that would have been natural during the 18th century. 

We hope that our striving for a deeper performance practice will enable audiences to feel transported to another time with us. We also hope that our work will inspire interest in early dance and that by inviting the audience to dance with us, they will understand that they are part of the early dance and music community, and not just observers.

Risks & Challenges

This is an ambitious project with a shoestring budget. We make our own costumes and borrow what we don’t have, and the artists are volunteering much of their time because they believe in what we’re doing. We seek volunteer ushers and ticket-takers, make our own programs and do our own administration. Countless hours are spent researching and reconstructing the dances, as well as finding appropriate music and creating the parts for the musicians. It is truly a labor of love.

We have experience producing concerts, so we know what’s involved. We have a detailed budget and know where every penny is going. We are aware it’s hard work but it’s also very fulfilling work. We are hoping concerts like this will help us in our mission to grow the baroque dance community in the San Francisco Bay Area.

We have received a small Musical Grant from Intermusic SF for this project. We are so happy to have the support of the music community in what we are doing. But this only covers about 30% of the costs. Your donations here will help us pay our artists fairly, and may even help with the venue costs and our costume-making, too.

Other Ways You Can Help

Are you excited about our project but don’t think you can send money at this time? You can still help by using the Indiegogo share tools and help us spread the word!

The Dancing Master FaceBook event page

SF Renaissance Dancers website

Nash Baroque website

story:
Short Summary

Andrew Cannata, Matt Connely, and myself, Joey Banks, decided to start Haymaker Players here in Austin in order to provide strong, original, and personal content to a theatre community we grew up in. Our goal for the company is simple: we will never pay a dollar to license a production. This means that when you sit down to see one of our shows you will be seeing world premiere productions of brand new plays, musicals, and stories about our communities. We will present unique adaptations of public domain work (Shakespeare, Ibsen, etc) and create pieces that tell the histories of our neighborhoods. On top of all that, our goal will always be to hire locally and give opportunity to those in Austin looking to make a living as a working artist. 

What We Need & What You Get

It's pretty simple! It costs money to put up high-quality productions and it really matters for our first few shows as we seek to create a dedicated audience base. We have already reserved the theatre space for August, but we are looking for an additional $2,000 to pay designers/actors, offset production costs (costumes, set, rentals) and to pay for basic marketing pieces (posters, ads, etc). 

We ask that you join us on this ride from the get go. If you are seeing this Indiegogo request, it's likely that you know one of us. Perhaps we've done a show together in the past or perhaps you've seen a show of ours. This is a chance to join with us in creating a new community in the Austin theatre scene and build something lasting. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand if you aren't at a place to contribute, but there are other ways to get involved! Come out and audition, do new play workshops, help build set, usher and work front of house, perhaps you have other connections that could assist us!

Simply email us: info@haymayplay.com

We can't wait to hear from you!

- haymayplay

story:
UPDATE:

WOW!!! We reached our goal in less than 24 hours!!!!

Thank you so much to everyone who has donated so far. We are so excited and honored that our goal has been met in such a short amount of time. The $1000 goal is the least amount of money we need to complete the project, and the fundraiser is still ongoing. Donations are still absolutely welcome as a higher budget will help to make this project even more impactful! Again, thank you so much to everyone who has shared and supported this project, we are so excited!!!!

 

Overview

Time & Space is an interactive non-linear live theatre experience that follows the life of a young girl named Joe navigating her senior year of high school. The audience will enter a high school party that morphs into an exploration of mental health and queer representation. 

Who We Are

We are a group of students and artists attempting to bring theatre to young people. We want the audience members to feel as free as possible during this experience. One of the main issues we are addressing is a lack of accessibility to the theatre arts. We want this experience to be comfortable, inexpensive, and get young people excited about live theatre. 

Our production team is made up of students who attend Emerson College, Berklee College of Music, and Boston Conservatory. 

What We Need

Let's break it down. We want to do this right! That means we need resources to allow us to:

  • Costumes
  • Set
  • Sound Equipment 
  • Lighting 
  • Transportation
  • Venue Costs

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can support with a monetary donation. We hope that you consider helping us out in different ways!

Share our campaign to your friends to spread the word.

Keep your eye out for the project come April!

story:
HOW IT ALL STARTED

This production of "Time Stands Still" began as scene-work for André Vauthey and Natassha Amalia at The Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute. 

Vauthey, an ER doctor turned actor/director, was deeply moved by the play, which explores the ethics and moral of working in war zones. The humanity of the characters in the play made him want to bring them to life, whatever the cost. 

 

THE JOURNEY

During their semester off, Vauthey and Amalia created their own production company in order to produce the play. 

They approached actors Ben Rademacher and Joy Turner, as well as assistant director David Ventura, who were all more than happy to donate their time and talent to the production. 

Next came getting the rights for the play, booking the venue, finding rehearsal space, hiring a makeup artist, and gathering costumes and props. 

THE CAST

- Natassha Amalia (Sarah Goodwin) marks her debut in NYC . She began working on Sarah during her time training at the Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute. She has just completed her first year at the institute and can't wait to put her training into use. 

- André Vauthey (James Dodd) is kicking off with this play his off-broadway debut as an actor and director. Originally from Switzerland, he moved to NYC to study at the Lee Strasberg's Film and Theater Institute. 

- Joy Turner (Mandy Bloom) grew up between Sendai, Japan and a small town in Maryland. She is a student at The Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute. This is her New York City stage debut. 

- Ben Rademacher (Richard Ehrlich) born and raised in Duesseldorf, Germany and recently graduated from the Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute. Ben recently had his successful Off Broadway debut, portraying the Nazi Major Steinsteiger in the original play “Defendant Maurice Chevalier” at the American Theater of Actors. Other acting credits include all lead male roles in David Hares "Blue Room" on Stage in Koblenz, Germany. He also featured in German Films and TV series including "Rosamunde Pilcher" and "Lindenstraße".

David Ventura, Assistant Director, is the “NYC Lee Strasberg Scholarship” winner and graduated from the one year conservatory at LSTFI. He was able to star in one of the school productions as Officer Lockstock in Urinetown: The Musical. This is his first time as an Assistant Director and wanted to use the knowledge he gained to help take part in directing “Time Stands Still”. He is currently on the Off Broadway show “Nightfall with Edgar Allen Poe” as Edgar with the Alpha/NYC Theatre Company.

NOW WHAT

**** Any help would greatly appreciated and no donation is too small. Please feel free to contribute however much you can. Hope to see you there! 

Any help would greatly appreciated: spreading the words, coming to the show, giving us a hand, etc.
story_txt: HOW IT ALL STARTEDThis production of "Time Stands Still" began as scene-work for André Vauthey and Natassha Amalia at The Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute. Vauthey, an ER doctor turned actor/director, was deeply moved by the play, which explores the ethics and moral of working in war zones. The humanity of the characters in the play made him want to bring them to life, whatever the cost.  THE JOURNEYDuring their semester off, Vauthey and Amalia created their own production company in order to produce the play. They approached actors Ben Rademacher and Joy Turner, as well as assistant director David Ventura, who were all more than happy to donate their time and talent to the production. Next came getting the rights for the play, booking the venue, finding rehearsal space, hiring a makeup artist, and gathering costumes and props. THE CAST- Natassha Amalia (Sarah Goodwin) marks her debut in NYC . She began working on Sarah during her time training at the Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute. She has just completed her first year at the institute and can't wait to put her training into use. - André Vauthey (James Dodd) is kicking off with this play his off-broadway debut as an actor and director. Originally from Switzerland, he moved to NYC to study at the Lee Strasberg's Film and Theater Institute. - Joy Turner (Mandy Bloom) grew up between Sendai, Japan and a small town in Maryland. She is a student at The Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute. This is her New York City stage debut. - Ben Rademacher (Richard Ehrlich) born and raised in Duesseldorf, Germany and recently graduated from the Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute. He was able to star in one of the school productions as Officer Lockstock in Urinetown: The Musical. story:
Bare Portland believes that stories don’t happen in a vacuum. They happen in communities and the places in which those communities thrive. We extract theater from the traditional stage and place it in fresh spaces.  Our interactive, site-specific performances make each location a performer. For our next production, we're asking for your help. Macbeth is our biggest undertaking yet. We've partnered with St. Luke's Cathedral and local composer Denis Nye to infuse original live music into the play. 

Bare Portland depends on the generous donations of our community to thrive. We are committed to accessibility and seek to maintain the sustainable growth in production costs. We are best able to foster growth when we set reasonable, achievable financial goals. We're reaching out to our community to help us grow.

What We Need & What You Get

The minimum funding we are asking for is $1,400. Here’s how we’re going to use it:

-This funding will allow us to compensate our composer and musicians for their work.

-Dynamic and professional images allow us to better market the production and our company as a whole. 

-Printing costs add up quickly. We would love to be able to print a program to showcase artists, thank supporters, and give context to the production. Programs are a valuable resource for students and audience members.

Perks include original poems, inclusion in our program, signed posters, performance shout-outs, rap-o-grams, dinner with the cast, and a guest-starring role in “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” and others.

If we don’t reach our entire goal, we will focus on paying our musicians and composer with what funds we do receive. We will not hire a production photographer if we don’t have funds to pay them. We don’t ask anyone to work for free.  However, we believe that our productions costs are modest and achievable.

The Impact

Bare Portland is Emboldened by the idea that stories can be told anywhere, we bring performances outside of the traditional theater walls and into notable spaces of Portland. Committed to accessibility, all performances are free or pay-what-you-can. Consistent support from the community and a track record of successful projects make us better able to expand our reach. Often, we are reaching audience members who have never seen live theater.

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us get word out about Bare Portland’s Macbeth and our campaign. Use the Indiegogo share tools for your social media.
Use the Hashtags:
#GreatPlays
#NewWays 
#BareMac 
#CareforBare

Follow us!
Bareportland.org
IG: @Bareportland
Facebook: Facebook.com/Bare-Portland

Macbeth by William Shakespeare
March 12th - 13th & 17th-20th
At St. Luke’s Cathedral
143 State Street 
Portland, Maine


A primal force is unleashed in this site-specific Macbeth. Four-women conjure 
Shakespeare’s legendary tale of ruthless ambition in the nave of St. Luke’s 
Cathedral. Experience ancient ritual surrounded by Gothic architecture and 
infused with original composed music by Denis Nye. Once you’re in it- there’s no 
turning back.


In collaboration with The First Folio Celebration and Portland Stage, Bare 
Portland’s visceral Macbeth will get your blood pumping.


SPECIAL THANKS TO ACORN PRODUCTIONS WHO ARE ACTING AS OUR FISCAL SPONSOR. THANKS TO ACORN, YOU CAN RECEIVE A TAX-DEDUCTIBLE DONATION FOR GIVING TO BARE PORTLAND'S "MACBETH."

story:
The Victory Theatre Center

40 years ago, The Victory Theatre Center was founded and built by its Artistic Directors, Tom Ormeny and Maria Gobetti, and a group of dedicated theatre artists and student volunteers. In 1997, with the help of its board of directors, 21 years ago the property was purchased. The Victory’s history attests to its commitment to the education of new talent and the development of new work. Since 1980, the Victory Theatre has presented over 100 productions and about 100 dramaturgical workshops. Over 80% of these productions and workshops were of previously unproduced new plays. Many moved on to much larger venues. 

The Victory Center Theatre is a small theatre, but what’s experienced here is large. Small space cultivates closeness; shared experience creates connection and community. Our mission is to be a creative hub for audiences and artists to engage with one another through ground-breaking theatrical productions, educational opportunities, and social events in an intimate setting that can’t help resulting in intoxicating conversation.

Your contribution is appreciated!

story:
Overview

    Η Ομάδα7 είναι η μόνη επιλεγμένη ελληνική συμμετοχή  στο Διεθνές Φεστιβάλ Θεάτρου της Στοκχόλμης για το 2019, με την παράσταση «Αντιγόνη, μια Ύβρις». Μια multimedia performance βασισμένη στην ομώνυμη τραγωδία του Σοφοκλή, σε νέα μετάφραση & διασκευή. Ο πρώτος κύκλος  παραστάσεων πραγματοποιήθηκε στο Booze Cooperativa τον Νοέμβριο και Δεκέμβριο του 2018.  Δυστυχώς η σύμβαση με το Stockholm Fringe Festival δεν καλύπτει τα έξοδα μετάβασης και διαμονής στην Στοκχόλμη, των οποίων το ύψος δυσκολεύει ακόμη περισσότερο την αυτόνομη ύπαρξη της Ομάδας7, καθώς το σύνολο της παραγωγής καλύπτεται ήδη με δυσκολία από προσωπικούς πόρους.

Omada7 is the only selected Greek participation in the International Theater Festival in Stockholm in 2019, with the performance "Antigone, a hubris". A multimedia performance based on the  Sophocles' tragedy, in a new translation & adaptation. The first round of performances took place at the Booze Cooperativa Athens, in November and December 2018. Unfortunately, the Stockholm Fringe Festival contract does not cover Stockholm's travel and accommodation costs, which make it even more difficult for Group 7 to stand alone as the whole production is already covered with difficulty from personal resources.

Ο στόχος μας είναι 2600 ευρώ τα οποία θα καλύψουν:

1. τα οδοιπορικά των μελών της Ομάδας7 (3 ηθοποιοί και 3 τεχνικοί, σύνολο 6 άτομα).

2. το κόστος της εκεί διαμονής μας.

 Η οποιαδήποτε συνδρομή από μέρους σας είναι εξαιρετικά βοηθητική για την επίτευξη του σκοπού μας. Το Φεστιβάλ της Στοκχόλμης θα είναι η τρίτη συμμετοχή μας με ίδιους πόρους, σε διεθνή διοργάνωση,  μετά το Διεθνές Φεστιβάλ Πειραματικού Θεάτρου του Καΐρου 2010 και  την Διεθνή Έκθεση Σκηνογραφίας και Θεατρικής Αρχιτεκτονικής της Πράγας (The Prague Quadrennial of Performance Design and Space, PQ 2015

Our goal is € 2600 to cover:

1. the travel expenses of the members of the Group7 (3 actors and 3 technicians, totaling 6 people).

2. the cost of our stay there.

Any subscription on your behalf is extremely helpful in achieving our goal. The Stockholm Festival will be our third own participation in an international event after the Cairo International Experimental Theater Festival 2010 and the Prague Quadrennial of Performance Design and Space, PQ 2015

​Λίγα λόγια για την παράσταση «Αντιγόνη, μια Ύβρις»

«…η Αντιγόνη του Σοφοκλή είναι μια κορυφή της δημοκρατικής πολιτικής σκέψης και στάσης, που αποκλείει και καταδικάζει το μόνος φρονείν, το οποίο αναγνωρίζει την έμφυτη ύβρη των ανθρώπων, και απαντά σε τούτη με τη φρόνηση» Κορνήλιος Καστοριάδης

Στο  κέντρο μίας σκηνικής εγκατάστασης με έντονη την παρουσία οπτικοακουστικών μέσων, τρεις γυναίκες ερμηνεύτριες μοιράζονται όλους τους ρόλους, παρεμβάλουν τις προσωπικές τους απόψεις και εμπειρίες και επεμβαίνουν στη σκηνική δράση. Σ’ αυτόν τον κλειστό κύκλο ενός σάπιου οικονομικού κέντρου εξουσίας τα δεκαπέντε πρόσωπα του Χορού μπορούν να φτάσουν μόνο διαμεσολαβημένα, μέσα από μια οθόνη, για να διαπραγματευτούν, να διεκδικήσουν ή να αρνηθούν τη δική τους ατομική ευθύνη.

Με όχημα τη σοφόκλεια τραγωδία, τις σκέψεις του Κορνήλιου Καστοριάδη και υλικά του θεάτρου της επινόησης, η Ομάδα7 ξαναδιαβάζει ένα κλασσικό έργο. Συνδιαλέγεται με την διαχρονική τραγικότητα αυτού του «δεινότερου» απ’ όλα τα πλάσματα, του Ανθρώπου και  θέτει ερωτήματα: είναι ηθικό χρέος του ανθρώπου να αντιστέκεται στην Ύβρη της  εξουσίας; Η αντίσταση μπορεί να γίνει ύβρις;  Είμαστε σε θέση να ακούσουμε πραγματικά την διαφορετική γνώμη, τον διαφορετικό άνθρωπο; Τι υπάρχει πριν τις αμετάκλητες αποφάσεις; Έχουμε δίκιο μόνο εμείς;

 Πληροφορίες παράστασης

Μετάφραση/Διασκευή: Βίκυ Μαστρογιάννη-Ομάδα7

Δραματουργία/Επιμέλεια κειμένου: Ευδοκία Δεληπέτρου

Βοηθός Σκηνοθέτη: Γιώργος Ανδράκης

Σχεδιασμός φωτισμού/Φωτογραφία/Video: Γιώργος Ζαφειρίου

Σκηνικά/Κοστούμια: Δάφνη Αηδόνη

Πρωτότυπη Μουσική: Μάριος Τσάγκαρης

Ηθοποιοί:  Έλσα Λουμπαρδία, Ελένη Μπαμπασάκη, Ευαγγελή Φίλη

Χορός Video: Ανδρονίκη Αβδελιώτη, Δάφνη Αηδόνη, Γιώργος Ανδράκης, Μυρσίνη Γεωργάκη,  Ευδοκία Δεληπέτρου, Γιώργος Ζαφειρίου, Αλκιβιάδης Ζούπας, Σοφία Λιάκου, Βαγγέλης Παπαδάκης, Μάνος Παπαδάς, Βασιλική Σκευοφύλαξ, Θοδωρής Σκυφτούλης, Γιάννης Τζέμης, Μάριος Τσάγκαρης, Ραφαήλ-Ανάργυρος Τσάντες.

Πότε: 4 και στις 5 Σεπτεμβρίου 2019

Πού: Διεθνές Φεστιβάλ Θεάτρου της Στοκχόλμης 2019 (Stockholm Fringe Festival) στο Teater 3  

Η παράσταση πρόκειται να ανέβει στην Αθήνα από τον Οκτώβριο 2019 σε χώρο που θα ανακοινωθεί σύντομα.

Χρήσιμα links

 www.stockholmfringe.com  

www.facebook.com/Ομάδα-7-145215469006072/  

Promo trailer  www.youtube.com/watch?v=8JeBcy8_VVE 

Antigone, a hubris.

Terrible wonders walk the world but none the match for (wo)man. Sophocles’ Antigone“. In a decayed centre of power, three female performers share all the roles of Sophocles Antigone, intervening with their own views and experiences and devising a multimedia performance. Only mediated through a screen can the fifteen members of the chorus have access to this restricted financial centre, in order to negotiate, to claim or to refuse their individual responsibility. Is resistance a moral duty? Is our judgement the only valid one? Can resistance turn into hubris? Can we listen?

 

Λίγα λόγια για την Ομάδα7​

Η Αστική Μη Κερδοσκοπική Ομάδα Θεάτρου Επτά (Ομάδα7) αποτελεί μια καλλιτεχνική κολεκτίβα  που διερευνά τις πολιτισμικές ιδιαιτερότητες της χώρας σ’ ένα διάλογο με τις φόρμες και τις μεθόδους του μεταμοντέρνου θεάτρου. Σχηματίστηκε το 2003 και απέκτησε νομική μορφή το 2006. Έχει είκοσι δύο παραγωγές στο ενεργητικό της μέχρι τώρα, στις οποίες συμμετέχουν κάθε φορά, τουλάχιστον 15 καλλιτέχνες και εθελοντές. Δεν διαθέτει μόνιμη θεατρική στέγη και δεν έχει επιχορηγηθεί ποτέ από το Υπουργείο Πολιτισμού ή άλλον δημόσιο φορέα.

Σημαντικά στοιχεία λειτουργίας της ομάδα είναι:

- η δημιουργική συνδιαλλαγή διαφορετικών αισθητικών μέσα από την προσωπική έκφραση του κάθε συνεργάτη και ο συλλογικός χαρακτήρας της πολυφωνικής σύνθεσης που σχηματίζεται.

-η χρήση και διαχείριση του χώρου (δημόσιου ή ιδιωτικού) ως εικαστικό περιβάλλον.

- η αξιοποίηση οπτικοακουστικού υλικού κάθε μορφής.

- η επεξεργασία των κειμένων ως μέρος ενός διαλόγου με τη σύγχρονη δραματουργία.

-ο ρόλος και η θέση  του ερευνητικού  θεάτρου στην σύγχρονη ελληνική πραγματικότητα.

- η αλληλεπίδραση και η συνδιαλλαγή με το ευρύτερο περιβάλλον της διεθνούς σκηνής.

About us

Omada7 is a performing arts group founded in 2003. The group does not own a permanent work space and has never been subsidized by Greek Ministry of Culture or other public funders. It has produced twenty-two productions so far, involving at least 15 artists and volunteers each time.Omada7 aims at investigating the cultural particularities of Greece in dialogue with the forms and methods of post-modern theatre.

Άλλοι τρόποι για να βοηθήσεις:

Διακίνησε την καμπάνια όπου και σε όσους μπορείς.

Στο  κέντρο μίας σκηνικής εγκατάστασης με έντονη την παρουσία οπτικοακουστικών μέσων, τρεις γυναίκες ερμηνεύτριες μοιράζονται όλους τους ρόλους, παρεμβάλουν τις προσωπικές τους απόψεις και εμπειρίες και επεμβαίνουν στη σκηνική δράση. Σ’ αυτόν τον κλειστό κύκλο ενός σάπιου οικονομικού κέντρου εξουσίας τα δεκαπέντε πρόσωπα του Χορού μπορούν να φτάσουν μόνο διαμεσολαβημένα, μέσα από μια οθόνη, για να διαπραγματευτούν, να διεκδικήσουν ή να αρνηθούν τη δική τους ατομική ευθύνη.
Με όχημα τη σοφόκλεια τραγωδία, τις σκέψεις του Κορνήλιου Καστοριάδη και υλικά του θεάτρου της επινόησης, η Ομάδα7 ξαναδιαβάζει ένα κλασσικό έργο. Συνδιαλέγεται με την διαχρονική τραγικότητα αυτού του «δεινότερου» απ’ όλα τα πλάσματα, του Ανθρώπου και  θέτει ερωτήματα: είναι ηθικό χρέος του ανθρώπου να αντιστέκεται στην Ύβρη της  εξουσίας; Η αντίσταση μπορεί να γίνει ύβρις;  Είμαστε σε θέση να ακούσουμε πραγματικά την διαφορετική γνώμη, τον διαφορετικό άνθρωπο; Τι υπάρχει πριν τις αμετάκλητες αποφάσεις; Έχουμε δίκιο μόνο εμείς;
 Πληροφορίες παράστασης
Μετάφραση/Διασκευή: Βίκυ Μαστρογιάννη-Ομάδα7
Δραματουργία/Επιμέλεια κειμένου: Ευδοκία Δεληπέτρου
Βοηθός Σκηνοθέτη: Γιώργος Ανδράκης
Σχεδιασμός φωτισμού/Φωτογραφία/Video: Γιώργος Ζαφειρίου
Σκηνικά/Κοστούμια: Δάφνη Αηδόνη
Πρωτότυπη Μουσική: Μάριος Τσάγκαρης
Ηθοποιοί:  Έλσα Λουμπαρδία, Ελένη Μπαμπασάκη, Ευαγγελή Φίλη
Χορός Video: Ανδρονίκη Αβδελιώτη, Δάφνη Αηδόνη, Γιώργος Ανδράκης, Μυρσίνη Γεωργάκη,  Ευδοκία Δεληπέτρου, Γιώργος Ζαφειρίου, Αλκιβιάδης Ζούπας, Σοφία Λιάκου, Βαγγέλης Παπαδάκης, Μάνος Παπαδάς, Βασιλική Σκευοφύλαξ, Θοδωρής Σκυφτούλης, Γιάννης Τζέμης, Μάριος Τσάγκαρης, Ραφαήλ-Ανάργυρος Τσάντες.
Πότε: 4 και στις 5 Σεπτεμβρίου 2019
Πού: Διεθνές Φεστιβάλ Θεάτρου της Στοκχόλμης 2019 (Stockholm Fringe Festival) στο Teater 3  
Η παράσταση πρόκειται να ανέβει στην Αθήνα από τον Οκτώβριο 2019 σε χώρο που θα ανακοινωθεί σύντομα.
Χρήσιμα links
 www.stockholmfringe.com  
www.facebook.com/Ομάδα-7-145215469006072/  
Promo trailer  www.youtube.com/watch?v=8JeBcy8_VVE 
Antigone, a hubris.
Terrible wonders walk the world but none the match for (wo)man. Sophocles’ Antigone“. In a decayed centre of power, three female performers share all the roles of Sophocles Antigone, intervening with their own views and experiences and devising a multimedia performance. Only mediated through a screen can the fifteen members of the chorus have access to this restricted financial centre, in order to negotiate, to claim or to refuse their individual responsibility. Is resistance a moral duty? Is our judgement the only valid one? Can resistance turn into hubris? Can we listen?
 
Λίγα λόγια για την Ομάδα7​
Η Αστική Μη Κερδοσκοπική Ομάδα Θεάτρου Επτά (Ομάδα7) αποτελεί μια καλλιτεχνική κολεκτίβα  που διερευνά τις πολιτισμικές ιδιαιτερότητες της χώρας σ’ ένα διάλογο με τις φόρμες και τις μεθόδους του μεταμοντέρνου θεάτρου. Σχηματίστηκε το 2003 και απέκτησε νομική μορφή το 2006. Έχει είκοσι δύο παραγωγές στο ενεργητικό της μέχρι τώρα, στις οποίες συμμετέχουν κάθε φορά, τουλάχιστον 15 καλλιτέχνες και εθελοντές. Δεν διαθέτει μόνιμη θεατρική στέγη και δεν έχει επιχορηγηθεί ποτέ από το Υπουργείο Πολιτισμού ή άλλον δημόσιο φορέα.
Σημαντικά στοιχεία λειτουργίας της ομάδα είναι:
- η δημιουργική συνδιαλλαγή διαφορετικών αισθητικών μέσα από την προσωπική έκφραση του κάθε συνεργάτη και ο συλλογικός χαρακτήρας της πολυφωνικής σύνθεσης που σχηματίζεται.
-η χρήση και διαχείριση του χώρου (δημόσιου ή ιδιωτικού) ως εικαστικό περιβάλλον.
- η αξιοποίηση οπτικοακουστικού υλικού κάθε μορφής.
- η επεξεργασία των κειμένων ως μέρος ενός διαλόγου με τη σύγχρονη δραματουργία.
-ο ρόλος και η θέση  του ερευνητικού  θεάτρου στην σύγχρονη ελληνική πραγματικότητα.
- η αλληλεπίδραση και η συνδιαλλαγή με το ευρύτερο περιβάλλον της διεθνούς σκηνής.
About us
Omada7 is a performing arts group founded in 2003. The group does not own a permanent work space and has never been subsidized by Greek Ministry of Culture or other public funders. It has produced twenty-two productions so far, involving at least 15 artists and volunteers each time.Omada7 aims at investigating the cultural particularities of Greece in dialogue with the forms and methods of post-modern theatre.
Άλλοι τρόποι για να βοηθήσεις:
Διακίνησε την καμπάνια όπου και σε όσους μπορείς.

story:
Le Grand Voyage

Cast: Ronit Asheri-Sandler, Dimitri Koan, Tatyana Kot, Sergey Nagorny,  Ruta Pauliukaityte, Alex Ryaboy, Noam Sandler, Anya Zicer

Directed by Aelita West

 

About the project

A couple of years ago I was given a birthday gift in a form of a Theatrical Clown class.  I was intrigued.  This class took me on an incredible journey into the world of ridiculousness,  pleasure, wonder, and vulnerability.  I ended up in Paris studying with the incredible Philippe Gaulier, where the idea for this project was born.  

Throughout our lives we all go through various journeys and transformations, literal and figurative.  Each of these present various obstacles, challenges, rewards and more journeys.  Clowns are simpletons, naive childlike versions of ourselves. They don't speak, don't know much, though sometimes think they do.  They're always faced with a dilemma but never phased by one. An immigrant is someone armed only with hope, someone who's ripped out of their life and stuck in a new country, city, culture, and in the process unwillingly becomes a clown.  We suspect everyone ends up in that situation at some point as we're all a bit of immigrants and clowns.  Hence we believe clowning is the perfect vehicle to tell this story. When it became unbearable to sit still on the idea, I invited fellow actors and clowns to celebrate, investigate and experiment together. 

We have an amazing team headed by Aelita West who's no stranger to clowning, and has been performing in the acclaimed Slava's Snowshow for the last 18 years, and has also worked as an actor in Young Spectator's Theater in Moscow.  

We are now in the midst of the creation of the production which is set to premiere in February 2020 in New York!!!

 

What We Need 

Putting up a full theater production is kind of a big endeavor, and we need all the help we could get.  You can play an instrumental part in making this a truly professional production.  Theater, costumes, stage design & set, light and all that is theater magic entails a lot of effort and resources.  You can hop along on this ride with us by helping sponsor this project!

 

The Impact

Our goal is to create a dialogue, an encounter with our audience no matter where they stand in their journey, and explore together. Explore the relationship between the past and the present, explore the relationship of them back then and now. And the language we propose is - clowning.  Because what is a better way to answer some key identity exploratory questions? We emphasize the strength and importance of identity exploration and "knowing your story" in our work.  We hope that the mutual experience of the journey will resonate with the diverse NYC community and we invite you to become part of it. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word, buy a ticket, come see the show, and bring friends! 

 

Special Thank You

Golden Medina Films

Jonathan F Schneider & Elizabeth Rao for creating our campaign video!

Anya Zicer I Co-producing

Set Builder | Vladimir Klintchev

Alya Svecharnik

Harlem Doc Loft

The campaign video cast featuring:

Lenny Gusel

Michael Gusel

Ilya Medvinsky

Yasha Medvinsky

Alex Ryaboy

Nathan Yentin

Robinswood Bungalow Cooperative

This project is created as part of COJECO BluePrint Fellowship supported by COJECO and Genesis Philanthropy Group. 

Le Grand Voyage is a co-production with the Lost & Found project

story:
HEATWAVE

It’s August and the city is gripped by an unrelenting heatwave. Danny and Mia, an average lesbian couple think they know everything about each other. However, when Mia finds a prescription for testosterone in Danny’s jeans, it comes as a big surprise. How could she not have known Danny wants to transition? Or... did she? With the arrival of Danny’s disapproving mother and an unexpected visit from a straight co-worker, things quickly reach a boiling point. Fishbowl Theatre Collective is proud to present HEATWAVE, playing at Theatre Aquarius Studio as part of the 2018 Hamilton Fringe Festival from July 19 -29.

We are excited to bring Mia and Danny to the stage at Hamilton Fringe, but we need your help. Fringe Festivals work on profit sharing, which means all box office return is split among team members. But just to get the show to you, we have to cover the Fringe entry fee ($675), the cost of rehearsal space ($350), print and promotional materials ($275) and transportation for our actors ($200). We know times are tough and giving isn't easy, especially with so many other worthy projects asking for your attention. We want to offer you something to acknowledge our gratitude for your support.  When you donate to this campaign, we will send you collage art created by Erika Reesor, playwright and director of HEATWAVE. We have bookmarks and greeting cards, gift tags for Christmas presents (hey, we know how quickly it sneaks up on us), and larger pieces of art.

We believe that knowing people's stories, their challenges and triumphs will lead to a better understanding; more compassion for each other. We hope that audiences, both straight and queer, will leave more curious than they were before seeing the show. Good theatre doesn't give us ready-made solutions, but provides the jumping off point for more questions. Excerpts of HEATWAVE were performed at HamilTen Festival and at Hamilton's first Pride Theatre Showcase this year. There, they were well-received by audiences and resulted in compelling discussions. We hope to carry on those conversations with folks after the show and at the Fringe Club. Theatre doesn't end when the curtain comes down, it lives in our hearts, souls and the conversations we have about it.

We hope you are able to help, but we know not everyone can. Even if you can't donate, please consider helping us by spreading the word about our show. Talk to your friends and co-workers about it, tell them why you believe this is a project worth supporting. Sharing our campaign and updates about the show helps tremendously and we appreciate all of your support!

story:
Help Banana Bag & Bodice present the long-awaited, highly anticipated World Premiere of our super sci-fi  SPACE//SPACE at Williamsburg's finest venue...The Collapsable Hole.

We need $3000 to get there and your donation will help pay the rent on the theatre. And put a space ship on a space stage. And funny costumes on our bodies. And emergency sandwiches in the mouths of these folks!

R. Black, Peter Blomquist, Zbigniew Bzymek, Mallory Catlett, Enver Chakartash, Jason Craig, Sandra Garner, Miranda Hardy, Jessica Jelliffe, Denise Lum, Dave Malloy, Paul Piekarz, Brandon Walcott


SPACE//SPACE
JUNE 8th - JULY 1st
THE COLLAPSABLE HOLE, Brooklyn NYC


We have been building this show for 3 years!
Now is the time!

And thank you, we much appreciate your kind generosity, this show can not happen without you!!

story:
Here's The Scoop:

My name is Thom. I am an emerging choreographer based out of the Midwest. I have choreographed some on Milwaukee Ballet's Studio Company and am represented by DManagement Dance Agency as a Choreographer. I am also the director of the summer-based Milwaukee Dance Company, NomadicLIMBS.

I have recently been accepted to the 15th Annual Dance Under The Stars Choreography Festival in Palm Desert, California. I competed against over 100 applicants for a spot at the festival, and am now in the running to win the grand prize for my work, "To Venture from the Norm." I am competing in the Division II category with two members of Milwaukee Ballet's Studio Company, and, while I am extremely excited to expand my choreographic career, my dancers and I need money to get there.

What We Need & What You Get

My dancers and I need three round-trip tickets to Palm Desert, as well as money for three days worth of lodging and food while we are there. The grand total is around $1000.

If 50 people commit just $20 to this campaign, I can send my choreography to california. In return, I would like to show donors YouTube videos of our progess, as well as videos of my group's adventures in california. This is a really exciting venture and I would love the chance to share it with you.

A Little Help Goes A Long Way:

I've done an Indiegogo campaign in the past for my company, NomadicLIMBS, that had good success. If I win the prize of $2000, this is money that will be put toward NomadicLIMBS having a second season in Milwaukee. If you didn't get a chance to see the company last summer, read about us (and our amazing articles in the Gazette and Express) on our website: www.nomadiclimbs.com
 
 

If You Want To Help, But Are Short On Funds:

I get it. I'm not made of money either, hence the campaign...but I would love the support. If you know people that have a passion for dance then PLEASE pass this campaign along to them. If nothing else, this is a great chance to show california the quality of dance present in the Midwest. :)

story:
Our Story

Help us fund the world premiere production of christopher oscar peña's i wonder if it's possible to have a love affair that lasts forever? or things i found on craigslist, performing as a part of the Dream Up Festival 2011 at Theatre for a New City August 28th through September 4th.  

As epic as your first kiss and a personal as a Facebook poke, ...things i found on craigslist is The Big Chill for the millennials. Still searching for perfection, a sense of purpose, and their high school crushes on Facebook, a group of 20-somethings still caught up in yesterday wake up to find themselves tripped up by their own faith. In the face of a ten-year high school reunion, the group are forced to confront their crippling insecurities and emotional baggage. Secrets are shared and people are "no longer in a relationship" as the personal becomes public in this gripping, witty insight into making it all work in web 2.0. 

...things i found on craigslist is directed by Mary Birnbaum (Founder of art.party.theatre), music and lyrics by Melissa Lusk (Boy Girl Party), set by Daniel Zimmerman, lights by Anshuman Bhatia.  

Cast includes Julia Arazi, Hannah Cabell (Compulsion), Leigh Dunham, Sofia Gomez (Angels in America), Michael Micalizzi, Topher Mikels, Dominic Spillane, Stephen Stout and Dax Valdez.   


The Impact

We're using our slot as a part of Dream Up to help try and find a home for ...things i found on craigslist at a larger theatre.  Our needs are modest, our production sleek and slim, and even a small display of support could go a long way towards making our aspirations a reality.  Basically, we're doing a mad dash to the finish line and your generosity (even small gifts make a huge difference) would be deeply appreciated. 


What We Need & What You Get

In the next few weeks we need to raise $2,000 in order to pay for our festival fees, build our set, get our costumes, lighting and pay our hugely awesome and understanding stage manager.  


If you support ...things i found on craigslist, you can receive free tickets to our show as well as original poetry by the playwright, a spectacular dinner party, and you might even get name checked in the play itself! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spreading the good word!

story:
The Project

This December, Kucheza Ngoma Dance Company will be collaborating with award-winning playwright, Thomas Melonçon, to produce “Our Feet Can Tell a Story As We Celebrate The Legacy”. Combining a range of dance styles from traditional West African dance to Hip Hop, this show chronicles the saga of African-American history. Kucheza Ngoma was personally selected by Mr. Melonçon to produce this show. We are honored that our dance company has such an amazing opportunity to tell this story because producing “Our Feet Can Tell a Story…” is in line with Kucheza Ngoma’s mission to reach the youth of our community through dance.

Formally established in 2008, Kucheza Ngoma Dance Company has been dedicated to helping at-risk youth deal with issues of health and self-esteem by offering free dance classes as well as health seminars. Our wholistic approach deals with developing the minds and bodies of young people. We’ve had a tremendous impact on the young people that we’ve worked with. Producing this show will add another dimension to our work in the community.

We have a large fundraising goal for producing “Our Feet Can Tell a Story…”. The expected total cost is $7,600. I would greatly appreciate your help in reaching this target. Your gift of sponsorship is tax-deductable through our fiscal sponsor Fractured Atlas and will help cover the cost of costumes, theater rental, and marketing, among other things.

Thomas Melonçon

Thomas Melonçon has served as an Adjunct Professor in the Department of Communications, and recently taught in the Fine Arts Department of Texas Southern University. He also served as Resident Playwright at the High School for the Performing and Visual Arts from 1989 through 2002. He is the playwright of the award winning play, Diary of Black Men which is the longest running touring play in the history of black theatre. Eventhough this production was clearly set apart in terms of substance from other "urban" plays, it clearly is the pioneer of what is now called Urban Theater, setting the stage for the likes of Shelly Garrett, David E. Talbert and even Tyler Perry.


Listen to an interview with Mr. Melonçon: http://www.blogtalkradio.com/letsbefrank/2009/08/04/lets-be-frank-interview-with-playwright-thomas-meloncon



Our Budget

Theater Rental……………….$1300
Thomas Maloncon…………...$400
Practice rental………………..$2000
Drummers…………………....$400
Costumes/Props…………….$2500
Light Tech……………………$300
Food/Drinks………………….$300
Flyers/Promotion………..…..$400

 

TOTAL………………………$7600

About KNDC

KNDC has been established since 2008, a vital asset to the Houston community as a gateway for young girls and boys to express their creativity through a variety of dance styles: hip-hop, tap, modern, West Indian (Caribbean) folk dance, and traditional West Afrakan dance. Since obesity is a growing problem in Houston and many places in America, we also encourage our students to maintain healthy diets and to choose fruits and vegetables and drinking plenty of water. Since children learn by example our instructors are all vegan.


Artistic Directors

Zinnijah Guadalupe is Kucheza Ngoma’s 26 years young artistic director.  She began dancing when she was 3 years old and she learned by attending dance classes and rehearsals with her mother Ruth.  At a young age, she knew she wanted to have her own dance company and help people explore the world through dance.


Leora Guadalupe is Kucheza Ngoma’s 22 years young assistant artistic director who has been dancing since she was 3.  She loves to perform modern and West African dance.  Leora dances because it makes her feel free.  Leora would like to use her dance knowledge to teach others and spread dance around the world.


Hannjah Guadalupe is 21 years young and is Kucheza Ngoma’s assistant artistic director. She has been dancing since she was 3. She enjoys dancing hip-hop most of all because it makes her feel free. She looks up to her older sister Zinnijah as her inspiration and plans to contribute to the expansion of the dance company. She also likes to play sports and is an animal whisperer.


We seek to preserve our Afrakan culture through dance.

Any donation amount is greatly appreciated!! Thank you!
story_txt:
The Project
This December, Kucheza Ngoma Dance Company will be collaborating with award-winning playwright, Thomas Melonçon, to produce “Our Feet Can Tell a Story As We Celebrate The Legacy”. Combining a range of dance styles from traditional West African dance to Hip Hop, this show chronicles the saga of African-American history. Kucheza Ngoma was personally selected by Mr. Melonçon to produce this show. We are honored that our dance company has such an amazing opportunity to tell this story because producing “Our Feet Can Tell a Story…” is in line with Kucheza Ngoma’s mission to reach the youth of our community through dance.

Formally established in 2008, Kucheza Ngoma Dance Company has been dedicated to helping at-risk youth deal with issues of health and self-esteem by offering free dance classes as well as health seminars. Our wholistic approach deals with developing the minds and bodies of young people. We’ve had a tremendous impact on the young people that we’ve worked with. Producing this show will add another dimension to our work in the community.

We have a large fundraising goal for producing “Our Feet Can Tell a Story…”. The expected total cost is $7,600. I would greatly appreciate your help in reaching this target. Your gift of sponsorship is tax-deductable through our fiscal sponsor Fractured Atlas and will help cover the cost of costumes, theater rental, and marketing, among other things.

story:
THE GOAL

We're raising completion funds for ETERNIDAY, a world premiere dance/theater piece by WR and Chuck Mee. We’re not starting from scratch – we’ve been working hard to earn the money to pay for this show. Teaching workshops in Australia, Norway, and Colorado, performing at NYC Summer Stage, and Dan choreographs shows outside the company (including Stravinsky’s Rite of Spring for the Philadelphia Orchestra with Ridge Theater). Through all of these gigs, money is put aside for future projects. As always happens, the future becomes the present, and that is now, and we’re asking for your help with the final stretch. We're $5000 short of our total budget.
 
Sets, costumes, and lights all cost money, and, of utmost importance, performers and designers need to get paid a decent wage for their hard work! Love and devotion don’t cover the rent when you’re in rehearsal, or painting a wall, or editing a video, or building a sound cue, or devising a dance.
 
We have performed our work in venues ranging from the Théâtre National de Chaillot in Paris, to the National Opera House in Cluj, Romania, to New York City Summer Stage, to the Bushwick Starr, deep in the heart of Brooklyn. The venues have ranged from very grand halls with marble staircases to raw spaces lovingly held together by duct tape. No matter where, no matter what, we give everything we have to make amazing work that will thrill you.
 
Anything you can give (really, we mean it, ANYTHING) will help bring this exciting new show to life. If you have been inspired, delighted, provoked, confounded, or moved by a Witness Relocation production, we are asking you to donate at this time. If you would like to be inspired, delighted, provoked, confounded or moved by ETERNIDAY in April at La Mama, we are asking you to donate at this time. We try to make truly incredible shows, and we’re asking for your help.

WHO WE ARE

Witness Relocation formed in 2000 and is led by director/choreographer Dan Safer. The company is ensemble based and makes shows ranging from fully scripted plays to original, devised dance/theater pieces to many things in between.

Based in New York City, we have been recognized as one of the “ensembles who now lead the city’s progressive theater scene” (Village Voice), and are the recipients of three New York Innovative Theater Awards.

We perform frequently in dance and theater venues in the US and internationally. In NYC and across the US, these include La MaMa, Dance New Amsterdam, The Ontological, NYC Summer Stage, Dixon Place, CATCH!, CSV, The Ohio Theater, Dancespace Project, Solar One, American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, MA, Fuse Box in Austin, TX, Bumbershoot in Seattle, WA, Revolutions in Albequerque, NM, Fury Factory in San Francisco, CA, and Out of Hand in Atlanta, GA.

Internationally, we've done our shows in France at Theatre de Chaillot, Paris, Les Subsistances, Lyon, and Le Quartz, Brest; in Poland at the Manggha Museum, Krakow and the Silesian Dance Theater Festival, Bytom; in Russia at the Open Look Festival, St. Petersburg; in Romania at Man.in.Fest, Cluj-Napoca; in Canada at the Dancing On The Edge Festival in Vancouver, BC; and in Thailand at Patravadi Theater, Bangkok.

WHAT WE'RE RAISING MONEY FOR

“Eterniday”, a new evening-length dance and theater piece, is the second show in our ongoing collaboration with award winning writer Chuck Mee, premiering in April at the legendary La MaMa Theater in NYC, where Witness Relocation is proud to be a resident company. “Eterniday” is about all of human history happening in a 24 hour period, the random nature of life, and how amazing it is to fall in love. Our incredible company members – Nikki Calonge, Sean Donovan, Mike Mikos, Wil Petre  – will be joined by Kate Lee (all the way from Australia!), Javier Perez, Vanessa Koppel, and the inimitable Saori Tsukada, as well as acclaimed actor/director/writer Carey Harrison on film. We also have amazing designers on board – sets & lights by Jay Ryan, original songs by Dave Malloy, projections by Kaz Phillips-Safer, sound design by Michael De Angelis, costumes & props by Deb O, co-choreography by Sam Pinkleton, dramaturgy by David McGee, assistant direction by Ben Gullard, and direction and choreography by Dan Safer. We’re going all out on this one – caveman costumes, original films, intimate duets and huge dance numbers, and a beautiful, funny, epic, poetic script by Chuck.

story:
The Senior Dance Company

The Dance Studio established the Senior Dance Company in 2007 for students who have a passion for dance and performing. Students must audition each year to be a member and get to participate in many performance opportunities in addition to the annual recital. This year we have 17 dancers on our Senior Company ranging in age from 10-16.

Why are we fundraising?

Our Senior Dance Company has been invited to perform at the Walt Disney World Resort in Downtown Disney this April! Travel expenses and Costume costs are very expensive so we are trying to raise as much money as we can so all of our dancers can participate in this AMAZING opportunity! Fundraising also helps cover costs of other performances during the year and convention costs for our students.

Your Impact

I always tell our dancers...every little bit helps! Thank you so much for helping us get one step closer to our goals! :)

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't forget to spread the word about The Senior Dance Company and share the link with family and friends!

story:
Help Out the Ladies of MissTaken Crew!

Hello everyone we are MissTaken crew! A group of seven young ladies who are infatuated with hip-hop dance. we come from a very small dance community in Fort Lauderdale, Florida. & we're out to prove it to the world that even though we dont exist to many of you out there, we ARE here and pack a powerful punch! We're trying to raise money to compete in this years Hip-Hop international Las vegas! The BIGGEST hip hop competition of the year where crews come from all over the globe come to face off & bring their artistry to the stage. Our crew is grounded, humble, and hungry to show the dance scene what were made of. Help our dreams come true!... pleasssssseeeee donate and help us achieve our goal! If you want to hear more about MissTaken:

videos: www.youtube.com/Misstakencrew

or www.facebook.com/Misstakencrew  

 

****ANYTHING HELPS!!!! $5.. $10... Whatever you wanna donate :)

 

What We Need 

This goal will cover Flights for each of the girls, hotel for three days of the event and registration fees. If you want to know more about the competition you can click on the link below:

www.hiphopinternational.com 

We will also definitely post the footage and pictures from the event on our website and even film a mini video of back stage experience and practices so you guys could see all the hard work and hours we've put in.

&& Please SHARE, SHARE, SHARE, this page. Need all the support we could get :)

 

Members

Brittany Anuez,

Danielle Rodas,

Jaidi "Rogue" Ventura,

Michelle Griffith,

Megan Batoon,

Samantha Lugo.

story:
Setting forth the strategic of my own campaign in Indiegogo, basic questions must be answered:


Who I am - What I want - What my goal is

Eventually, I think that is not easy at all to answer in such questions!
But let’s start from the beginning, or almost from the beginning!


Who I am

My name is Stella Serefoglou and I live in Athens for the last 15 years.  Since 2001 when I started my studies in directing, I work hard trying to improve my abilities in the field.

Producers’ assistant, second assistant director, continuity girl, first assistant director and, for the last 15 months, director. 

When my second child was born in 2008, my life changed course. I started writing children stories and theatrical plays. I attended seminars and courses on drama in education and started teaching theatre games to preschool kids.

My play "My mum's great hug" is an attempt to answer on questions regarding the power of love, acceptance and unconditional support.

This is parents' primary objective for me: holding their children into their lap, giving them all their love in order to make them strong and ready to face the world.

My mum's great hug" is a story about a young mother and her 2 years old child being attached to her lap. Actually, it's a story about the power of the lap.


How it all started

As I’ve already told you, I’m a mother of two and an artist. My life changed when in our neighborhood moved in Daphne, a young and talented actress. She is a mother as well, so we had a lot in common! Almost immediately, I spoke to her about the show I had in mind.

After I talked to her about the style and the techniques I was planning to use, I found the rest of the collaborators –a whole different chapter I will unfold some other time- and we started rehearsals.

In this phase we are right now, we are rehearsing –in the studio or at our places, sometimes with our children! As I already told you…we won’t back down! 

 

Style, technique, impact

Our play is inspired by the era of the silent movies and the films of Marx Brothers, Jerry Lewis and Jacques Tati. The action is mute and mimetic. Sound is produced by the actors' body movements, tap dancing and scat singing. Movement and flow is based on precision and rhythm.

The show is targeted to audiences of all ages. It's a theatrical play that parents and kids will definetely love! It's full of tenderness, humor, love.

It's something that goes straight to the heart and soul!

 

Our campaign's scope

We expect to collect enough money to fulfill the production's basic requirements. The truth is, funding of art projects in Greece has always fallen short of generous and daring initiative. Current events in our country’s economy make things even harder for everyone.

It's virtually impossible for young, creative artists to find enough resources to reach their goals. And yes, we believe that it is very important, even more so in our times, to be able to ensure support for artistic expression of any kind.


When will it go up?

The show is scheduled to go up in October 2012 at the Michalis Kakoyannis Foundation in Athens.

 

How you can help

In this point, the easy part ends and the hard part begins…It’s called reality!

As you might know, in Greece it has always been difficult to ensure financing to make a short film or a full length movie, even to stage a performance.

So, we need some money in order to materialize our beautiful idea. We really need 15.000 dollars to cover the needs of our play, in order to pay every professional involved in the  project. 

Deducting the money I would need in order to pay all my collaborators (actors, assistant director, lighter, art director, producer, teacher for the puppet) -who for the time being are helping me gratuitously-, deducting costs for transfers, cell phones and studio rental,  I set my campaigns’ goal to 5000 dollars.

In detail:

  • $1000 for making the puppet
  • $2000 for props and costume
  • $1000 for the choreographer
  • $1000 for the musicians

What do you think? Are you going to help so “My Mum’s Great Hug” becomes reality?

I’ve put my heart and soul in this project, and the same goes for my collaborators who work for me with high spirits and devotion.

I thank you so much for your time and attention.

Please share with others!

story:
Welcome to our fundraising campaign!

We are the Burning Circle Company, a multi-media performance arts group that combines numerous disciplines and art forms to create stunning audience experiences!

The four members of the company are performers, creators, and leaders that have trained with premiere theatre, film and music professionals from around the world. Our debut project, Walkmann, is a creation that viciously explores communication technology and the human soul.

Why we need your help!

We need $5000 to help share our debut project with the world and to help take it back to Vancouver where it all started! Burning Circle Company has researched and work-shopped our project for over a year and now invites our strongest supporters to help us reach our goal. In exchange for your generous support we’re offering lots of cool perks including handmade postcards, downloadable original music, recorded radio plays performed by our company, and of course, tickets to our performance!

Why Burning Circle?

Our show, Walkmann, features the talents of amazing young creators that strive to produce exciting and inspiring work. Our shows are dedicated to exploring social issues and creating an audience experience that inspires questioning of the world we live in. Your contribution will ensure the success of our first performance and also invest in the future performance in Vancouver!

To all of our supporters helping us make this possible we thank you!

Please help us spread the word through Facebook, Twitter, E-Mail, Texting, PhoneCalls, Word of Mouth, Smoke Signals or any other way you can get our campaign to the world!

Please help us spread the word through Facebook, Twitter, E-Mail, Texting, PhoneCalls, Word of Mouth, Smoke Signals or any other way you can get our campaign to the world!

story:
Danse Elargie: dance event in Theatre de la Ville, Paris.

OS 351 is a dance collective of seven contemporary dancers, who met and graduated at SEAD (Salzburg Experimental Academy of Dance) in Salzburg, Austria. We are choosen to be part of Danse Elargie, the 3rd Edition of this dance event organized by the Théatre de la Ville in Paris. We're part of the 20 pieces they have selected amongst 320 projects representing 37 countries!

It's a precious and unique opportunity to perform there, help us make it happen!

Collective members

Daniela Faria (Portugal)
Francesca Perrucci (Italy)
Nahee Lee (South Korea)
Louise Everarts de Velp (Belgium)
Luan De Lima (Brazil)
Evandro Pedroni (Brazil)
Sander Deben (Belgium)

www.danse-elargie.com

www.OS351.com

We need your support! 

The venue doesn't cover travelling and accommodation costs, the money raised will be used for these two purposes.
We thank you already for your generous support, and this is what we offer you for contributing to this exiting event:                                      

  • Donation €10 (Not limited)
    Thank you on Facebook and webpage

  • Donation €20 (Not limited)
    Thank you + Postcard from Paris with a special dedicatory

  • Donation €30 (Not limited)
    Thank you + Pin OS351 + Postcard from Paris with a special dedicatory

  • Donation €50 (Limited to 10 persons)
    Thank you + T-shirt OS351


  • Donation €75 (Limited to 10 persons)
    Thank you + Poster with a special dedicatory

  • Donation 150€ (Limited to 10 persons)
    Every item above


You can also support us by checking our website, sharing, liking us on Facebook, or even coming to see the performance in Paris. ;)

It's a great opportunity for us to perform, be seen, make contacts, and take the collective one step further!

story:
Being/with others...

is a collaborative and interdisciplinary dance/theatre work which explores the experiences and connections between a group of people of various identities. This project provides a space for emerging artists of various disciplines to develop contemporary and avant-garde performance works inspired by the body, memory, and experience while also touching larger issues of gender, race, ethnicity, sexuality, and ability. These individual performance works are then combined and structured together to create a evening-length show which highlights the intersections between the different artists and their work. 

                                                                              

The project will make its work-in-progress debut as part of the University of Texas at Austin Spring Lab Theater Series on April 11th, 12th, and 13th. 

Movement...Choreography...Spoken word…Video Projection…Visual Theatre Art

By using various mediums, the performers have freedom to express themselves in the ways most appropriate to their stories and experiences, as well as adding texture and depth to the aesthetic of the entire show. 

Being/with others challenges the conventional theatre structure by intertwining and combining performances, bringing two contrasting or complimenting performances together and leaving behind the memory of certain moments to inspire the next. All of the performances exist and breathe together though they may occur at different points in the show. 


What would otherwise be considered a conventional proscenium stage is transformed into an all immersive and encompassing experience. Performances  will not only happen on stage but will also occur outside of the theater in the courtyard, in the lobby as if it were a museum gallery, and travel in and out the audience. Thus the audience is fully involved and present in the performance space, and not outside of it looking in.  

The artists

Being/with others involves ten performers: Negin Raoof, Jossina Mark, Tanya Winters, Sara Madandar, Morgan Taylor, Mackenzie Taylor, Susie Angel, Brittany Reeber, Kelsey Rondeau, and Lucy Kerr. Excerpts of the show includes Rondeau’s expositions of the vulnerabilities of being a femme gay man and also a drag artist, Madandar’s embodiments of the tensions of being “in between” Iran and the U.S. and the reappearing memories of religion and society, Mark’s retelling and reframing of black women in history, and Angel’s expression of the social challenges and hypervisibilities that are felt when having cerebral palsy, such as not having an ADA accessible stage to perform on. Lighting designer Gavin Cantrell will be lighting the performances from the outside to the lobby to the audience to the stage in order to create a robust performance world. Projection Designer Daniel Berkowitz will create dynamic projections which submerge the artists in colorful imagery. 


From the director, Lucy Kerr:

"As the director and dramaturge, I am committed to maintaining a cohesive aesthetic throughout the entire show which will provide substantial core that supports the diversity of performances and mediums. Thus the performances both suspend familiar beliefs about what what is considered theater while also being accessible to the audience in a visceral, powerful, and tangible way."

What we need

In order to create this ambitious and complex performance we need the funds to provide artists with the props, materials, and costumes, as well as to have a dependable team of sound and lighting designers, projection and video designers, stage managers and prop/costume assistants. It is important for us to be able to pay these designers and managers as they are working artists in Austin, TX and they are taking their time to be involved with this project because they are passionate about it.

This project is important because it speaks to the experiences of diverse artists and encourages collaboration and the act of sharing, connecting, and recognizing our intersections. It provides a safe place for risk taking and an opportunity to create new and experimental work in a vulnerable and honest way. This show also ties into ongoing discussions based on race, gender, sexuality, and ability, and thus it contributes to the journey for change and supports other UT students in this journey. Please help us pursue these goals!

story:
***PLEASE WATCH THE VIDEO ABOVE TO FIND OUT MORE***

Contacting the World is a young people's international theatre festival taking place this July in Manchester,UK. We need your help with food, travel, accomodation & festival costs for 100 young artists taking part from Nigeria, Thailand, Trinidad & Tobago, and the UK.

The 100 performers are with us for one week (7 days) so how will your money help? Here are a few examples...

  • $10 (£6.29) will cover the costs of one evening meal or 2 breakfasts 
  • $70 (£43) covers the cost of evening meals for one person or breakfasts for two people for a week.
  • $20 (£12.58) will cover the costs of 4 breakfasts or 3 lunches or 2 evening meals or one weekly travel ticket.
  • $35 (£21.98) will cover the costs of one night accomodation plus one evening meal
  • $245 (£152) will cover 7 nights accomodation and evening meals
Please give as much or as little as you can - every little helps.

***********************************************

Testimonials from Donors to the Campaign so far...

ES: "I can’t wait for July! Please donate to support this inspiring, life-changing festival!"

AlbinoMosquito: "A remarkable project well worth supporting"

John & Rosemary: "Such a worthwhile project deserves all the support it can get."

Alison Jeffers: "Contacting the World is a unique and important event."

Helen Jenkins: "Great project, worthy of support."

K: "Noel would be so thrilled that CTW is continuing – he always cherished the energy and imagination of young people and their ability to change the world. Now more than ever we need to support young people’s creativity and create the opportunities for their powerful and diverse voices to be heard. Please support this really fantastic event and thanks to everyone who is busy making it happen. Looking forward to seeing the work."

Monste: " this is such an amazingly rich experience for young people."

Read more at: http://www.indiegogo.com/CTW2012?c=comments&a=510890

*******************************************************

A Message From Contact Young Actors Company

We’re Contact Young Actors Company (CYAC) from Manchester, UK.

This summer we’re hosting a brilliant international festival called Contacting The World that brings together young people from around the world for an amazing week of exchange and performance. 

Taking place from 9 - 15 July, the festival will be held here, in Manchester, with companies from Thailand, Nigeria, Trinidad and Tobago and the UK. We want to put on a fantastic festival to welcome them. To do that we need your help.

This is the first time that we've been involved in Contacting The World. We've heard loads of stories from young people who've taken part before about how much they learnt, the people they met and how it really changed their lives. Have a watch of our video to see what people who've been involved with the festival before have to say about it.

This will be a once in a life-time experience for us. Please help us share it with as many people as possible and put on a festival that Manchester can be proud of!

We are not only raising money for our show but to make sure we can give our guests from around the world all the support they need to stage their shows and have a great experience in Manchester. We are working hard with Contact to make this possible!

Sara and Steve (who you see in the video) are great examples of how this festival lives on. They are previous participants of CTW who are now supporting us as project managers and the creative team.

In return for your donation you can have us come and perform a show in your back garden if you like! Or just simply get your name and photo on our website. Check out our range of perks on the right...

We really appreciate all your help.

Thank you!

CYAC

x

The Impact

In the last 10 years Contacting the World has enriched the lives of more than 1000 young people from 57 youth theatre companies in 30 different countries.

Over eight months, young people from countries across the world collaborate online, learning and sharing with each other to create new shows which are then performed during the festival week. The festival provides an international platform and profile for theatre made by young people around the world.

The impact this festival has on its participants is huge.  For some, it's the first time they've ever left their country, so Manchester is their first experience of the rest of the world.  It helps young people build confidence; learn new skills, grow as artists and understand what it means to be a global citizen. It creates lifelong friendships and professional relationships; and promotes mutual understanding and respect between young people from different backgrounds, helping them to have a broader view of the world and how they can make a difference within it.

What We Need & What You Get

By donating to Contacting the World you will help cover the costs of accomodation, travel and food for the 100 performers, contribute to the production costs of the festival and pay for the development of CYAC's show including the creation of sets and costumes.

You can donate as little as $10 (That’s only about £6.29!) to become an Accomplice and see your name on our website, or as much as $1750 to become a Director and receive a bespoke workshop experience from our  Artistic Director, Baba Israel…

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about our campaign via Twitter, Facebook, our website (via the links below) and telling all your friends and family!

You can also buy a ticket for the shows via 0161 274 0600 or via the links below:

CYAC (UK) & Arts-in-Action Wordsmiths (Trinidad & Tobago) 
Yard Youth Theatre (UK) & Moradokmai Theatre Community (Thailand) 
Boundless Productions (UK) & Crown Troupe of Africa (Nigeria)

Difficulty donating?

Some people have reported difficulties with being able to donate - please text CMCR12 and the amount you want to give to 70070. So the text should read 'CMCR12 £10' (or whatever amount you can spare!)

Any problems donating ring 0161 274 0612 or email judepratt@contactmcr.com.
