story:
What is this "Mr. Buttermen" thingy?

Join the class of the beloved Mr. Buttermen (a wonderfully disturbed man that lives in the park) as he leads us on a journey of learning. His Fables teach us the importance of being a moral adult in the modern world with classic stories such as Petey the Impotent Rabbit, The Girl Who Cried Rape and The Tortoise and the Gin. Don't miss the opportunity to once again giggle as a school child. (Note: Peeing your pants in the auditorium is frowned upon.)


Ok... But what the hell is it?

A multi arts performance of original fables for adults from Mind The Art's poetry book by the same title, the show is a fusion of art forms and includes work by Mind The Art's Poetry, Acting, Playwriting, Visual Arts, Music, Musical Theater and Production divisions.

It is to be directed by Christian De Gré, Artistic Director of Mind The Art Entertainment, and will feature resident artists of Mind The Art including some of the original poets.

 

Yo, why do you need my money?

Mind The Art Entertainment has announced that they will be re-launching their acclaimed La Mama E.T.C. and Center Stage NY production of Story Time With Mr. Buttermen, a part of their La MaMa E.TC. Presents: A Mind The Art Anthology, at this year's New York International Fringe Festival.

The show was a big hit in 2010 and features writing by Jake Holmes, Christian De Gre, Ariana Paganetti, Joe Kurtz, Lauren Brady, David Williams and Joseph Reese. All very talented (yet somewhat disturbed) poets.

 

Soooo....what are you going to do with my hard-earned dollars?

We are keeping it simple. We only need $900 to get this show up. Most of the funding will go to our participation fee for this year's festival and to cover our basic tech fees.

 

And what do I get? Surely I get something in return...

We are glad to know that you are as greedy as our beloved Solomon Finch. We planned accordingly, so take a look on the right at all our perks. Now feel free to donate and swim in the riches of your rewards. :-)

 

Thanks so much and don't forget to check out the show this summer!

--Mind The Art Entertainment

story:
Please Help Send My Sister To Convention!


Hi. My name is Kaeley. The reason I am starting this campaign is because I am trying to raise money to help send my sister to a Zumba convention this year. She has been through so much this past year, yet never lost her faith in God and never stopped being the amazing woman she is. I will share with you a little about her and also what the Zumba convention is, in case you don't know.


About My Sister:
Hope is originally from our hometown, Lafayette, Louisiana. In high school, she got saved and gave her life to Christ. She attended a Bible college called Master's Commission at our church. Shortly after that she moved to Houston to continue to serve God and follow Him where ever He led her. She was living her life for Him daily but knew she was made for more. She raised money and went on a mission trip to Waco, Texas where she lived with the homeless for a weekend. She immediately fell in love with the people and the place. She returned back to Houston and told God if He wants her to move to Waco then that's what will be. Well, just that thing happened. God called her to Waco, and not only did she fall in love with the city but she also met the love of her life, (now her husband) there! They both were so passionate about Christ and helping the less fortunate they immediately fell in love. Not long after, they got married only to find out their world was about to DRAMATICALLY change. They got approved to finance a home of their own in a part of town that is predominately poor and needs a lot of help.They were living out their dreams. Unfortunately, just a few months after ICE agents came knocking at their door taking away her precious husband, with no explanation. Her husband is a native of Singapore. He has been in America since childhood but as a young boy trying to fit in got into trouble. Well,  to explain it more shortly, when he did get into trouble it revoked his green card but no one told him. He went to rehab, willingly gave his life to Christ and became a completely different man. Five years later after his life was totally changed, they decided that it had fell through the cracks and now he needed to be deported. 11 long excruciating months for my sister, who was at Baylor University for Social Work and only doing Zumba classes for income, was now alone, with a note on a brand new home and her best friend and soul mate gone, but yet she never ever gave up on God, her husband, or the people in her community. She made t-shirts, bracelets, went to every court hearing, traveled hours every weekend just to see him through a glass, had rallies, spoke to every DA and lawyer, the list is endless. By God's grace, he was released and everything was dropped because lack of evidence. During that whole year, she never had time for herself but never once complained about it. She now is part of the DREAM ACT alliance and is using all of the information she received while Naz was detained to try to help others facing the same situations. You can actually read the whole story at www.freenaz.com Her passion is children and every helpless person in this world. Pretty much God and all of His people and His world. She gives so freely of herself without ever expecting anything in return. She allowed myself and my son to come live with her and her husband after him just getting released just a few months before. She inspired me and reminded me of God's love and grace and completely helped me restore my life. I cant even begin to explain what an loving, caring, passionate and just beautiful woman she is, inside and out. I know one thing for sure, God looks upon her with delight!


In Conclusion:
If you took the time to read all of this. THANK YOU. If not, to get right to the point. My campaign is to try and help send my sister Hope to Zumba convention. Convention is a place where thousands of Zumba instructors come together and have tons of classes and so much informational material and also the creator of Zumba is present! It is  quite pricey and of course she doesn't have the funds for it. I just really think someone who gives so much of herself deserves one weekend doing something she loves. She is a Zumba instructor and does about 4 classes a day. She has helped so many women feel better about themselves and truly loves her job. I would be so thankful if you could please help me give her this gift that she would appreciate so much.

 
WHAT WE NEED:
So: Im trying to raise atleast $2,000. The convention itself is $500.00. Then theres flight costs, food, and hotel and fees for the site. If we dont raise our entire goal atleast it is that much closer to helping her out. I plan to do carwashes and whatever else it takes. :)
 
I just feel that God has called me to help give her a gift that she so much deserves. She never spends money on herself but often does on helping others. Charities etc. Not to mention the living costs of myself and my son living in her home.

 Ways You Can Help

Any amount helps, and we would appreciate it so much. If you cant contribute can you please atleast help get the word out for us? We dont have much time. She wasnt going to say anything about convention because she never thought she would be able to go. When I saw her watching the video and tears coming to her eyes i knew i needed to help.

 

I myself am a single mother so although we dont have any perks or anything to offer in return, I can say that your gift will be TRULY appreciated and God will bless it in many ways. Thank you so much for your time and consideration.
story_txt:
Please Help Send My Sister To Convention!
Hi. My name is Kaeley. The reason I am starting this campaign is because I am trying to raise money to help send my sister to a Zumba convention this year. She has been through so much this past year, yet never lost her faith in God and never stopped being the amazing woman she is. I will share with you a little about her and also what the Zumba convention is, in case you don't know.
About My Sister: Hope is originally from our hometown, Lafayette, Louisiana. In high school, she got saved and gave her life to Christ. She attended a Bible college called Master's Commission at our church. Shortly after that she moved to Houston to continue to serve God and follow Him where ever He led her. She was living her life for Him daily but knew she was made for more. She raised money and went on a mission trip to Waco, Texas where she lived with the homeless for a weekend. She immediately fell in love with the people and the place. She returned back to Houston and told God if He wants her to move to Waco then that's what will be. Well, just that thing happened. God called her to Waco, and not only did she fall in love with the city but she also met the love of her life, (now her husband) there! They both were so passionate about Christ and helping the less fortunate they immediately fell in love. Not long after, they got married only to find out their world was about to DRAMATICALLY change. They got approved to finance a home of their own in a part of town that is predominately poor and needs a lot of help.They were living out their dreams. Unfortunately, just a few months after ICE agents came knocking at their door taking away her precious husband, with no explanation. Her husband is a native of Singapore. He has been in America since childhood but as a young boy trying to fit in got into trouble. Well,  to explain it more shortly, when he did get into trouble it revoked his green card but no one told him. He went to rehab, willingly gave his life to Christ and became a completely different man. Five years later after his life was totally changed, they decided that it had fell through the cracks and now he needed to be deported. 11 long excruciating months for my sister, who was at Baylor University for Social Work and only doing Zumba classes for income, was now alone, with a note on a brand new home and her best friend and soul mate gone, but yet she never ever gave up on God, her husband, or the people in her community. She made t-shirts, bracelets, went to every court hearing, traveled hours every weekend just to see him through a glass, had rallies, spoke to every DA and lawyer, the list is endless. By God's grace, he was released and everything was dropped because lack of evidence. During that whole year, she never had time for herself but never once complained about it. She now is part of the DREAM ACT alliance and is using all of the information she received while Naz was detained to try to help others facing the same situations. You can actually read the whole story at www.freenaz.com Her passion is children and every helpless person in this world. Pretty much God and all of His people and His world. She gives so freely of herself without ever expecting anything in return. She allowed myself and my son to come live with her and her husband after him just getting released just a few months before. She inspired me and reminded me of God's love and grace and completely helped me restore my life. I cant even begin to explain what an loving, caring, passionate and just beautiful woman she is, inside and out. I know one thing for sure, God looks upon her with delight!
In Conclusion:If you took the time to read all of this. THANK YOU. If not, to get right to the point. My campaign is to try and help send my sister Hope to Zumba convention. Convention is a place where thousands of Zumba instructors come together and have tons of classes and so much informational material and also the creator of Zumba is present! It is  quite pricey and of course she doesn't have the funds for it. I just really think someone who gives so much of herself deserves one weekend doing something she loves. She is a Zumba instructor and does about 4 classes a day. She has helped so many women feel better about themselves and truly loves her job. I would be so thankful if you could please help me give her this gift that she would appreciate so much.
 
WHAT WE NEED:
So: Im trying to raise atleast $2,000. The convention itself is $500.00. Then theres flight costs, food, and hotel and fees for the site. If we dont raise our entire goal atleast it is that much closer to helping her out. I plan to do carwashes and whatever else it takes. :)
 
I just feel that God has called me to help give her a gift that she so much deserves. She never spends money on herself but often does on helping others. Charities etc. Not to mention the living costs of myself and my son living in her home.
 Ways You Can Help
Any amount helps, and we would appreciate it so much. If you cant contribute can you please atleast help get the word out for us? We dont have much time. She wasnt going to say anything about convention because she never thought she would be able to go. When I saw her watching the video and tears coming to her eyes i knew i needed to help.
 
I myself am a single mother so although we dont have any perks or anything to offer in return, I can say that your gift will be TRULY appreciated and God will bless it in many ways. Thank you so much for your time and consideration.

story:
SUMMARY

Tapology, Inc. is a family based non-profit organization founded by Alfred Bruce Bradley in Flint, Michigan, as a way to inspire, educate, and provide opportunity for his students to learn and be trained by some the world's finest musicians, dancers, and historians. In 2001 the Tapology Tap Festival for Youth consisted of workshops for dance students and visiting schools, a luncheon, competition, and a concert performance featuring Savion Glover, Jimmy Slyde and Dianne Walker. The festival became an annual event featuring stage performers encompassing an age span of 90 years.  Performers included Arthur Duncan, Mable Lee, Jenni LeGon, Derick Grant, Jason Samuels, Dormeshia Sumbry Edwards, Nelida Tirado, Cartier Williams, Acia Gray, Germaine Ingram, Harold Cromer, Johnny O'Neil, Orrin Evans, Nick Rolfe, Mama Sol, and the late bassist Don Mayberry.  

     We aim to serve youth who lack resources to pay for programs that will nurture their ability to dance while promoting excellence. We believe through education and exposure, tap dancing can help youth focus, work cooperatively with others, increase a healthy lifestyle, build self esteem, cultural pride and provide opportunity for economic growth. With the help of  incredible volunteers, board members, and amazing guest artist who share their knowledge and skills with the youth and community at large, we have served over 24,000. Our vision is to continue to unite, progress, create and produce more avenues to serve more people throughout the world.




What We Need

Our goal is to raise $20,000 to help us offset some of our operational fees for programming and production cost.

Tapology Outreach Program:  
 
 Through outreach programming, partnership, and collaboration, Tapology programming  teaches tap classes and presents live performances at schools, churches, and senior citizens homes. We are currently running a program with the Academy of Flint Charter School using tap dance as way to increase math, science, and reading to children who are at risk, via incarcerated parents, behavior problem, and teen pregnancy. Because this program is expanding in the numbers of students we are in need of more teachers, space, and learning materials. $5,000 would go towards training teachers to teach the Tapology Educational and Dance Curriculum, tap shoes, flooring, books, and historical documentation.


Walker/Collins Project:
   
    The Walker/Collins Project is an initiative that was concieved by Dianne Walker and Alfred Bruce Bradley. Walker is a protege of the legendary Leon Collins who is a master tap dancer and musician. Collins created a body of work that was designed for the dancer to understand musicality and structure of jazz music. Over the past year she has been travelling back and forth from Boston to Flint teaching this material to the Tapology Youth Tap 
Ensemble. The goal of the this project is to archive this information with Tapology and create a show tributingLeon Collins and a few other masters who were mentors to Mrs.Walker performed by the youth ensemble.  $5,000 will be used to offset housing, transportation fees, artist fee, and rehearsal space.


The Murals for Flint Project:

   The Murals for Flint concept uses instruction in visual arts as a means to provide at risk youth with a culturally defined mission to find the pride in their heritage; then give them a means to demonstrate that pride in mural projects that will also beautify the City of Flint and exhibit the diversity of talent in its youth.  $5,000 will be used for paints, brushes, transportation, stipends and equipment to install the mural.



Tapology Youth Tap Ensemble:  
 
    Formally know as the Flintstone Hoofers, the Tapology Youth Tap Ensemble is a program that is designed to train youth into proficient and professional dancers. This ensemble has traveled and performed in professional shows in cities such as Detroit, St.Louis, Ohio, Chicago, and New York City. In 2013 we would like to expose our company to other youth groups and tap programs that are designed to increase their skills and provide performance opportunities in other states through out the country. $5,000 will go towards transportation, housing, food, and tuition fees.


 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

 We are always in need of volunteers throughout the year for different Tapology events. Contact us if you are interested in getting more involved check out our website and like us on facebook as well. Share ths with all of your friends and family.

story:
Who We Are

We are Off the Fence Theatre Company (OtF), a producing and touring theatre company based in Leicester. Formed in June 2011 we produced our first performance in December 2011 and, by July 2013 our seventeenth. At OtF we focus on new writing for stage and site specific pieces and have performed in an NCP car park, Leicester Castle, a coffee shop -  sometimes even theatres!

In March and April 2013 we turned an under-utilised room over The Western in Western Road into Leicester’s first pub theatre.  We built a stage, installed lights and a sound system, hired folding seats and created Upstairs at the Western, enabling 21 performers and 700 people to visit us. 

With your help we now wish to turn the room into a permanent theatre space and improve facilities to an acceptable standard for both performers and audience. 

Why do we need money?

We need £1500 to pay for new seating. We listened to feedback after our first season and the big issue for audiences was the chairs. We'd rented some very uncomfortable wooden ones and to make a big difference to future Upstairs at the Western experiences we would now like our audiences to sit on nice comfy chairs of our very own - after all, we want to keep bums on seats! 

We need 72 chairs at around £20 each. In return for your money you will receive a personal thank you on our website and a special mention in our next season's brochure. Depending on your donation you could also receive a limited edition Upstairs at the Western bag plus free tickets for shows. If you're feeling really generous you can have your name painted for all to see on the stairway up to the theatre. 

The Impact

Our pilot season proved Upstairs at the Western works and we want to progress this to the next stage (great pun!) and make it a more permanent space. The Western agrees and we are delighted to have the full backing of the brewery and landlords. It also provides us with a rehearsal space for our own productions as we develop as a producing and touring company.

Pub theatres are a popular addition to a city’s culture, predominantly found in London with many having been in existence since the 1970s. They make use of what would otherwise be spare space and provides pub regulars, local residents and theatre goers with the opportunity to experience theatre and culture together in the community. It also creates opportunities for emerging and existing writers and performers to perform their work. 

Upstairs at the Western will help Leicester become known as a place to go for culture and the Arts and add to the theatre scene in the East Midlands. Upstairs at The Western was recently featured in the city’s bid for the UK City of Culture 2017 demonstrating the impact it has had on the city in a short amount of time.

Other Ways You Can Help

Off the Fence wouldn’t have made it this far without all the wonderful people and organisations who have helped us create Upstairs at the Western.

Running a theatre company requires a lot of hard work - both on and off stage - and we are always delighted to hear from anyone who would like to work with us. Perhaps you’d like to help Front of House? Or have technical or admin experience? Maybe you would like to stage-manage? If you would like to make the theatre your career or want to be a part of Leicester’s cultural scene then Upstairs at the Western can give you invaluable experience to boost your CV.

If you would like to get involved with Off the Fence Theatre Company and Upstairs at the Western or would like any further information about the roles we can offer then please get in touch – email vb@off-the-fence.com

We’d love to hear from you.

Please share this campaign as far and wide as you can. We are so excited about the next stage of Upstairs at the Western's journey and now is your chance to be a part of it too!

story:
The Lower Bottom Playaz, Inc:

Theater at its Most Committed

The Lower Bottom Playaz, Inc, were once a nomadic troupe that performed in parks, churches, shelters, warehouses, and a number of other non-traditional spaces. They provided 11 Seasons of theater in a outdoor theater in the Lower Bottoms of West Oakland. 100's have sat in the cold and the rain to see some of the best theater done on the West Coast. The troupe has been called one of Oakland's secret treasures. Kenneth Bullock, Independent Arts Reporter, calls The Lower Bottom Playaz, "Theater at its most committed." It was catastrophic for the troupe to learn the theater they have performed in for 12 years has gone dark in the middle of the troupe's 12 Season. 

However the most committed troupe in Oakland with its usual pluck and the assistance of stanch supporters continues to offer some of the highest caliber theater in the East Bay and they invite you to help ensure a triumphant close to their 2013 Season. The troupe under the direction of Ayodele Nzinga, MFA, Ph.D are currently engaged in mounting the entire Century Cycle by August Wilson in chronological order. They are closing out their Season 12: Tales of Iron and Water, at The African American Museum and Library at Oakland with F E N C E S the sixth installment in the epic ten-play cycle.

  • .Public art depends on public support.
  • Invest in art that builds community.
  • Help this Oakland troupe become the first troupe in theater history to stage all of August Wilson's works in chronological order.

Help us continue to serve.

Where Your Money Goes:

  • Funds raised here will  pay for office space, buy copy paper for scripts, ink for copiers, pay our box-office bill, help to host our web sites, buy postage, and assist with all of the cost associated with running a non-profit organization engaged in creating art for public presentation. 
  • We are a non-profit organization if you don't want a perk your donation is tax deductible and 100 per cent of your contribution helps us continue to exist. We also offer an array of pretty cool perks to reward you for supporting such a worthy cause.
  • All funds will be used to assist the troupe in its day to day operation through the closing of its 12th season.

The Importance of Supporting Local Art

The Lower Bottom Playaz have the motto of, "Creating what we need from what we have been gifted." Please support our efforts to bring the finest possible theater to Oakland CA.

  • Arts enrich communities in multiple ways including providing wholesome inclusive entertainment, common ground for diverse populations, and the preservation of culture.
  • Arts experience opens the door to multiple roads to employment. The Lower Bottom Playaz employ actors, train actors, and provide valuable experience for those interested in industry related employment. 
  • We get what we build and in a challenging economy many arts organization are forced to close or curtail activities -- we are trying to maintain our level of service and continue to offer oppourtunity to artist and serve Oakland theatergoers.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to help or you have already donated to a previous fundraising effort by us you can still help us by:

  • Please help us by spreading the word, There is theater in Oakland!
  • Please use the share tools!

See you in the Theater!

story:
"GoLi - The Moving Theatre"

The 1st Inflatable Pop-up Theatre in Singapore!
Bringing socially relevant, artistically and aesthetically intriguing works to the community

"Theatre does not target only the upper class. If theatre needs to convey a message, then our target audience should be the masses at the lowest end. I have always believed that it is time people can easily access theatre. In other words, every time I want to watch a play, I can do so without having to pay a lot of money, or even without paying a cent. Community theatre discusses issues that are easy to understand, but that does not mean that its presentation or artistic value is at the lowest-end. We cannot underrate the general public's ability to appreciate the arts."
– Extracted from "Interview with Kok Heng Leun — Newspaper/Community Theatre", from the book "Drama Box: 1992-2002" (Singapore: Drama Box, World Scientific Publishing Co Pte Ltd, 2004), Page 283.

We strongly believe that community cultural development is an important aspect of developing humanistic approaches to community building, as well as empowering and honouring the creativity of individuals at all levels.  We also believe that Community Theatre should be given as much respect and effort as performances in the theatre.

After more than a decade of engaging the community in exploring social issues through timely and intimate works, Drama Box is ready to bring our works in the community to the next level.

We are set to build the 1st inflatable pop-up theatre “GoLi – The Moving Theatre” in Singapore!

It has always been our dream to be able to reach out to more people with our work, and elevate its artistic and aesthetical qualities so as to better engage with the community.  “GoLi”, an iconic structure, that not only complements our work but provides us with foundation to build our works upon, does just that.  Our dream is almost within reach.

As with all our work in the community, this dream can only be complete with you. 


The beginning


In 2001, we did our first performance “Lian Can Cook” at Toa Payoh housing estate. The play looks at the protagonist’s relationship with her husband, son and her work place. It was a funny yet poignant take on domestic violence and oppression through the style of street theatre.  

Since then, community theatre has become an important part of our programming. To date, we have produced more than 16 original productions, mostly using the form of Forum Theatre, reaching out to more than 55,000 people.  We have also worked with many organisations including: Migrant Workers, Selarang Drug Rehabilitation Centre, AWARE Singapore, etc and explored many issues including AIDS, out-of-school youths, ageing, racial tension and terrorism concerns, problem gambling, etc.

In 2010, our Associate Artistic Director, Koh Hui Ling shared with her childhood friend Ting-Ting Zhang (Architect, Atelier Watt) the kind of works Drama Box does in the community. They then talked about the possibility of building a mobile structure that can  travel to different parts of Singapore, transforming community spaces into vibrant places for arts and culture. Thus was “GoLi” conceived.

[Forum Theatre originated from “Theatre of the Oppressed” established by Brazilian theatre master Augusto Boal. The most distinct feature of Forum Theatre is that it turns passive spectators to become proactive “spect-actors”, by allowing them onstage to replace actors and change the outcome of a play. ]


Our Campaign

“It takes a place to build a community and a community to build a place”

*GoLi – The Moving Theatre is a travelling theatre that’s going to be touring Singapore. She will be a spectacle wherever she goes, activating the space she inhabits, transforming it into an iconic and vibrant place for arts and culture.  The basketball court in a neighbourhood will become a drama theatre, the park will become an arts carnival.  She will draw in crowds from all over Singapore, the region and the world to participate in cultural activities that not only entertain, but also engage and stimulate audiences creatively, and provide a platform for dialogues over issues and for different voices to be heard. 

[*Goli is also the name of a traditional game popular in Singapore, a shared activity and memory of many Singaporeans. With simple props – a set of goli (marbles) and a shallow hole in the ground, a game starts.  A game is spontaneous, right in front of homes, with neighbours and friends.]

However, to build “Goli”, we need to raise S$400,000 by the end of 2014 and we hope to raise at least US$50,000 from the online committee. 

It is not the amount but the support that counts. Having the collective power of the community, corporations and the government coming together to make this dream come true is an integral part of this project.  This dream belongs to all of us.

Any amount of donation, no matter how big or small means a lot.
Together we can build something special.


The Structure

GoLi will be a set of four inflatable structures of varying sizes.  They will be cross-ventilated, light and easy to set up.  Flexibility is factored into the design where different combinations of the set can be assembled, allowing the structures to appear independently, in groups of two, three or four.  This provides for multiple possibilities in how they can be used to cater to the needs of the programmes.  They can be easily transported and stored so that it is convenient to use on tours.

The mobility and adaptability of the structures activates the different public spaces.  Outdoor spaces in the heartlands will be transformed into a place for arts and culture, creating diversity in the town and city centres.  The interesting architecture design will also encourage and nurture community interest in design, architecture and performance arts.

Performance Arts by tradition are held in static venues and are not deemed part of the “everyday”, whereas street performances held in marquees and tentages lack the aura and sense of place that theatre buildings provide. Through GoLi, we seek to bridge the gap between mobility & place.

GoLi is projected to have a life-span of about 8 to 10 years, exciting and inspiring Singapore for the next decade.


The GoLi experience

With 13 years of experience in bringing theatre to the community in the heartlands, Drama Box forges forward with our mission to bring to the people theatre that is fun and entertaining, aesthetically exciting, sincere and intimate, while engaging and provoking the audiences to dialogue, respond, reflect and participate.  We will continue to bring to the people theatrical experiences that mirror our social fabric.  We will also engage our audiences with theatre that blurs the boundaries between the audience and performers, as well as enable them to develop an appreciation of theatre as an effective and affective language of engagement.

GoLi will make its tour to the community every July from 2014, featuring programmes that include theatre performances, installations, exhibitions, carnivals and festivals. These will be co-created by artists as well as neighbours, for everyone in the community to enjoy. 

In July 2014, GoLi will be making her first sneak appearance at *Bukit Ho Swee Housing Estate, sharing stories of its residents and giving the audiences a taste of life in this little neighbourhood.  Beginning in July 2015, GoLi will host a biennial Community Theatre Festival, the first in Singapore, showcasing works from both local and overseas community theatre practices, in the spirit of deep engagement and inter-connectedness.

*Bukit Ho Swee is a small housing estate in Singapore. In 1961, a major fire broke out in Bukit Ho Swee and the recently constituted Housing and Development Board of Singapore moved in quickly to construct low-cost public housing to house the residents, and as a result, successfully curb the secret society activities in the area.


The creative brains behind GoLi

Co-Artistic Director (Programming)

Koh Hui Ling


Kok Heng Leun 


The Designers

William Tan & Ting-Ting Zhang (Atelier Watt)

William & Ting-Ting were lead designers at Zaha Hadid Architects, a Pritzker prize winning design firm and have managed design teams in various high-profile international projects.

They are experienced in performance venue design and creation of public architecture and the public realm, having worked on numerous performance venues. Projects include: Grand Theatres in Morocco (Rabat and Casablanca), National Performance Arts Centre in Kaoshiung Taiwan (competition, 2nd prize), People’s Conference Palace in Tripoli, Libya and opera houses in Middle East.

They are highly conversant and interested in advanced fabrication techniques vis-à-vis digital design platforms and how these can be creatively applied in the manufacturing process of conventional, everyday projects.

William and Ting-Ting were educated at Cornell University in Architecture, modern political theory, film and philosophy. They also read business at University of Oxford. Under the tutelage of Neil Leach and Chris Perry’s Responsive Systems Group (RSG) their thesis project “Terminal Life”, an omni-channel user-responsive airport system was first presented at the 2006 American Institute of Architects Dean's Roundtable exhibition and later at the Beijing Architecture Biennale.

Both of them have an academic interest in political science, cultural theories and semiotics, specifically how urbanism shapes the way society behaves. Subsequently, they have published essays and lectured on urban and socio-political issues at the Venice Biennale and universities such as ETH (Zurich) and The Bauhaus.

Who are Watt

Atelier Watt is the think-tank of William and Ting-Ting. Borne out of their passion for objects of crafts and luxury, Atelier Watt’s work traverses design and art, referencing the beauteous past, mirroring the present and projecting the hereafter.

Focusing on products, design-art, interiors and installations, they see Atelier Watt as the main vassal for their design and artistic projects that are not bounded by typologies, conventions nor trends - beyond the confinements of ‘form and function’. They wish to blend their ideas with traditional crafts and cutting-edge technique, creating objects that appeal both to the intellect and the emotion.

They envision The Goli Project as a blend of theatre making and architecture- bringing to the public a creative use of social spaces that provokes the imagination and participation of its inhabitants.
story_txt:
"GoLi - The Moving Theatre"
The 1st Inflatable Pop-up Theatre in Singapore!Bringing socially
relevant, artistically and aesthetically intriguing works to the community
"Theatre does not target only the upper class. If
theatre needs to convey a message, then our target audience should be the
masses at the lowest end. I have always believed that it is time people can
easily access theatre. In other words, every time I want to watch a play, I can
do so without having to pay a lot of money, or even without paying a cent.
Community theatre discusses issues that are easy to understand, but that does
not mean that its presentation or artistic value is at the lowest-end. We
cannot underrate the general public's ability to appreciate the arts."
–
Extracted from "Interview with Kok Heng Leun — Newspaper/Community
Theatre", from the book "Drama Box: 1992-2002" (Singapore: Drama
Box, World Scientific Publishing Co Pte Ltd, 2004), Page 283.

We strongly believe that community cultural development is an important
aspect of developing humanistic approaches to community building, as well as
empowering and honouring the creativity of individuals at all levels.  We also believe that Community Theatre should
be given as much respect and effort as performances in the theatre. 
After
more than a decade of engaging the community in exploring social issues through timely
and intimate works, Drama Box is ready to bring our works in the community to
the next level. 
We are set
to build the 1st inflatable pop-up theatre “GoLi – The Moving
Theatre” in Singapore! 
It has
always been our dream to be able to reach out to more people with our work, and
elevate its artistic and aesthetical qualities so as to better engage with the
community.  “GoLi”, an iconic structure,
that not only complements our work but provides us with foundation to build our
works upon, does just that.  Our dream is
almost within reach.

As with
all our work in the community, this dream can only be complete with you.  
 

The beginning 



In 2001, we did our first performance “Lian Can Cook” at Toa Payoh housing estate. The play looks at the protagonist’s
relationship with her husband, son and her work place. It was a funny yet
poignant take on domestic violence and oppression through the style of street
theatre.  
Since then, community theatre has become an
important part of our programming. To date, we have produced more than 16 original
productions, mostly using the form of Forum
Theatre, reaching out to more than 55,000 people.  We have also worked with many organisations including:
Migrant Workers, Selarang Drug Rehabilitation Centre, AWARE Singapore, etc and explored many issues including AIDS, out-of-school
youths, ageing, racial tension and terrorism concerns, problem gambling, etc.
In 2010, our Associate Artistic Director, Koh Hui
Ling shared with her childhood friend Ting-Ting Zhang (Architect, Atelier Watt)
the kind of works Drama Box does in the community. They then talked about the
possibility of building a mobile structure that can  travel to different parts of Singapore, transforming
community spaces into vibrant places for arts and culture. Thus was “GoLi” conceived.

[Forum Theatre originated from “Theatre of the Oppressed” established by Brazilian theatre master Augusto Boal. The
most distinct feature of Forum Theatre is that it turns passive spectators to
become proactive “spect-actors”, by allowing them onstage to replace actors and
change the outcome of a play. ]

Our Campaign
“It takes a place
to build a community and a community to build a place”
*GoLi – The Moving Theatre is a travelling theatre that’s going to be touring
Singapore. She will be a spectacle wherever she goes, activating the space she
inhabits, transforming it into an iconic and vibrant place for arts and
culture.  The basketball court in a
neighbourhood will become a drama theatre, the park will become an arts
carnival.  She will draw in crowds from
all over Singapore, the region and the world to participate in cultural
activities that not only entertain, but also engage and stimulate audiences
creatively, and provide a platform for dialogues over issues and for different
voices to be heard.  
[*Goli is also the name
of a traditional game popular in Singapore, a shared activity and memory of
many Singaporeans. With simple props – a set of goli (marbles) and a shallow
hole in the ground, a game starts.  A
game is spontaneous, right in front of homes, with neighbours and friends.]

However, to build
“Goli”, we need to raise S$400,000 by the end of 2014 and
we hope to raise at least US$50,000 from the online committee.  
It
is not the amount but the support that counts. Having the collective power of
the community, corporations and the government coming together to make this
dream come true is an integral part of this project.  This dream belongs to all of us.
Any amount of donation, no matter how big or small means a lot.Together we can build something special.


The Structure




GoLi will be
a set of four inflatable structures of varying sizes.  They will be cross-ventilated, light and easy
to set up.  Flexibility is factored into
the design where different combinations of the set can be assembled, allowing
the structures to appear independently, in groups of two, three or four.  This provides for multiple possibilities in
how they can be used to cater to the needs of the programmes.  They can be easily transported and stored so
that it is convenient to use on tours.
The mobility and adaptability of the
structures activates the different public spaces.  Outdoor spaces in the heartlands will be
transformed into a place for arts and culture, creating diversity in the town
and city centres.  The interesting
architecture design will also encourage and nurture community interest in
design, architecture and performance arts.
Performance Arts by tradition are held in static venues and are not
deemed part of the “everyday”, whereas street performances held in marquees and
tentages lack the aura and sense of place that theatre buildings provide.
Through GoLi, we seek to bridge the
gap between mobility & place.
GoLi is
projected to have a life-span of about 8 to 10 years, exciting and inspiring
Singapore for the next decade.


The GoLi experience

With 13 years of experience in bringing theatre to the community in the
heartlands, Drama Box forges forward with our mission to bring to the
people theatre that is fun and entertaining, aesthetically exciting, sincere
and intimate, while engaging and provoking the audiences to dialogue, respond,
reflect and participate.  We will
continue to bring to the people theatrical experiences that mirror our social
fabric.  We will also engage our
audiences with theatre that blurs the boundaries between the audience and
performers, as well as enable them to develop an appreciation of theatre as an
effective and affective language of engagement.
GoLi will
make its tour to the community every July from 2014, featuring programmes that
include theatre performances, installations, exhibitions, carnivals and
festivals. These will be co-created by artists as well as neighbours, for
everyone in the community to enjoy.  
In July 2014, GoLi will be
making her first sneak appearance at *Bukit
Ho Swee Housing Estate, sharing stories of its residents and giving the
audiences a taste of life in this little neighbourhood.  Beginning in July 2015, GoLi will host a biennial Community Theatre Festival, the first in
Singapore, showcasing works from both local and overseas community theatre
practices, in the spirit of deep engagement and inter-connectedness.
*Bukit Ho
Swee is a small housing estate in Singapore. In 1961, a major fire broke out in
Bukit Ho Swee and the recently constituted Housing and Development Board of
Singapore moved in quickly to construct low-cost public housing to house the residents,
and as a result, successfully curb the secret society activities in the area.


The creative brains behind
GoLi



Co-Artistic Director
(Programming)




Koh Hui LingKok Heng Leun The Designers
William Tan &
Ting-Ting Zhang (Atelier Watt)

Pritzker prize winning design firm and have managed design teams in various
high-profile international projects. 
They are experienced in performance venue design and creation of public

Performance Arts Centre in Kaoshiung Taiwan (competition, 2nd prize), People’s

Who are Watt

the hereafter. 
Focusing on products, design-art, interiors and installations, they see

not bounded by typologies, conventions nor trends - beyond the confinements of
‘form and function’. They wish to blend their ideas with traditional crafts and

They envision The Goli Project as a blend of theatre

story:
“Ms. Spain creates worlds ﬁlled with mystery.”    - Katia Bachko, The New Yorker

My former life In New York for 20 years has changed drastically with the move to my  home country the Czech Republic which I have left as a child. As a choreographer and dancer I am taken on the task to reflect on my former life in New York and my new life here in Prague now.  The theme of my new work “Sorry...you’re in my space” is about space and its meaning in our lives: How much space do we need to exist, to breath freely? When do we allow our lives to be overtaken by the space of others, or just noise, chatter, opinions? How does that effect our lives? As Edwin Way Teale writes:
“Time and space - time to be alone, space to move about - these may well become the great scarcities of tomorrow”.

This new work “Sorry...you’re in my space” tells individual and universal stories. 18 artists from 10 different countries are involved. The 10 performers who are made out of actors and dancers are constantly asked to overcome barriers of separation within themselves, as well as in the space that they share with one another.  They can choose to share the space, as well as not. The audience will find their own story in this work: A woman dealing with her body image protecting herself against outside humiliation, a man loosing almost himself and his belongings after a relationship...and many more.
"Sorry...you're in my space" can make us laugh or cry...

I am very proud to work with this wonderful group of artists who are willing to risk, feel and dare to express what might be hidden deeply within themselves. The Czech Republic has its own historic share of invasions and its people have been forced to function in the former enclosed space of their country’s borders for many decades. My own family history is imbedded in these stories and I am very moved to present my first major dance performance here in Prague also for this reason. The evening also includes my older “Yellow is not Gold” (2012) which was presented at Danspace Project/St. Mark’s Church in New York last year and very well received.
“Yellow is not Gold” is a wonderfully mystic journey as each individual explores the idea of treasures in life.”    Eye on the Arts, NY– Jennifer Thompson

I am inviting some artists from the US and Germany to join me here in Prague and to share this special performance with me, because I know that their contribution is irreplaceable. I would love to be able to pay them as much as I can for their travel expenses. This new work is bringing a separated world of mine together after more than 40 years. It is a significant step towards healing and the transformative power of art.

If you would like to support to bring this work to a larger audience, we would be deeply grateful for any support possible, as small as $1. It would give all artists a deeper sense of appreciation for their time and creativity, especially for the ones coming overseas. We are planning to have a photography exhibition and an outstanding video production accompanying this work to promote it further to more former Eastern European countries and Germany. Since I moved back here to my home country I am even more committed to create art that has healing power and is imbued with hope and to create an artistic exchange between NY based artists and the Czech Republic.


“Sorry...you’re in my space” (2013)
choreography: Dagmar Spain with the performers
performers: Klara Burgess, Jan Cina, Jay DeYonker, Jared Doreck, Klára Kočárková, Sameena Mitta, Mirka Prokešová, Jakub Sedláček, Martha Sobotka and Dagmar Spain
composer: Anar Keytarman, Jose Ramon Gonzales,
on flute: Maria Victoria Calero
text and co-director: Carolyn Morrow
costumes and set: Kristina Karmazinová and Kateřina Soukupová
lighting design: Johanna-Mai Vihalem
producer: Lucie Vojtíšková
www.danceimprints.com

story:
Short Summary

The inaugural Body Percussion Festival will be held March 28th to 30th, 2014, as part of the Harbourfront Centre’s NextSteps series. Led by Artistic Director Viv Moore, the event has been enthusiastically hailed by Canada’s dance, music and performance community, and will feature art forms that create music and rhythm through the body. Step, clog, tap, gigue, gumboot, hambone, flamenco, kathak, beatbox, hocket, and Carnatic vocal music, are only some of the extraordinarily diverse practices you'll see - and hear - presented by international, national and local artists. We need your help to make this first edition a success, so that the vision for the festival can embrace a wider community of artists and audiences.


About the Programming:

Keith Terry. Photo Credit: Paul Haggard.

We are excited to present international and national guest artists never or rarely seen in Toronto, including the renowned body music duo Keith Terry and Evie Ladin (Oakland, CA); traditional hambone artist SlapJazzDanny (San Diego); Southern English step and Appalachian clog dancer Kerry Fletcher (UK); and gumboot ensemble Bourask (Montreal), whose work reflects influences of  gigue and other body percussion practices. We are also pleased to have commissioned two artists to create original works: Toronto-based tap dancer Allison Toffan, and flamenco dancer Carmen Romero. And we are privileged by the virtuosity of the artists chosen through our call for submissions: Alejandro Céspedes, Esmeralda Enrique, Bageshree Vaze, Hachey the MouthPEACE, Sharada K. Eswar & Rup Sidhu, Chhandam Dance Company, Green Barn Morris, GREX, and Mafa Dance Village & Beyond Sound EmpiJah.

Our guest artists will also give workshops for people of all ages and all levels of experience. Evening showtimes are at 7 pm so that families with children can attend with ease; there is also a Sunday matinee. At all performances we are offering discounted prices for seniors, students and arts workers, and very special ticket prices for young children (as low as $5 for children under 12).

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $2,500 through this campaign. All funds raised will contribute to the production, including commissioning and presenting fees for local artists, travel and accommodation for out-of-town artists, venue and technical costs, publicity and marketing, as well as our energetic efforts to reach families with young children, and seniors. Donations big or small are all gratefully appreciated; perks in recognition of your generosity are listed on the right side of the page.

The Impact

The Body Percussion Festival is a unique event in the Canadian landscape, revealing the connection between the joy, spontaneity and play of being in one's body, and the act of creation and performance. It is our sincere belief that the Body Percussion Festival can touch the lives of people who may not usually attend performance events as well as seasoned watchers. No matter who, all will be delighted by the spirit of community of the performances and workshops of the festival. Our vision is to make of this event an opportunity to bring together artists and audiences, and to be inspired by the diversity and possibilities of body percussion, as a creative art form, and as a community practice.

Kerry Fletcher. Photo Credit: John Halliday

Other Ways You Can Help

Come to the festival! Your presence is what makes it all worthwhile. We would love your help in making noise about our fundraising campaign, and the festival itself. Please LIKE the Body Percussion Festival (www.facebook.com/bodypercussionfestival) and share this campaign with your family and friends using the Indiegogo share tools.

story:
The Show

Everything I Do, a contemporary musical loosely adapted from George Bernard Shaw’s Man and Superman, will be part of the 2014 Capital Fringe Festival. We will be in the Atlas Performing Arts Center in NE Washington, D.C. on 7/10/14 @5:30pm, 7/15/14 @8pm,  7/19/14 @8pm, 7/24/14 @5:30pm, and 7/26/14 @8:15pm.

It was read before a standing room only audience at the Kennedy Center Page to Stage Festival and workshopped at the Source Theatre through Artist’s Bloc.

About Us

Playwright/Composer John Becker recently co-directed and co-wrote a short film for Farar, Straus, and Giroux in New York. He’s been awarded Individual Artist’s Grants by the Maryland State Arts Council for both playwriting and fiction. His play, Summit Meeting, was performed in a theatre festival held at the Kennedy Center in Washington, D.C., where it was awarded 1st place by audience vote. He has had a play performed Off-Broadway at the Emerging Artists Theatre in New York. He has also had plays performed at the Source Theatre, Baltimore Playwrights Festival, the Writer's Center, Company 13, the Run of the Mill Theatre (for which they won a Greater Baltimore Theatre Award), the Human Rights Arts Festival for Amnesty International, and many others.

He also teaches music and theatre to kids and teens, introducing many young people to the arts.

The cast consists of Jared Calhoun, Sarah Welsh, Laura O’Brien, Phil Hosford, Sam Game, Tucker Bacon, and David Tuttle.

Everything I Do is directed by the illustrious Brad Porter, our stage manager is the wonderful Lauren Snyder, and our choreographer is the magnificent Emily Crews.

Help Us Fly

The fundraising campaign will allow us to pay our hardworking actors and crew, as well as offset the costs of production overall. The arts make us think, laugh, and feel. As Aristotle said, "The aim of art is to represent not the outward appearance of things, but their inward significance." And society needs as much of that as we can get!

Please use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word!

This production is presented as a part of the 2014 Capital Fringe Festival, a program of the Washington, DC non-profit Capital Fringe.

our choreographer is the magnificent Emily Crews.
Help
Us Fly
The fundraising campaign will allow us
to pay our hardworking actors and crew, as well as offset the costs of
production overall. The arts make us think, laugh, and feel. As Aristotle said,
"The aim of art is to represent not the outward appearance of things, but
their inward significance." And society needs as much of that as we can
get!Please use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word!

This production is presented as a part of the
2014 Capital Fringe Festival, a program of the Washington, DC non-profit Capital
Fringe.

story:
Hello, My name is Mary and I run Bellingham Dance Company Youth Competition Club.  This is a club for kids ages 12-19 yrs old and open to all levels of dancers.  These kids train in Swing, Latin and Ballroom dancing three times a week.  For some of them, this is the first introduction to dance they have ever had.  

I have been teaching for 19 years.  Teaching teens to social dance is one of the most rewarding things I do with my time.  The confidence I see blossom in these kids is tremendous.  Kids learn social skills, confidence, and partnership working as a team.  When kids set a goal and then are able to reach that goal, their joy and sense of accomplishment is infectious.

Many of these kids over the years and in this class are on scholarship (funded in house by us) and we are happy to continue this.  However, for this particular competition the funds are more than we can personally cover.

What We Need

Seattle Star Ball (and other competitions) have fees for the competition to help them fund what they are offering :)  We have 9 kids from our classes heading to competition.  Your contribution will help cover this for the kids.  We will be paying their -

Competition fees per dance - $295 

Entry fees (and chaperon entry fees) - $1045

Hotel Costs - 600

Travel fee (auto fuel for our volunteer chaperons :) - $100

Total Costs = $2040.00

*So far we have raised $950 through our endeavors at the studio.  Each kid is expected to contribute something for the competition.

So we need to raise $1000.00 more  ** I know it says $1200 I just updated this section, and cannot change the amount we wish to raise via indiegogo :)  Thanks All

    Risks & Challenges

    These are some of the best kids any one could hope to work with.  We were able to raise enough money last year when we went to competition.  We only entered 2 events each kid as it was our first year.  Well one year later and we have some returning students who have really improved and come a long way in their dancing. They have trained for and passed national level exams for dance and are turning into beautiful dancers.  They are ready for more advanced levels.

    One of our biggest obstacles has always been having enough leads for our dancers.  This year we have 3 boys ready to lead our 6 girls in their dancing.  This fall we hope to push and expand our competition program and recruit more leads.  

    Our girls and our boys always learn both Lead and Follow parts for dancing, in order to increase our practice abilities and to increase their understanding of the dance and how partnership works.  Someday we hope to visit a competition or host one ourselves that allows either gender to enter as a lead or as a follow to show their skills in partner dancing. 

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Whether you are able to contribute to our efforts or not, we hope you will pass along our campaign.  Thank you!!! :)

story:
Cohesion is about Baltimore's Artists

Cohesion Theatre Company is currently Brad Norris and Alicia Stanley, along with anyone who will come make collaborative work with them.  Brad is an actor, director, lighting designer and professional theatre nerd who has been working in the non-profit arts world in Chicago and Baltimore for over 15 years.  Alicia is a graduate of St. John's College in Annapolis who has acted, directed, and obsessively read her way into being a Shakespearean fanatic.  Together they were the Directorial team behind the critically acclaimed adaptation of Christopher Marlowe's Edward II at Spotlighter's Theatre in the Spring of 2014.  Now they are using their powers for good.

Cohesion Theatre Company was born out of a desire to foster connections amongst the theatrical and artistic community of Baltimore. We believe passionately that when artists combine their talents and energies across disciplines and despite competitive tendencies, what is created becomes greater than the sum of its parts, and what would be a success for one becomes a triumph for all.

We are currently putting together a three-show inaugural season in Baltimore, Maryland that will include two Baltimore Premiere Productions.  We are collaborating with established local theaters and artists to house our productions for extended runs in the Fall, Spring, and Summer.

As Cohesion grows, we hope to partner with other grassroots theatre companies in the Baltimore area to create new and interesting works of art. These collaborations are central to our mission statement, and we hope they will help foster the sense of community in the Baltimore theatre scene.

We want you to join us in our mission, and at our Launch Party!

We will be announcing our three show season at our Inaugural Season Launch Party on Friday, September 26, 2014 - 8pm to Midnight at Gallery 788 in Hampden - 3602 Hickory Avenue, Baltimore 21211. 

Tickets for the party are $20 each and will include food, drinks, raffle prizes, and live music performances from The Black & White Milk Bar, featuring Dyana Neal, Jim Knost, Beth Weber, and Christine Thomas-O'Mealy, as well as dancing with DJ Aurturo Ozaeta.

Tickets for our party are available online through this IndieGoGo Campaign!

What We Need & What You Get.

You can see the benefits related to each donation level on the right side of the screen, but right now let's talk about what the community gets when you give.

Your ticket purchase and donation mean that each of the artists involved in Cohesion Theatre Company's Inaugural Season gets paid for their work.

Let's say that again.  This company is going to pay its actors, designers, directors, stagehands, playwrights, stage managers, assistants, run crew, graphic artists, and anyone else who does work with or for us.  We believe strongly that art has value, and that the value of artists’ work should be recognized.  We also believe that being fiscally responsible with the art you make means that you can make more art in the future.  These ideas can work together.

Your donation to Cohesion Theatre Company will go into the pockets of local Baltimore Artists so that they can live, work, and create in and for this city.

Here's how it works.  Cohesion is planning three shows this season.  We'll start small by paying people stipends that are on par with other local theatre companies who pay their artists.  That means that this is the budget for our artist pay this year:

  • 30 Actors @ $200 each
  • 3 Directors @ $400 each
  • 3 Assistant Directors @ $200 each
  • 3 Stage Managers @ $500 each
  • 3 Assistant Stage Managers @ $200 each
  • 3 Lighting Designers @ $300 each
  • 3 Costume Designers @ $300 each
  • 2 Sound Designers @ $300 each
  • 1 Puppetry Designer @ $300 each
  • 3 Set Designers @ $300 each
  • 3 Prop Designers @ $300 each
  • 6 Run Crew/Technicians @ $200 each

That comes out to $15,600 in artist pay, just for our three productions.

What happens if you don't raise all this money through this campaign? 

We will rely more heavily on ticket sales from our three shows and grant and sponsorship opportunities to find this money over the course of the season.  We may need to cut production budgets in other areas.  We will not reduce the amount paid out to our artists.

What happens if you raise tons more money than you need to meet this goal?

We will put some of the excess towards our artist pay for our second season, and the rest will go toward increasing the stipends for all our artists across the board.

A Rising Tide Lifts All Boats

As Baltimore artists, we work day jobs, we work night jobs, we work retail, and restaurant, and minimum wage gigs all in support of what we really love to do: Create.  Now sometimes that's for nothing, and sometimes it costs us, and sometimes it costs us dearly.  We pay in time lost, we pay in gas cost, we pay in nights spent up late learning lines when we need to sleep.  That is worth something, and should be treated as such.  We hope that through our connections and our collaborations we will be able be able to offer that value to all theatre artists in Baltimore.  We hope to work with other companies to find ways to partner with them and raise their ability to support their artists more fully.  To create a vibrant and supportive artistic theatre community in Baltimore that is about more than just applause for its actors, directors, designers and technicians.

This is where we start that mission.  Will you join us?

Other Ways You Can Help

Share Cohesion's campaign and Launch Party details to as many friends and family as you can.  You can use Indiegogo's share tools to spread the word on Facebook, Twitter, and even through your own email.  We thank you for your time and hope to see you soon.
-Brad and Alicia

story:
"I don't wanna change the world. I just wanna be happy. Not almost happy, not pretend happy, but happy. And to love someone who loves me back. As ridiculous as that sounds."

"Almost Happy" is a sharp, funny, honest, and emotional new play written by Jacob Marx Rice and directed by Kelly Webb. It's the story of three young people trying to figure out what it means to grow up and how to be happy. It's a modern-day love triangle, but it's also so much more than that. These three characters are fully formed, complex, emotional people with a story that needs to be told, but we need your help! 

What We Need & What You Get

We're currently 60% funded but we still need $3000 to cover:

  • Rehearsal space rental
  • Theater rental costs
  • Props, costumes, set pieces 
  • Insurance 
  • Stipends so we can pay our creative team 
The good news is, whether we make our goal or not, THIS SHOW IS STILL HAPPENING. We have the script, we have the actors, and most importantly; we have the theater. Where there is a will there is a way. But that way might involve going into debt...
Which is where you come in! 
Every donation brings us one step closer to making this show the best it can be. We want to share this beautiful and well written play with you. So when you donate, besides getting some awesome perks (CAKE!) you're helping make independent theater happen. 
Theater has always been an art form that exists in the space between the audience and the performers. It rarely (almost never) actually turns a profit. We're working so hard to make this show a reality because we care about this story and want to share it with you!

Other Ways You Can Help

Share our Indiegogo page! Send the link along to your friends/enemies/lovers/ex-lovers & roommates! Like us on facebook, follow us on twitter and instagram, and most importantly...

COME SEE THE SHOW! 

Tickets are currently available at www.almosthappyplay.brownpapertickets.com

story:
The Story

Josh Nungesser started his theatre career with Advice To The Players (ATTP) when he was a youth appearing in many productions, attending Shakesperience Camps, as well as being involved in Queen Mab all-teen productions. Josh loved the stage from a young age and his participation extended to school and community productions. In 2013, Josh had to leave college to settle the estate of his mother, the late Colleen McDermott, who was a great friend and supporter of ATTP and Josh's motivating force.

Josh has spent the last two years in Sandwich settling his mother's estate, and his years have been highlighted by his involvement in Advice To The Players' productions. This Spring, Josh was able to work with Shakespeare & Company's Director of Education, Kevin G. Coleman who directed ATTP's Romeo & Juliet. Kevin helped to rekindle Josh's passion for theatre and desire to learn.

Josh has been accepted into the 2015 Summer Training Institute at Shakespeare & Company, which is a month-long intensive actor training program especially geared towards college-age students. Shakespeare & Company's actor training is world renowned and Josh has the opportunity to train with a group of his peers under the expert teachers at Shakespeare & Company. This training program is going to be the bridge to Josh's continuing education; after the Summer Training Institute Josh aspires to return to college in the fall.

What We Need & What You Get

Josh is not financially able to support the full weight of this program so he is getting support from his family, Advice To The Players, Shakespeare & Company, and you!

  • We need to raise at least $1,000 by the end of Josh's training with Shakespeare & Company so that the he is able to afford the monthly payments for the balance of his tuition.
  • Your donation will earn you heart felt thanks from Josh, plus a personalized thank you note for donations over $25 and Advice To The Players perks for donations over $50.
  • If we are unable to reach our goal, all money donated will still go towards Josh's tuition in the Summer Training Institute, but Josh will need to take out a personal loan to finance the rest, which will put further stress on his financial situation.

The Impact

The impact of Shakespeare & Compny's training has a 35-year unrivaled reputation, Josh will receive professional training in:

  • Shakespearian text, including monologue, sonnet, and scene work
  • Linklater voice training from certified instructors
  • Alexander movement training
  • Clown & Stage Combat training
  • Classes in Elizabethan  dance, stagecraft, and theatre practices

The training culminates in a final sharing of scene work open to family and friends.

Challenges

 Our major challenges with this effort are that many major educational grantors do not fund professional actor training offered by non-profit theatre companies and Josh has already been accepted into the program so we need to act fast!

  • Shakespeare & Company training is not eligible for Federal education grants or many private education grants like those offered by Sallie Mae
  • We need to raise the money by June 29, the day Josh completes the Summer Training Institute

Spread the word

If you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help!

  • Share Josh's story  and let others know we're raising money
  • Post a link to this campaign on your social media  pages and endorse 'Send Josh to Shakespeare & Company Training'

We really appreciate your help!

story:
Short Summary

THE BLOODLINE OF SHADRICK GRACE

Writer: Maya Contreras

Director: Kristin Skye Hoffmann

"Take one abandoned Bootlegger, add one bitter wife, a Caddo Indian, two muddled Aunts, three dashes of corrupt cops, a pinch of lesbian nuns, and pour into a depression-era-glass for a Southern tale about a diamond in a rough place. "

The Bloodline of Shadrick Grace” is a two-act comedy/drama running 50 minutes, which includes a five minute live music intermission. The cast includes 13 characters played by 7 actors.  The play has quick transition sets, film projections, and period costuming.

It will premiere at the FringeNYC Festival in August 2014

What We Need & What You Get

Producing a show at Fringe means producing a show from scratch. We're up for the challenge but we need your help!

"The Bloodline of Shadrick Grace"  is an independent theater project written by Maya Contreras.

Your support towards our goal of $3500 will go towards:

Rehearsal Space

And most importantly: paying our creative team for their amazing work.

All money raised over our goal will allow us to create an even more fully realized production (Lighting Design, Set Pieces, Costumes, Sound, Design Projections, Participation Fees, Insurance, Marketing, Transportation.) We are so grateful for your support!

Other Ways You Can Help

We completely understand if you are unable contribute financially, but that doesn't mean you can't help!

  • If you can spread the word about our play at the FringeNYC festival that will mean the world to us! And OF COURSE we would love to see you at the show!
  • Feel free to utilize the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

Based on my experience with indiegogo, I have written an article about:

How To Raise Funds For Anything That Is Close To Your Heart

Do read it here, and don't forget to share it if you like it, it may help someone else, to realise their dream:
http://www.polkacafe.com/how-to-raise-funds-for-anything-678.html

Thank you for your support!
