story:
We’re taking The Bridge to Brooklyn!  Come along for the ride!

THE BRIDGE at BROOKLYN HISTORICAL SOCIETY

128 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn NY, 11201

WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 15 at 7:30pm

THURSDAY, OCTOBER 16th at 7:30pm

FRIDAY, OCTOBER 17th at 7:30pm

ADMISSION: $10 / $5 for BHS Members


FEATURING

CINDY MARCHIONDA as Emily Warren Roebling

&

BILLY HANNON as Hart Crane

As the Gothic towers of the Brooklyn Bridge are rising, 1920s poet Hart Crane is writing his epic poem ‘The Bridge’…and yet, these events are separated by 50 years.  In this music theatre fantasy, Crane becomes obsessed with the Bridge and its builder, history’s first female chief engineer, Emily Warren Roebling.  We’re taking The Bridge to Brooklyn… and we want you to come along for the ride!

http://thebridgemusical.webs.com


THE PEOPLE & THE PROJECT

This exciting new music theatre piece explores the building of two bridges: the Roeblings’ bridge, begun in 1869 and completed in 1883, and the poetic bridge of Hart Crane, inspired, of course, by the former.  Inspired by theatrical greats including Bertolt Brecht and Robert Wilson, the piece is structured as a collage, with short, French scenes leading up to bigger,  ironic song moments as Hart’s poem and Emily’s bridge are built.  Musically, the piece draws on both the jazz-infused ‘20s and the genteel Victorian 1880s.  The sound of the Chorus – the Voice of the Bridge – runs the gamut from Vaudeville to contemporary minimalism.

Matt Marks is a composer, musician and performer based in Nottingham, England, who has worked with theatres and theatre companies in the UK, USA, Australia, China and Europe, and is currently associate artist with Maison Foo Theatre Company.   Liv Cummins is a lyricist/bookwriter best known for the oft-produced Vanishing Point, recently translated into Spanish and performed in Madrid, Spain.  Together, they began their adventure fifteen years ago at NYU’s Tisch School of the Arts Graduate Musical Theater Program.  The Bridge has had several developmental readings and workshop productions, most recently at Russell Sage College for Women in Troy, NY.  This workshop is the New York City premiere of the piece – in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge.

In partnership with Brooklyn Historical Society, we will present a workshop of The Bridge from October 15–October 17, 2014. We will be working with 10 principal actors and a 16-member chorus in and around the beautiful BHS building at 128 Pierrepont Street.  This Indiegogo campaign supports our goal to illuminate in this piece the relationship between art, infrastructure, and history, showing how the examination of these elements together can lead to exponential cultural understanding—as we showcase the work with an eye toward a full production in celebration of the 50th Anniversary of the NYC Landmarks Law in 2015.

CREATIVE TEAM

Liv Cummins & Matt Marks - Book, Music and Lyrics

David Baecker - Director

John Eckert - Lighting Designer

Andrew Diaz - Set Designer

The Bridge is presented by Columbia Arts Team (CAT), a 501 (c) 3 not-for-profit performing arts corporation dedicated to showcasing new work by performing artists.  All donations made to The Bridge must be made to Columbia Arts Team, and are tax-deductible according to the law.  See columbiaartsteam.org for more. 

THE (BACK) STORY

When walking across the bridge, Matt and I were intrigued by the plaque on the Brooklyn tower, which starts out: “Dedicated to the memory of Emily Warren Roebling…”  It goes on to name the other two Roeblings – her father-in-law, John, mastermind of the project, and her husband (John’s son), Washington – but it lists Emily’s name first.  Who was she, and how was a woman in charge of engineering the Brooklyn Bridge in the very Victorian 1870s?

We were further intrigued when our research kept pointing us to Hart Crane, ‘20s poet, whose epic poem, “The Bridge,” was the accomplishment of his life.  Both Emily and Hart achieved the greatest possible creative act – a literal bridge, and a figurative one – in the same spot in Brooklyn, fifty years apart. 

In one way, this is their story.  In another, of course, it is the story of all of us: we belong to the Brooklyn Bridge, and it to us.  It connects us to people and places, to the past and the future, to ourselves.  This is the story we are telling.



WHAT WE NEED

We need $14,650 to do this workshop.  Here’s the budget break-down:

Personnel:

Writer: $300

Director: $500

Musical Director: $750

Videographer: $500

Stage Manager: $500

Scenic Designer: $400

Lighting Designer: $400

Sound Designer: $200

Costume Designer: $200

10 Principal Actors: $5000 ($500 ea.)

BHS Staff Fees = $1,000

  Personnel Subtotal: $9,750

Production Costs:

Travel RT Airfare from England {composer}: $900

Food/Housing Stipend: $750 {for Writer, Director, & Designers}

Travel Stipend for 16 Chorus Singers @ $50 ea: $800

Rehearsal Space: $350

Program: $200

Printing / Promotion: $300

Props/Costumes/Misc: $200

Lighting Equipment/Rental: $1,000

Sound Equipment/Rental: $200

Video Equipment/Rental: $200

  Production Subtotal: $4,900

TOTAL: $14,650


THE WORKERS OF THE BRIDGE

The Bridge tells an important New York and, especially, Brooklyn story: one of real people, immigrants – the workers, whose blood, sweat, and sometimes lives were offered to lift those great, Gothic towers.  This is their story as much as Emily’s, as much as Hart’s – and they must be acknowledged.  This piece shines a light on their work and their struggle, delving down into the depths of the underground chambers, becoming ill with ‘Caisson Disease’ – known today as ‘the bends’ – as decompression forced many to become bedridden for long stretches, including Washington Roebling himself (Emily’s husband).  Many sustained serious injury and paralysis.  Many died from this frightening, then-unknown disease.  All suffered, yet continued digging out the caissons, getting the work done.

Celebrating 50 Years of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Law

We are partnering with the NYC Landmarks 50, an alliance of over two hundred organizations and landmarks across the city engaging and informing the public about the passage of the Landmarks Preservation Law on April 19, 1965.  From now through 2015, myriad cultural and arts events engage the public about this important law and the need to protect and preserve landmarks.

As the Brooklyn Bridge may be the greatest landmark in all of New York (we’re not biased or anything!), our piece plays a key role in these celebrations.  Specifically, this Indiegogo campaign supports a workshop of The Bridge, the first step in our goal to illuminate the relationship between art, infrastructure, and history, showing how the examination of these elements together can lead to exponential cultural understanding.

We plan to launch a full-scale production in late 2015 in celebration of the 50th Anniversary of the NYC Landmarks Law.  Surrounding this production, we envision immersive events throughout the city, involving thousands of citizens and performers, engaging the public in an awareness and appreciation of the Landmark Law, in general, and the Brooklyn Bridge, in particular.

With your help, we can launch this work which celebrates New York City’s past and present, inspiring us to create the great, unimagined art and architecture which will shape the future.

How can The Bridge make a difference, to you, to the world?

The Bridge is a story of the workers who built it under terrifying, unsafe conditions.

The Bridge challenges contemporary ideas of gender politics and female role models, and examines the role of an outsider struggling to change the world while finding acceptance within it.  Questions emerge about art versus science, beauty versus function, and the ways in which past, present, and future are linked by bridges – both real and metaphorical.

But finally, The Bridge is OUR story.  Yours and mine.  Because this great landmark – perhaps New York’s greatest – belongs to all of us.  John Roebling’s inclusion in his architectural plans of a pedestrian walkway allows us all – one hundred and thirty-one years later! – to freely encounter it, touch it, be a part of it, whenever we wish. Through it, we are connected to people and places, to the past and the future, to ourselves. 

This story must be told.  Help us tell it.  Be a part of The Bridge!

CHALLENGES

Though we believe deeply in this project and believe everyone who hears of it will want to take part and contribute, we recognize we may not raise our entire financial goal in this campaign.  If we do not, here are our plans.

Where we can do with less, we will: categories include equipment rental, costumes and designer, props, and writer stipend.  However, we will not decrease any funds for the professional, top-caliber creative team, performers, and staff, without whom we cannot do live theater!  These people are the workers of our bridge, offering their time and talents to allow this new work to flourish. 

With these accommodations, we know we can make it work.  This Bridge will be built – with your help!

HOW CAN YOU HELP?

You can help in so many ways! 

        Contribute now, in any amount!  No amount is too small (or too large!).

  • Help us spread the word and make some noise about our campaign.  Use the Indiegogo share tools and talk it up with your friends!! 
  • Walk across the Brooklyn Bridge.  Contemplate.  Consider.  Talk to your friends about the story of the bridge; do they know how it was built?
  • Read Hart Crane’s epic poem, The Bridge.  Contemplate.  Consider. 
  • Consider a contribution, no matter how small, to help us tell their stories.  Our story.  Your story.

THANK YOU!!!

story:
For those who have experienced The Rocky Horror Picture Show, it needs no introduction. It is a night of crowd merging with movie, where the fourth wall of the screen is broken, and the audience is connected by the rambunctious, gender-crossing joy and shock of a movie that is as much a film as it is an experience. The show will feature local performers dancing, acting, and singing along with the film, for an all immersive adventure.

Although largely ignored upon release, it soon gained notoriety as a midnight movie when audiences began participating with the film at the Waverly Theater in New York City in 1976. Audience members returned to the cinemas frequently and talked back to the screen and began dressing as the characters, spawning similar performance groups across the United States. Today, the film has a large international cult following and is one of the most well-known and financially successful midnight movies of all time.

In this M.E.S.H.y embrace of the dirty cult classic, performers will add an edu-taining layer of integrated discussions about accountability, consent, sexuality, slut-shaming, and safer spaces!  This is the first screening of Rocky Horror with active participation in Portland since The Movies closed.  As Rocky Horror is still in limited release (nearly four decades after its premiere), we need to pay for rights to the film and for permissions.  We've got to raise $500 to make this happen, so we are in need of the community's support!

You are encouraged, as audience members, to dress up, sing along, and shout call lines during the film.  Prop bags (including noisemakers, hats, squirt guns, etc) will be for sale at the event.

Friday January 9th! Two screenings, complete with a shadow cast performance, at 8:00pm and 11:00pm. $10 advance, $12 at the door. 
Go to https://onelongfellowsquare.com/ to reserve your spot! All Virgins and Sluts are welcome! Prop bags will be sold at the show!! Dammit!

story:
Project Y

Project Y was founded 15 years ago in Washington, DC, by Michole Biancosino and Andrew Smith, who remain the Co-Artistic Directors.  Now a New York City-based company, Project Y produces new work by new and emerging playwrights through an 18-month long gestational process that takes a play from early draft reading to fully produced world premiere.  Project Y has produced some of the most exciting plays and playwrights working in the American theatre today, showcased talented and emerging actors, designers, and directors, and created a forum for new work to be presented in exciting and original productions in high-profile venues.   

In 2014, we have planned:  

TechnoPlays Reading Series

FoodPlay Video Monologues

a monthly PopUp touring production of LoveSick

our first Playwrights Group (bimonthly developmental group)

a workshop production of 13 Short Plays by Playwrights Group Members

and the NY premiere of The Religion Thing by Renee Calarco


This 15 Year Birthday Campaign will help support all of these new works, all part of Project Y's expanded programming.  By contributing to the 15 Year Campaign you will help produce and promote the voices of new writers, actors, designers, directors, and artists, allowing them to shape the next 15 years of American theatre. 

Project Y has always been a grassroots theatre company. Many of our current supporters were the audience members from our very first season.  Please be part of Project Y now.  We need you and we want you to join the family of our PY fold. 


 $7500 

We want to raise $500 for each year since our birth. That means 15 x $500 for a total of $7500.  We will use those funds to support our 2014 programming and launch the next phase of our company. 

Here is the programming your donations will fund:

  • $3000 Design budgets for NY Premiere of "The Religion Thing" 
  • $1250 Rehearsal space for NY Premiere of "The Religion Thing"
  • $1000 Workshop Production of 13 Short Plays (written by members of our Playwrights Group)
  • $1000 Reading Series (rehearsal and performance space)
  • $500 "LoveSick" PopUp Tour 
  • $500 Project Y Playwrights Group (bimonthly meetings)
  • $250 Food Plays Video Monologues 

We NEED You!

Project Y exists because of the generosity of donors like you.  We rely on your support to create the innovative, edgy work that has become our trademark.  

Here is some of the World Premiere work our supporters have enabled us to create in the past:  LoveSick or THINGS THAT DON'T HAPPEN, Goodness, Before & After, Undressing Cinderella, Scapism, Sinking UP!, The Firsts, How. What. Now., A User's Guide to Hell, featuring Bernard Madoff, I'm From Driftwood, Downward Facing Debbie, Therese Raquin Desire, Gidion's Knot, FUBAR, and many more….

 Help us continue to make an impact in the theatre world and in our shared community.

How else can you Join PY?

Come see "The Religion Thing" this summer.  The show plays June 18-August 1 at the Cell Theatre, 338 W23rd Street.  For more info check out: www.projectytheatre.org

story:
Ms ORIENTAL Movement

In a time where diversity is a heated issue everywhere, especially in the performing arts community, how do we embrace the conversation on representation and identity?  

We put it in a play.

Ms. Oriental is a new play by Asian American writer Marisa Marquez.  When an Asian American actress finds herself amongst some of the most influential women in Asian history, she takes a magically theatrical journey that forces her to question her own identity.  Awakening to the reality of a hospital bed, she struggles to understand the past, the present and choosing to have a future.

From Page to Stage

Who would want to see a play with an all Asian Female cast - help us find out!

  • We are not a commercial theater, we are a scrappy group of ladies who desire to be heard.
  • While we have received a wonderful grant from the Asian Women Giving Circle, it is far from the $30,000 we need for costumes, to pay the talented actors and crew, rental fees, and the set.
  • Not only will your donations go to producing the show, but they will give an underrepresented and at risk community a platform to discuss issues of representation, identity, and suicide.
  • If we don't make our goal, Ms ORIENTAL will remain silent on the page

Not Just a Play

We are asking the hard questions and inviting others like you to join the conversation:

  • Silence is not an option:  Few outlets are openly discussing the prevalence of suicidal thoughts amongst Asian-American women. We bring to light issues buried in the dark.
  • Outreach is paramount: Your donations will cover the cost for those most at risk - Asian American, women and youth groups - those who can't afford the ticket to be able to see the show.  
  • Talk backs: Our goal is to engage the audience after the show.  An open dialogue is necessary if we strive for change and understanding.

Other Ways You Can Help

While monetary support is amazing, our needs don't stop there!

  • Follow us on social media.  Tell people about us.  Come to the show!
  • Community partnerships - if you are part of or know of any organizations that would like to come to the show, we would love to hear from you!
  • We need a home - a theater, rehearsal space, a place to grab a bite - so if you have any of those, please contact us!

Thank for joining us in breaking barriers, making history and impacting all those who see the show!

Marisa Marquez is a sponsored artist with The Performance Zone Inc (dba The Field), a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the performing arts community. Contributions to The Field earmarked for Marisa Marquez are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906 New York, NY 10038, phone: 212-691-6969 or for our national charities registration. A copy of our latest financial report may be obtained from The Field or from the Office of Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.
story_txt:
Ms ORIENTAL Movement 
In a time
where diversity is a heated issue everywhere, especially in the performing arts
community, how do we embrace the conversation on representation and identity?
 
We put it
in a play.
Ms.
Oriental is a new
play by Asian American writer Marisa Marquez.  When an Asian
American actress finds herself amongst some of the most influential women in
Asian history, she takes a magically theatrical journey that forces her to
question her own identity.  Awakening to the reality of a hospital bed,
she struggles to understand the past, the present and choosing to have a future.
   From Page to Stage Who would want to see a play with an all Asian Female cast - help us find out!

We are not a commercial theater, we are a scrappy group of ladies who desire to be heard.

While we have received a wonderful grant from the Asian Women Giving Circle, it is far from the $30,000 we need for costumes, to pay the talented actors and crew, rental fees, and the set. Not only will your donations go to producing the show, but they will give an underrepresented and at risk community a platform to discuss issues of representation, identity, and suicide. If we don't make our goal, Ms ORIENTAL will remain silent on the page    Not Just a Play We are asking the hard questions and inviting others like you to join the conversation:  Silence is not an option:  Few outlets are openly discussing the prevalence of suicidal thoughts amongst Asian-American women. We bring to light issues buried in the dark.
Outreach is paramount: Your donations will cover the cost for those most at risk - Asian American, women and youth groups - those who can't afford the ticket to be able to see the show.  
 Talk backs: Our goal is to engage the audience after the show.  An open dialogue is necessary if we strive for change and understanding.


    Other Ways You Can Help While monetary support is amazing, our needs don't stop there!

Follow us on social media.  Tell people about us.  Come to the show! Community partnerships - if you are part of or know of any organizations that would like to come to the show, we would love to hear from you!
We need a home - a theater, rehearsal space, a place to grab a bite - so if you have any of those, please contact us!   Thank for joining us in breaking barriers, making history and impacting all those who see the show!Marisa Marquez is a sponsored artist with The Performance Zone Inc (dba The Field), a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the performing arts community. Contributions to The Field earmarked for Marisa Marquez are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906 New York, NY 10038, phone: 212-691-6969 or for our national charities registration. A copy of our latest financial report may be obtained from The Field or from the Office of Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

story:
Who We Are

Ótimo is a Latin fusion dance company inspired by styles of Brazilian dance such as: Samba Reggae, Maracatu, Samba no Pé and Samba Axé. For more information on who we are, please visit www.otimodance.com.
Ótimo Dance is proud to present our 2016 calendar fundraiser! Our goal is to raise $2,000 toward the creation of a brand new company set of professional-grade, handcrafted dance costumes that will serve us for years to come. 

Our costumes are hand-crafted, American made! So is our passion.
You simply can't fake an excitement like this!


What We Need What You Get

We need to raise $2,000 and every dollar will go towards purchasing bulk materials needed to create and build a brand new company set of feather headdresses and beaded belts for lots of #shakeyshakey! These new professional-grade costumes will be debuted at our biggest performance of the year, Carnaval in February 2016! For show information, visit www.otimodance.com.

The first 100 people to contribute $20 to our fundraiser get a limited-edition 2016 Calendar! The calendar will feature a gorgeous selection of full-color, professional photos by Ray Pfeiffer from 2013 to present. 

Our performing artists are creative, innovative and incredibly dedicated to the costume design and construction process:

    • $348 covers the cost of headdress wire frames for 11 dancers
    • $500 covers the cost of almost 800 authentic rooster coque and ostrich feathers for our headdresses for 11 dancers
    • $300 covers the cost of thousands of beads that we will string ourselves for our beaded belts for 11 dancers that make us #shakeyshakey
    • $250 covers the cost of gemstones, rhinestones and sequins to add shine and sparkle to our belts and headdresses
    • $150 covers the cost of other crafting supplies for belts and headdresses:  wire, fabric, thread, hooks, ​felt, foam, glue, ribbon and elastic 
We need 100 calendar backers in order to reach our goal - will you back us?
We truly wouldn't be able to do what we do without the support of the community! Thank you so much for checking out our fundraiser and for your support!

#otimodance #emergingfromthejungle #shakeyshakey

story:
The TimeLine Projects is a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of The TimeLine Projects must be made payable to "Fractured Atlas" only, and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Founded in 2000, Rising Circle Theater Collective is a nexus for artists of color, empowering them to conceive, develop, and produce original work. We are dedicated to broadening the scope of storytelling on the American stage by placing the stories of people of color first.

In May 2016, Rising Circle Theater Collective is producing the world premiere of Sevan K. Greene's "This Time," directed by Kareem Fahmy, at The Sheen Center in NYC.  Inspired by a true story, the play tells the tale of an Egyptian woman who abandons her country and her children to be with the man she loves. Both an epic romance and a searing family drama, "This Time" is about the consequences of love and the ties of responsibility. 

As members of Rising Circle, we are so excited to have helped the development of this play over several years, and are taking our biggest risk as a theatre company to produce this work next Spring.  The play "This Time" lands at the center of our mission: to put stories of people of color first, and to empower artists of color to bring these stories to the stage.

Your generous contribution will support artist fees and other production expenses.  A donation in any amount will bring us closer to producing this great play and supporting all the artists.

story:
Hello! 

My name is Kat Marie Yoas. I’m a queer writer, performer, comedic healer, storyteller, candle maker, magic creator — a general working class sweetheart! 

I have been writing (not so) quietly for ten years and creating sold out one woman shows for the last three years. I have made work locally and toured my work throughout the country and other countries with Sister Spit and with my own damn self! My performance and writing is audacious, bold, feminist and rooted in shame eradication. 

I have written a new one woman show that has been selected as part of the 2015 National Queer Arts Festival! It is called A LESBIAN’S GUIDE TO SELF CARE.  (Sample video here!!!) It will be presented at CounterPULSE June 5th, 6th and 7th. I am beyond thrilled at the chance to perform at such a wonderful venue during such a great, historic festival.  Furthermore, I will finally be able to set the costs of my tickets, which are sliding scale and also no one turned away for lack of funds!  I welcome all my brothers and sisters <3

A LESBIAN’S GUIDE TO SELF CARE is a comedic, astrologically drunken hero-journey. I find the road to wellness is under construction and bumpy at best. The show is about the desire to be happy and healthy. It is about how we cope with life at the queer margins of society.  I’ll allude to everything from Chicken Soup for The Teenage Soul and talk shows to wealthy woo woo womb-mother retreats. A LESBIAN’S GUIDE TO SELF CARE is an urge to consider how we take care of ourselves. Themes of loss and humor vacillate as wildly as my Stevie Nicks fringe in this evening length show.

I have self-produced all of my work up until this point. This time, for a show of this magnitude, I need my friends and family to help support A LESBIAN’S GUIDE TO SELF CARE. That is why I have launched this campaign — I have so many ideas for this show that will flourish with the help of this Indiegogo campaign. I see you all as more than donors; you are also my collaborators. I want to make something with and for each of you!

$2,500 will offset the costs of this production. This sum will mostly cover the costs of renting CounterPULSE (which is $2,200.  The remainder goes to Indigogo's fees). Turns out, it is INSANELY EXPENSIVE TO RENT A RESPECTED THEATER. If I raise more than that (!!), the rest will go to other related costs like production, video, design, marketing, shiny costumes, time and other resources unforeseen.

I feel confident that I can make my goal of $2,500 just in time for the premier of A LESBIAN’S GUIDE TO SELF CARE in June. I promise to make the most out of this campaign and bring you a show that will make you laugh, cry, feel the love and shout out a resounding yes to the goddess!  

Please take a look at my perks  --------->

story:
The Wild Ensemble was set up in 2010 with a view to creating punky,edgy and  innovative theatre in Cork City in Ireland.Our first production was a sell-out production of Anthony Burgess' controversial "A Clockwork Orange" and subsequent productions have been the award-winning "Fade To Black" by Mark Evans,"A Rustle Of Wings" by Linda Eisenstein,the Irish premiere of "Clocked" by Neil Flynn,the horror anthology "Disconnected" by various writers and "Unfinished Portrait" by Yvonne Coughlan.


As anybody who works in theatre knows it is a challenge at the best of times to get any production off the ground as funding is local authority funding for productions is scarce and in many cases non-existant so any form of funding from any party is welcomed and much appreciated.


For this production we are seeking to raise the small figure of 500 Euro,which will enable us to obtain the performance rights for the show (thus enabling us to announce what the show is) and other minor costs.


Anybody who donates 50 Euro or more will get a free ticket for the show and a thank you in the programme and anybody who donates anything up to that will get a copy of the poster for the show and a special mention in the programme.

story:
Help our talented troupe earn the funds they need to reach the ★'z!!

ST★RZ CHEER & DANCE is a ground breaking, award winning, non profit community team based in Lakeland, FL.We are the first to offer All Star competitive instruction to athletes ages 5-18, who show a desire to excel further than city-owned competitive teams. We have a professional, yet friendly volunteer board of directors comprised of moms and coaches, dedicated to the success of our team and, more importantly, to the growth and confidence of every member of our team. Our coaches dedicate hours of time and talent to our award winning troupe and play an incredible role in instructing our members to pursue excellence. We’re very proud to say that last season, ST★RZ CHEER & DANCE, earned the title of National Champions at Florida Cheer & Dance Association's Nationals, Orlando FL. A concrete demonstration of the talent, creativity and hard work of our entire team. This is an unprecedented accomplishment for a novice team. As we enter our 3rd annual season, we continue to expand our growing family and want to see our team with more financial stability. Gym time, tumbling mats, costumes and competition fees are always needed for our athletic family. Without large corporate sponsors, we need your help. Please consider helping our amazing group of girls.

story:
Secretary!, written by Jessica Rose, has been selected by pivotal(arts) theatre company inc. to be part of their annual WriteNOW! Festival of New Works in March 2011. The play has been in development for several years, and has been workshopped since June 2010 through the pivotal(arts) playlab series.


This is the exciting debut of a new female playwright, and will showcase the work of some enormously talented young artists. You won't want to miss it!


But we need your help.


The cost of putting on theatre can be overwhelming for "starving" young artists, which is why Secretary! has not been produced until now. Just like in fringe festivals, while the producers of the festival are providing the venue and technical support, all the other production costs come out of the artist's pocket. In order to have any hope of making a profit--which can then be used to pay the cast and crew for their time, energy, and creativity--it is essential that we raise more money. 


More specifically...

We need funds for rehearsal space, props, costumes, advertising materials, and programs. Rehearsal space alone can cost up to $1000. Every cent that we raise will be going to funding the production with the hopes that we can put on the most professional performance possible and earn a profit to split among the cast and crew. We believe that theatre should be exciting, passionate and brave, and that the work should be of the highest quality and integrity. We also stand by the belief that our artists should be valued for their work and contribution, which means providing financial compensation whenever possible.

Every $1, $5, $10, $20+ will make a huge difference to the team and ensure that not every penny of the show will come out of one hungry artist's pocket. Every person who donates will also have a special mention in our program -- and a ton of love and gratitude from us! We know there are others who love the arts as much as we do and are excited to see and support new Canadian theatre... help us show other artists like ourselves that it is possible to fund and create new work!

Spreading The Love

Please spread the word to theatre lovers around the city. Whatever you can contribute will make all the difference. Go ahead and share on facebook, twitter, etc!

Thank you so much for your support!

Details:


Event: WriteNOW! Festival of New Works 2011

Venue: Bread & Circus, Toronto

Dates: March 21, 22, 24, 25

Director: Michelle Alexander

Producers: pivotal(arts) theatre company inc. (www.pivotalarts.ca)

story:
What if Carrie and Mr. Big traveled back in time to 1930s London and Paris? Theyâ€™d be starring in NoÃ«l Cowardâ€™s PRIVATE LIVES!

Yes, PRIVATE LIVES is as fun and timely as ever. Much like Shakespeareâ€™s Taming of the Shrew, PRIVATE LIVES is a classic â€œBattle of the Sexesâ€ about the people we canâ€™t live withâ€¦or without.

A production of PRIVATE LIVES featuring â€œSex and the Cityâ€ star Kim Catrall is currently running on Broadway, but you donâ€™t have to travel to the Big Apple to enjoy this play.

 

Our theatrical company, Table for Two Productions, has the rights to produce PRIVATE LIVES at GTC Burbank, an intimate 99 seat theatre where NoÃ«l Cowardâ€™s witty wordplay and scintillating humor will be on full display.

This is the first time in 10 years that PRIVATE LIVES will be produced in the Los Angeles/Burbank area. Weâ€™re assembling a team of professional actors, designers and other creative talents to help bring Cowardâ€™s clever comedy from the page to the stage.

Thatâ€™s where you come in...

Your generous contribution will go directly towards the production costs, including: theatre rental, royalties, director, set design, light design, sound design, costume design, stage management, marketing, publicity, and advertising.

We have set a goal of $10,000 for this campaign, but even that does not cover all of the expenses weâ€™ll incur by opening day. Ticket sales will help contribute to our bottom line once the play opens, but like most live theater productions, theyâ€™ll only cover about 50 percent of our total cost.

So, letâ€™s see how much we can raise above and beyond the $10,000 goal!

Donations of every amount are welcomed. No amount is too smallâ€”or too large!
So why PRIVATE LIVES?
â€œDevastatingly funny.â€ â€œAn iridescent bubble of a play.â€ â€œSomething to go silly over.â€ â€œAll but continuous laughter.â€

Those are just a few of the accolades heaped upon the original 1930 production of PRIVATE LIVES, which follows the saga of perpetually dueling lovers Amanda and Elyot, two divorcees who unwittingly book adjoining rooms while honeymooning with their new spouses. They soon realize the folly of their new marriages and impulsively flee together to Paris, only to be caught days later by their jilted spouses.

This stylish, savvy and still-timely comedy is loaded with pointed barbs about modern romance that anyone can relate to.

Written in 1930, the original production of Private Lives starred NoÃ«l Coward, Gertrude Lawrence, Adrianne Allen and Laurence Olivier. The play has been revived many times on Broadway (including a memorable 1983 production that starred Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton), and has been produced in theaters throughout the world.

Now, with your help, PRIVATE LIVES will be coming to GTC Burbank.

Who is Table for Two Productions?
Table for Two Productions was founded by Stasha Surdyke and Christopher Trela to create and host theatrical & culinary fundraising events for arts organizations, as well as present professionally produced plays in venues throughout . Christopher and Stasha co-write the Table for Two dining column in the Newport Beach Independent, and they are the co-editors of Coastal Food and Wine, a website devoted to covering epicurean experiences along the coast of So Cal.

Nominated for a 2011 Women in Business Award from the Orange County Business Journal, Stasha Surdyke is an Ovation nominated actress and vocalist who has appeared in numerous commercials, films, television shows and theatrical productions throughout Southern California, including a starring role in An Empty Plate in the CafÃ© du Grand Boeuf at The Laguna Playhouse. A graduate of University of Washingtonâ€™s School of Drama, she was one of eighteen students accepted into the schoolâ€™s prestigious two-year Suzuki program and received her BA in Drama and a minor in Communications from UW. Stasha is a proud member of Actorâ€™s Equity and Screen Actors Guild.

In addition to her performing credits, Stasha oversees media relations and other creative services for the boutique PR agency, ArtsPR. Stasha designed the award-winning press kit for Laguna Playhouseâ€™s production of The Second City: Can You Be More Pacific? which won the 2011 PROTOS Award of Excellence this year. She is a member of the Southern California Restaurant Writers Association, Orange County Press Club, and the NoÃ«l Coward Society.

Twice nominated for Entrepreneur of the Year by the Orange County Business Journal, Christopher Trela is the owner and president of ArtsPR, a boutique PR agency that specializes in public relations services for arts organizations. Current clients include The Laguna Playhouse, Irvine Barclay Theatre, Long Beach Symphony Orchestra, Festival Ballet Theatre, Chance Theater, The Queenâ€™s Gallery/MUZEO, Costa Mesa Playhouse, Young Singers of OC, and Classical Mystery Tour (a Beatles tribute band that performs with orchestras around the world).

He is also the founder of New Voices Playwrights Workshop, and has written plays that have been produced at venues throughout Orange County, Los Angeles, and New York. Christopher is President of the Orange County Press Club, serves as an Arts Commissioner for the City of Newport Beach, and is an Adjunct Professor of Public Relations at Chapman University. Christopher is a member of the Public Relations Society of America.

Stasha and Christopher thank you for your support!

For more information on Table for Two Productions and PRIVATE LIVES, visit our website: www.Table4Two-PrivateLives.com.

designers and other creative talents to help bring Cowardâ€™s clever comedy from
the page to the stage.Thatâ€™s where you come in... 

Your generous contribution will go directly towards the production costs,
including: theatre rental, royalties, director, set design, light design, sound
design, costume design, stage management, marketing, publicity, and
advertising. 
We have set a goal of $10,000 for this campaign, but even that does not cover
all of the expenses weâ€™ll incur by opening day. Ticket sales will help
contribute to our bottom line once the play opens, but like most live theater
productions, theyâ€™ll only cover about 50 percent of our total cost. 
So, letâ€™s see how much we can raise above and beyond the $10,000 goal!
Donations of every amount are welcomed. No amount is too smallâ€”or too large!
So why PRIVATE LIVES?

â€œDevastatingly funny.â€ â€œAn iridescent bubble of a play.â€ â€œSomething to go silly
over.â€ â€œAll but continuous laughter.â€
Those are just a few of the accolades heaped upon the original 1930 production
of PRIVATE LIVES, which follows the saga of perpetually dueling lovers Amanda
and Elyot, two divorcees who unwittingly book adjoining rooms while
honeymooning with their new spouses. They soon realize the folly of their new
marriages and impulsively flee together to Paris, only to be caught days later by their
jilted spouses. 
This stylish, savvy and still-timely comedy is loaded with pointed barbs about
modern romance that anyone can relate to. 
Written in 1930, the original 
production of Private Lives starred NoÃ«l Coward, Gertrude Lawrence, Adrianne
Allen and Laurence Olivier. The play has been revived many times on Broadway
(including a memorable 1983 production that starred Elizabeth Taylor and
Richard Burton), and has been produced in theaters throughout the world. 
Now, with your help, PRIVATE LIVES will be coming to GTC Burbank.Who is Table for Two Productions?

Table for Two Productions was founded by Stasha Surdyke and Christopher Trela to create and host theatrical & culinary fundraising events for arts
organizations, as well as present professionally produced plays in venues
throughout . Christopher
and Stasha co-write the Table for Two dining column in the Newport Beach
Independent, and they are the co-editors of Coastal Food and Wine, a website
devoted to covering epicurean experiences along the coast of So Cal.
Nominated for a 2011 Women in Business Award from the Orange County Business
Journal, Stasha Surdyke is an Ovation nominated actress and vocalist who has appeared
in numerous commercials, films, television shows and theatrical productions
throughout Southern California, including a
starring role in An Empty Plate in the CafÃ© du Grand Boeuf at The Laguna
Playhouse. A graduate of University of Washingtonâ€™s School of Drama, she was
one of eighteen students accepted into the schoolâ€™s prestigious two-year Suzuki
program and received her BA in Drama and a minor in Communications from UW.
Stasha is a proud member of Actorâ€™s Equity and Screen Actors Guild.
In addition to her performing credits, Stasha oversees media relations and
other creative services for the boutique PR agency, ArtsPR. Stasha designed the
award-winning press kit for Laguna Playhouseâ€™s production of The Second City:
Can You Be More Pacific? which won the 2011 PROTOS Award of Excellence this
year. She is a member of the Southern California Restaurant Writers
Association, Orange County Press Club, and the NoÃ«l Coward Society.
Twice nominated for Entrepreneur of the Year by the Orange County Business
Journal, Christopher Trela is the owner and president of ArtsPR, a boutique PR
agency that specializes in public relations services for arts organizations.
Current clients include The Laguna Playhouse, Irvine Barclay Theatre, Long
Beach Symphony Orchestra, Festival Ballet Theatre, Chance Theater, The Queenâ€™s
Gallery/MUZEO, Costa Mesa Playhouse, Young Singers of OC, and Classical Mystery
Tour (a Beatles tribute band that performs with orchestras around the world). 
He is also the founder of New Voices Playwrights Workshop, and has written
plays that have been produced at venues throughout Orange County, Los Angeles, and New York. Christopher is President of the Orange County Press Club, serves as an Arts
Commissioner for the City of Newport Beach, and
is an Adjunct Professor of Public Relations at Chapman University.
Christopher is a member of the Public Relations Society of America.
Stasha and Christopher thank you for your support! 
For more information on Table for Two Productions and PRIVATE LIVES, visit our
website: www.Table4Two-PrivateLives.com.

story:
My name is Fee King.  I'm the writer, producer and performer of:  "Momma Was a Bad Mutha...Shut yo Mouth". 

 "Honey..you haven't lived enough to write a 1-woman show". So, I wrote MY 1-woman show

Momma Was a BAD Mutha... Shut Yo Mouthis not only full of laughs, reminiscing and trash talking, but it sends a powerful message of hope filled with life lessons and coping skills for  young people in under privileged and disadvantaged communities.

It's Real! Raw! It's True!  This is the story of young girl's untimely coming of age amidst her mother's weekend house parties.  The most happening house on the block.

Imagine:

.  Being pregnant at the age of 12

.  Being molested by your mother's boyfriend at the age of 12

.  Having an abortion at the age of 12

 

If sharing my story...my TRUTH, can help another child from being a VICTIM of his/her circumstances or situation...then I must share this story.

Because of this show, the following happened in my life:

.  I healed  past traumas 

.  I mended the tumultous relationship I had with my mother before she passed of cancer

.  I forgave the men who hurt, misrepresented themselves and violated me

.  I learned to forgive myself, love myself and others 

.  I stopped living my life as a VICTIM

This show is in honor of my mother's life and death.  This show is the vehicle that I believe, with my Whole HEART, can help prevent & bring awarness to:

.  Teen pregnancy epedemic

.  alarming high school drop out rates

.  dependents of alcoholism and drug addiction

.  Young girls and women chosing lifestyles based on what happened to them, early in life; as opposed to who they really are

.  plight of women trying to find their voice

*I want people to get mad and then move into action and do something ..get involved when  they hear about a young boy or girl who's been molested, sexually assaulted, raped and victimized*

I'm in ACTION; however, it takes a Village to raise a child.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need a minimum of $9,600.00 for:

.  Theater rental for 4-6 performances

.  20-25 rehearsals      .  Director 

.  treat a group of disadvantaged/at-risk teens to see the show and workshop for FREE (This may include transporation to and from show)

.  treat a group from sober living/rehab facility to see the show and workshop for FREE (This may include transporation to and from show)

.  Stage Manager      .  Publicity/Publiist      . Flyer/postcard     . Social Media

.  Props

We have some Dynamite perks:

.  private track and field coaching session w/Johnny Gray

.  Signed autograph photo of Olympian:  Duane Bang Solomon

.  FREE Tickets to the show for anyone who donates $55 or more

.  2- FREE 5-gallons of Premium alkaline water

.  Coffee Bean Gift Card

.  Co-Producer Credit

AND more to come from our celebrity friends!!

_____________________________________________________________________

The Impact your Contribution will have on this project:

People, in the acting community, used to ask me if I wanted to be the next Hally Berry or Meryl Streep? " I am using acting as platform to Empower, Inspire and help Improve the lives of inner-city kids", I would say. I couldn't believe I was saying that outloud; which made it real for me. I didn't know that was my life's calling, but apparently my higher self knew.  Opportunity has been met with drive and a strong desire.  When young people feel loved, safe and supported - they are more likely to thrive and conribute to society in a positve and empactful way versus the ladder. They then resort to criminal activities,  pre-mature sexual behaviors, seek low-paying jobs, resort to abusing alcohol, drugs, have anger issues and a plethora of other negative and detrimental activities. Who am I NOT to share my story with the World.

My partner, USA Track and Field Hall of Famer and 4 Time Olympian:  Johnny Gray and i, currently work with the R. eady  S.et  G. old Olympic program. We mentor, teach track and field drills and the importance of teammanship and leadership skills to both elementary and middle school aged kids.  Our program starts with a motivational session where we Inspire kids to aspire to Greatness. We give them tools that will help them believe and then achieve their dreams and goals. We've recently adopted our first middle school in South L.A.:  George Washington Carver

Our short term goal is to raise monies that will allow us to expose this show and our Js youth Foundation 501-C-3 program to the kids who will benefit the most.

Our long term goal is to secure funds, via an investor partnership, grants and sponsorship, that will support us in taking this show and our accompanying track and field mentoring workshop program across the country. 

Our desire is to work with:

.  at risk/disadvantage youth ages 9-19

.  kids in juvenile detention facilities

.  foster care homes

.  youth transitioning out of the foster care system

.  teen shelters

.  those in need of mentoring, coaching, a helping hand, understanding and LOVE

 

Thank you for allowing me to share

 

Fee King

www.badmommatheplay.com         www.youtube.com/feeking 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

.  Producer     .  website assistance      .  socia media    . News/Media

story:
Intersect Dance Collective exists to use the art of dance to encourage the growth of individuals and the greater Jackson, MS, community through education, charitable projects, and choreographic and performance opportunities.  This summer, we're taking the show on the road.  We'll be performing and volunteering in locations throughout Indiana and Ohio.  Please consider partnering with us to help us with our travel expenses.  Let's bring some love and laughter to new audiences!

Intersect Dance Collective was founded in 2010 by husband/wife team Andy and Alli Leatherman, along with a handful of other wonderful people (who just happen to be dancers). Intersect is a modern dance company based in Jackson, Mississippi. From the beginning, however, Intersect has been not-your-typical dance company, with a unique style that is appreciated by both dance enthusiasts and those who have never seen dance before. Intersect believes that teaching dance is actually teaching about life, and that providing opportunities for dancers and choreographers to practice their art is the best way to help them grow. In addition, Intersect believes that performances should benefit others both in the intangible and tangible sense; Intersect often donates a portion of its ticket sales to help out local charities such as soup kitchens and special-needs preschools.

story:
What We Do:

Here at Broadway Wishes: NYC, we love theater. Love it. But we also love giving back. We combined our passions and designed a group that celebrates the art of giving.  

Broadway Wishes was founded in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania by cancer survivor Lauren Buben. Diagnosed with Leukemia at the age of three, Lauren decided she needed to give back to her childhood community, the Make-A-Wish Foundation®. Together with forty of her friends, Lauren raised over $10,000 to fund six year-old Hannah’s wish to be in the ensemble of Broadway’s revival production of Annie. With the funds raised, Lauren and her team were even able to help a second child.

Inspired by Lauren and our experience with her in Philadelphia, we were intrigued by the opportunities New York City had to offer Broadway Wishes. Founding a New York City chapter at New York University became the next step.

We want to take theater arts to the streets for a good cause!

What We Need & What You Get:

To help our wishes come true, we need your help! 

We want to raise $1000 for our start up expenses (the things that make this work possible, i.e. posters, rental spaces).

Anything money raised over $1000 will be going to our charities!!

We need to be able to provide resourses that will make our events successful- having successful events means sharing art with more people, and sharing art with more people means being able to give more to various charities!

No matter how much we make, reaching our goal of $1000 or not, we will be using these funds to further our cause!

The Impact

With Broadway Wishes: NYC, the theater community will be able to celebrate the art of giving- a misson that we feel strongly about. We want to be able to educate people from all walks of life, inspire people with music, and learn from our amazing New York City community. Bringing people together through the world of theater and music is a no brainer- what better way to connect than through a medium that can make us laugh, dance, and sing?

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate, its ok! You can still help us out! Please use the share tools on this page to spread the word about our mission!

Check us out on Facebook and Twitter and talk to your friends!

Help us make the world a better place through art and giving!

story:
Hello, I am Mark Dundas Wood, a writer and dramaturg living in New York City. I am thrilled to announce that a New York production of my play The Tragic Muse has been accepted into the Living Literature Festival at the Metropolitan Playhouse, this January 13-26. The theme of the 2014 festival is “The Gilded Age”—and perhaps no American writer defines that era (1875-1901) more authoritatively than the cosmopolitan Henry James.

James’s 1890 novel The Tragic Muse is not one of his better-known works. But when I read it several years ago, I was taken in immediately by its sweeping romantic story, unfolding against the political and artistic backdrop of England and France as the nineteenth century draws to its close. Most of all, I was intrigued by the glimpses James provides of the theatrical life of the time. 

The “muse” in James’s story is an aspiring actress who becomes introduced to a pair of cousins from an established British political family. Both cousins are drawn to her. The beautiful and ambitious performer becomes a disruptive—and finally a transformative—force in their lives. The Tragic Muse is a serious novel about what it takes to become—and to remain—an artist, but at times it is also very funny. James’s wit in this novel has a sharpness that at times calls to mind that of his contemporary, Oscar Wilde. 

As a dramaturg I've worked for New Professional Theatre and the New York Musical Theatre Festival. My theatre writing has appeared in such publications as Back Stage and American Theatre magazine. I have an MFA in creative writing from the University of Oregon and an MFA in dramaturgy from Columbia University.

Directing The Tragic Muse is Jesse Jou. His inventive productions, of both classical and contemporary material, have been seen at Soho Rep, Ars Nova, the New York International Fringe Festival, The Kitchen Theatre Co., and the Yale Cabaret. 

Your contribution will fund ample rehearsals, casting, costumes, design, and razor-sharp performances for the debut of this Jamesian treat. Please join us on what we know will be an inspirational journey. We will keep you posted every step of the way. 

Thank you!

Mark Dundas Wood

story:
Please Help Us Continue To Keep Live Theatre Thriving

Contribute ANY AMOUNT by clicking CONTRIBUTE NOW

A 501(c)3 Non-Profit Company

What this really means is our actors are here because it's their greatest passion.

Our theatre is warm and inviting and audiences love the intimacy they feel with the actors and the worlds we create.

However, with only 45 seats ticket sales do not cover our production costs and to remain open we rely on donations from fans of live theatre.

WWW.ATWATERPLAYHOUSE.COM

Why Is Live Theatre Important Today

"It is a crucial part of our culture that we preserve this unique art form before technology completely takes over." - Rawan - Http://macaulay.cuny.edu 

"Theater is so important for our society today despite its waning popularity because it gives not only growth, but also character and culture to a society."       -  Rawan - Http://macaulay.cuny.edu  

"Is that it influences the way we think and feel about our own lives and encourages us to take a hard look at ourselves, our values, and our behavior."    - Howard Shalwitz 

THERESA REBECK

Theresa is among a handful of modern day contemporary playwrights cut in the same mold as many of the greats from the past like, Tennessee Williams, Pinter, Strindburg, Arthur Miller, Sam Shepard, Eugene O'neill...

What sets these writers apart is that they go beyond simply entertaining us.  Their works examine the most pressing societal issues of the times in the hopes of inspiring a better tomorrow. 

SUNDAY ON THE ROCKS is important, challenging, relatable, and at the same time hilarious and entertaining.

What We Need & What You Get

This is an easy one. We need money to build our sets, to pay the royalties for great plays like this one, for costumes, lights, set pieces, props, and of course rent and utilities to keep our theatre sparkling for our loyal audience.

We strive to provide a memorable human experience for our loyal audience.

THE COMPANY'S COMMITMENT

Dramatic live theatre is a dying art form in LA and it is extremely important to our theatre company members. If we can touch even one person with our work we feel as though we've made a difference.

Over the course of eight years we feel as though the stories we've told not only entertained our audiences but also left them considering the most important social issues of our times.

http://atwaterplayhouse.com/past-productions-2/

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate we understand. Please help us spread the word to friends, family and theatre fans in your circle through social media. Indiegogo has great sharing tools available.

story:
Finding the right location for a performance is the most important thing in the world to the 3 of us as site-specific producers. We spend almost as much time and energy chasing the spaces as we do on the shows we put in them.

For our upcoming play MANNA-HATA, we believe that we have found a truly singular place for creating an exceptional production: the iconic James A. Farley Post Office on 8th Avenue. The building is bigger than even we can take advantage of, but we’re going to take audiences through some unique, behind-the-scenes areas in this massive facility.

We’re pulling out all the stops for MANNA-HATA, but now we need that thing that always dogs us: more money.

To truly fill the massive post office space, we need to raise another $3,000 for the larger-than-usual artistic and technical team, and to cover the unique production materials and items that are needed for such a large venue: lighting for 3 floors, costumes for 20 actors playing over 100 characters, security guards for the historic space, even cleaning supplies for rooms that haven’t been occupied in years! And it’s coming up soon – June 7-23, 2013 – so we need your help NOW!

Another thing that is special about this project is that the post office is about to become a train station, the Daniel Patrick Moynihan Station. It’s going to take a few years, but this could be the last chance people have to see inside what was once the country’s largest postal facility.

It’s a once-in-lifetime opportunity. You don’t want to miss it. There’s more about the production below, and hopefully you’ll want to be part of this show by donating something, anything at all, right now.

Thank you so very, very much.

Barry, Catherine & Ralph

 

MANNA-HATA is…

a theatrical spectacle combining classic writings with original dialogue, live music, dance, puppetry, and projection. Audiences will travel room-to-room through the James A. Farley Post Office on 8th Avenue, an iconic City landmark and future home of Moynihan Station—a site-specific journey through 400 years of compelling NYC history.

Guided by the likes of Walt Whitman, Jane Jacobs, Shirley Chisholm and a contemporary Lenape Indian, MANNA-HATA brings to life an incredible array of NYC’s colorful characters: famous scoundrels (Peter Stuyvesant, Boss Tweed, Robert Moses); artistic legends (Edna St. Vincent Millay, Dorothy Parker) and other beloved City figures (Emily Roebling, Charles Pfaff). There are tales of graft, oppression, and violence, as well as stories, poems and songs of love dedicated to the Great City herself.

We are so proud to have brought together an amazing team for MANNA-HATA: performers Ashleigh Awusie, Eric C. Bailey, Jimmy Brooks, Cristi Castro, Tina Chilip, Cherrye Davis, Kevin Drouillard, Dionisio Flores-Garcia, Lorna Hampson, Christopher Hurt, Hank Lin, Katey Parker, Grace Phelan, Catherine Porter, Everett Quinton, J. Kelly Salvadore, Jennae Alexa Ruiz Santos, Precious Sipin, Nomi Tichman and Bradley Wells; Co-Directors Barry Rowell and Kathleen Amshoff; Composer Howard Fishman; Choreographer Lynn Neuman; Visual Designer Lake Simons; Lighting Designer David Castaneda; Costume Designer Angela Harner; Video and Projection designer Myrel Chernick; Choreographic Assistant Malinda Crump; Production Stage Manager Maxwell Waters; Production Coordinator Heather Olmstead; and Press Representative: Karen Greco.

The culmination of 3 years of development and planning, and over 10 years of dreaming before that, MANNA-HATA is truly Peculiar Works Project’s most ambitious project to date.

Peculiar Works Project is…

an OBIE Award-winning company led by Co-Artistic Directors Ralph Lewis, Catherine Porter, and Barry Rowell. We perform in unconventional, non-theater spaces because we believe unique sites impact our work, the work in turn impacts the site, and audiences then experience both in surprising new ways. We have taken performances directly into local communities, presenting site-specific productions in public spaces, city streets, landmark buildings, gutted storefronts and other peculiar sites throughout NYC.

Show website: http://www.peculiarworks.org/index.php/works/current-show

Company website: www.peculiarworks.org

"Good Old New York" by Jelly Roll Morton, performed by the Howard Fishman Quartet (buy it on iTunes: http://goo.gl/H571R)

story:
Linda can’t stop baking pies ever since her husband up and left. Her son, Nicholas can’t stay out of trouble at school and is on the brink of being expelled. Could their only hope be Sara, the new guidance counsellor? Or will this trio find themselves in an unprecedented familial tangle with life changing consequences?


Hatched is loosely based on my personal experience as an egg donor in 2004. It was written and inspired by personal interviews with egg donors, donor children and recipient couples. 

The purpose of this work is to give voice to an alternative sector of the growing sub-society of the infertility trade. No-where in the “normal” conversation surrounding this abnormal topic does egg donors surface. Egg donors are expected to be the silent partners in this medical industry. Hatched strives to give them a voice.

Alongside this theatrical creation, we are working to create a Toronto based donor support group and network.

Hatched was read at an informal partnership with George Brown College in 2010. Excerpts from the piece were also heard at Theatre Passe Muraille’s Buzz Festival. A second reading of the play and workshop occurred in April of 2012, which was extremely instrumental in finalizing the present draft of the script. The play has also been reviewed and edited by respected members of the arts community. 

The playwright, Claire Burns, is a Toronto based actor and playwright. Her first play, True North, was short listed for Nightwood’s Write from the Hip. She participated in Driftwood Theatre’s Trafalgar 24 in 2011, producing The Anatomy Lesson. Hatched has been workshopped at the Buzz Festival (TPM) and is currently being produced by Triangle-Pi Productions. Claire is a graduate of the University of Toronto as well as George Brown Theatre School. 

 

The Assisted Human Reproduction Act made it illegal to buy eggs, sperm and embryos in Canada.

"As  reproductive technologies stretches the notion of the family beyond the nuclear, and  Canada bends to accommodate this evolution, this piece of federal legislation inadvertently forces a slew of prospective parents underground, towards an ever growing black market."

"The laws are trying to enforce a moral vision on a society that does not share it. Of course women are going online to search for ovum. What other
choice do they have?" 

       

      Supporting Material

http://www.cbc.ca/video/news/audioplayer.html?clipid=2198382210

 

We are asking for donations that will

go directly into the cost of producing

this show.

Your donations will go towards:

  Renting the theatre 

  Set / Props / Costumes

  Marketing and Publicity


With Government cuts to the arts, private funding has become ever more integral in ensuring the growth of Canadian theatre.

 

Diane Allen

          Executive Director of the Infertility Network of Canada

Dr. Carolyn Bennett
          Toronto M.P. for St. Paul’s. family physician and a founding partner of Bedford Medical Associates in downto College Hospital and Assistant Professor in the Department of Family and Community Medicine at the University of Toronto.

 

Media coverage

CBC - Metro Morning Radio

http://www.cbc.ca/metromorning/episodes/2012/05/24/egg-donation/

http://www.cbc.ca/video/news/audioplayer.html?clipid=2238698893

 

The Grid TO

Interview with Claire Burns by  Sarah-Joyce Battersby

http://www.thegridto.com/city/local-news/ova-experienced/

 

 

  For more information, please visit:

http://hatchedtheplay.wordpress.com/

https://www.facebook.com/hatchedtheplay

https://twitter.com/#!/hatchedtheplay

 

Work Cited

- Dickens, Bernard; Professor emeritus of health law and policy at the University of Toronto

 


Claire Burns (Playwright)

 Claire Burns is a writer, performer and creator of theatre. She most recently was a guest playwright for Driftwood Theatre’s 24 hour playwriting contest and has performed selections of her play Hatched for the Buzz Festival (Theatre Passe Muraille). Her short play “True North” that was shortlisted for Nightwood Theatre’s Write from the Hip. She has performed her own works (Pine and Games) with Strangebird Theatre and through George Brown College Theatre School respectively. Claire was also a collaborator in the creation of work by the Blyth Festival’s Young Company in its 2009 season. Claire is a graduate of George Brown College and is an alumni of the University of Toronto with an HBA in Political Science and History. Claire was recently seen in The Mail Order Bride (Blyth Festival), The Nuttalls (Blyth Festival), Pride and Prejudice (Grand Theatre), The Sad and Cautionary Tale of Smackheaded Peter (Summerworks), Breaking News (Triangle Pi) and This Wide Night (Mermaid Theatre). Upcoming include Hatched (Triangle Pi) and The Mistress Project (Theatre Heterae)

 

Jeannette Lambermont-Morey (Director)                                                        

Jeannette Lambermont-Morey has directed major productions in major theatres across Canada and the United States, from the Stratford Festival, to the Virginia Stage Company; including such theatres as The Citadel (Edmonton), The Great Canadian Theatre Company (Ottawa), Atlantic Theatre Festival (Nova Scotia), Manitoba Theatre Centre (Winnipeg), Theatre Aquarius (Hamilton) the Thousand Islands Playhouse (Gananoque), Talk is Free Theatre (Barrie), the Muskoka Festival (Gravenhurst) and Huron Country Playhouse (Grand Bend); and Toronto theatres, Factory Theatre, Canadian Stage, Harbourfront Centre, and The Toronto International Fringe Festival, etc. Jeannette directed the World Leaders Tributes to Harold Pinter and Robert Rauschenberg as part of the internationally acclaimed Series produced by Harbourfront at the Liberty Grand in the fall of 2001. That year also marked her 8th season with the Stratford Festival in Ontario, where she directed Henry V.

Other significant Stratford Festival productions include As You Like It (2000), Pride and Prejudice (1999) and The Miracle Worker (1998). In earlier years at the Festival she directed Titus Andronicus, The Grand Inquisitor and Swan Song (1989 and 1990), as well as serving as collaborating director on The Comedy of Errors and The Relapse (1989) and assisting Richard Monette on The Taming of the Shrew (1988) and John Neville on Othello (1987). Her hit production of The Syringa Tree (The Citadel) won a Sterling Award for Liisa Repo-Martell; and her productions of Twelfth Nightin High Park (Canadian Stage) and Digging For Fire (Paramour Productions) were both nominated for a Dora Mavor Moore awards for Outstanding Production.  Jeannette works extensively in college and university theatre programs as a director and instructor. Among her regulars are George Brown College, York University, the Juilliard School (NY), the University of Alberta, Ryerson University, Dartmouth College (NH) and the University of Victoria.

 

Brett Haynes (Producer)

Brett graduated from the University of Waterloo, majoring in Drama and Set Design. He then went on to graduate from George Brown Theatre School in 2008. Since graduating, Brett has dove into the world of theatre. He as worked for Canadian Stage as an Artistic Programming Intern and Script Coordinator for the Tarragon Theatre. In 2010, Brett started the company, Triangle Pi Productions Inc. which is dedicated to producing new Canadian work as well as providing opportinuties for emerging artists to showcase their talent to the theatre community. Triangle Pi Productions Inc. produced its first show, Breaking News, as part of the 2011 Toronto Fringe Festival. Breaking News, written and directed by Brett, went on to win Critic’s Pick and Patron’s Pick.

Along with producing Hatched, Triangle Pi Productions will also be producing Vacant; a new play by the emerging writer, Fraser Elsdon in the summer of 2012.

 

Catherine Fitch (Actor)

Catherine Fitch has been acting in theatre, film, television and radio for over 20 years.Starting with the critically acclaimed "Sowth of Wawa" ,through her Gemini award winning performance in "Butterbox Babies", to her Gemini nominated performances in "This is Wonderland", Catherine has been dedicated to pursuing her career in Canada and working with Canadian artists. Most recently she has spent 4 years at the Blyth Festival - a festival of new Canadian plays and play development. She has worked there with writers such as Michael Healy (The Nutalls), Kate Lynch (Early August), Gary Kirkham (Pearl Gidley), Paul Ciufo (A Killing Snow) and Marcia Johnson (Courting Johanna) on first productions of their work. Other theatre credits include: Half Life(Theatre Aquarius); Orpheus Descending(MTC/Royal Alex); Forever Yours Marie-Lou(Centaur); Escape From Happiness(Factory Theatre) Other TV credits include: Series regular on Living in Your Car and Slings and Arrows; Murdoch Mysteries: Profoundly Normal; Lost Girl Other film credits include: Niagra Motel; Prizewinner of Defiance  Ohio; Knockaround Guys and the upcoming The Boy Who Smelled Like Fish and Picture Day.

story:
Cause It's My Birthday

My name is Dev Dugal.  Every year for my bday I fundraise for a social cause. This year, I'm raising money for a fabulous organization called Manav Sadhna based in India at the Gandhi Ashram.  This campaign serves as a kick starter for the 2012 North America Ekatva Tour.


EKATVA

The journey of 16 children, 

from the slums of Ahmedabad to the spirit of Oneness. 


And a dance-drama show that will touch the world.


The Impact

The impact simply put is in the spirit of Oneness.  The tour occurred only once, 10 years ago.  It was quite an experience with individuals pushing in as we reached capacity to see/feel/hear and be ONE with the amazing children.

The tour is not cheap and the funds I'm raising will go towards securing a venue in Los Angeles for the 2012 show.  I'm also a part of the North America team to organize the multiple city tour.  


What We Need & What You Get

We need about $5,000 to secure a theater for the performance.  The money raised in this campaign will go to Manav Sadhna to use for the Los Angeles EKATVA show.  


We are scoping out corporate sponsors to also MATCH the amount raised so if your company matches, please let us know ASAP.  Any amount doubled is extremely helpful.


WAY MORE INFO...

manav sadhna: http://www.manavsadhna.org

EKATVA tour: http://bit.ly/EKATVA

the EKATVA blog: http://ekatva.blogspot.com/


Other Ways You Can Help

spread the word on facebook | twitter | google +


thanks in advance.  

one.
